SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Difficulty urinating, waking up 3-4 times per night to urinate
* History of present illness: Urination stream weak, takes time to empty bladder, symptoms have been ongoing for about six months and somewhat worse in recent months, no burning during urination, no recent urinary retention, no bowel issues, no chest pain or shortness of breath, tries to exercise, reports difficulty sitting to watch games, manages blood sugars with diet and medication
* Past medical history: History of coronary artery disease with stent placement, diabetes
* Social history: Not specified
* Family history: Not specified

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Heart: slight 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base; lungs: clear bilaterally; abdomen: nondistended, nontender, no masses, no rebound or guarding; prostate: enlarged, no masses on digital rectal exam
* Test results: No initial lab results provided; plan includes ordering labs, PSA, urinalysis, urine culture, echocardiogram, lipid panel, hemoglobin A1c

A (Assessment):

* Urinary difficulty, likely benign prostatic hyperplasia
* Cardiovascular: history of coronary artery disease, stable systolic murmur
* Diabetes: well-managed

P (Plan):

* Order PSA, routine blood tests, urinalysis, urine culture
* Prescribe Flomax 0.4 mg at night
* Refer to urology for further evaluation
* Order echocardiogram to follow up on heart murmur
* Continue Lipitor 40 mg daily, aspirin, metoprolol
* Order lipid panel
* Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily
* Order hemoglobin A1c
* Follow-up in 3-4 weeks
* Physician will contact urologist to arrange appointment
* Patient instructed to contact or message if concerns arise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right foot pain
* History of present illness: Injury occurred a couple of days ago while playing tennis; patient fell on the right foot while attempting to catch herself, resulting in pain, swelling, and bruising. No numbness or tingling reported. Pain partially alleviated by wrapping, icing, and ibuprofen.
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Play tennis recreationally with friends

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 125/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 18, temperature 97.1°F, oxygen saturation 100%, pulse 60/min
* Physical exam: Right foot shows bruising on plantar and dorsal aspects, swelling, tenderness to palpation of midfoot, positive piano key test of first and second metatarsals, warm to touch; neurovascular exam shows capillary refill less than 3 seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, sensation intact; left foot exam normal
* Test results: X-ray review indicates subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal, 3 mm separation of the first and second metatarsal bases, and a bony fragment in the lisfranc joint space

A (Assessment):

* Right foot pain consistent with Lisfranc fracture

P (Plan):

* Recommend surgical intervention to realign bones using plates and screws to prevent complications such as poor bone healing, loss of foot arch, and arthritis; MRI ordered to assess for ligament injury
* Surgery scheduled as day surgery with same-day discharge
* Postoperative instructions: Cast application, crutches for 6-8 weeks, follow-up in 1 week
* Physical therapy recommended post-surgery to strengthen muscles and optimize recovery
* Discussed potential risks of surgery, including bleeding, nerve damage, and loss of sensation; provided with informational paperwork
* Patient expressed concern about surgery and being out for the rest of the season; explained season-long absence and rehabilitation plan

* Chief complaint: Left back pain, blood in urine
* History of present illness: Pain started about three days ago, constant, traveling lower, severe enough that the patient cannot get comfortable, no fever but chills and nausea, has not passed the stone yet
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 130-150 mmHg systolic (varies), pulse 78 bpm, no other vitals provided
* Physical exam: Tenderness to palpation of the abdomen and back, CVA tenderness on the right, lungs clear bilaterally, heart: grade 2 systolic ejection murmur

* Diabetes, well-controlled with metformin

P (Plan):

* Educate patient on passing the stone and monitoring for complications

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sudden right back pain, radiating to groin
* History of present illness: Pain started about a week ago during work with horses, sudden onset, associated with sweating and nausea, pain radiated to groin, pain has since decreased and been intermittent, no blood in urine noted, no change in urine color, no previous kidney stones, family history of kidney stones (father)

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits, no fever observed
* Physical exam: No tenderness to palpation of the abdomen, no rebound or guarding, tenderness over right flank consistent with kidney involvement, no evidence of hydronephrosis on CT imaging, stone measuring 0.5 cm in the proximal right ureter

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone (nephrolithiasis) in right ureter, measuring 0.5 centimeters, no evidence of obstruction or hydronephrosis

P (Plan):

* Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate passage of the stone
* Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain management
* Continue Tylenol as needed for breakthrough pain
* Advise patient to use strainer when urinating
* Order BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to assess for infection
* Schedule follow-up in 1-2 weeks to evaluate stone passage; discuss further treatment such as lithotripsy if not passed by then
* Send nurse with prescription before discharge

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Non-healing ulcer on right foot present for approximately six to eight weeks
* History of present illness: Ulcer located on right lateral foot near the fifth metacarpal metatarsophalangeal joint, size 2x3 cm, with granulation tissue and slight purulent discharge, no associated pain or cellulitis, no fever or chills reported
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus with elevated hemoglobin A1c (>9), prior myocardial infarction in 2018 with stent placement in right coronary artery
* Social history: Former smoker (ceased approximately four years ago after 20+ years of smoking 2 packs/day), no recent activity such as long walks, current activity mostly hanging around the house
* Additional information: Occasionally experiences sensory changes such as numbness and tingling especially in cold weather; no recent trauma or footwear issues reported; no complaints of chest pain or shortness of breath

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/80 mmHg, heart rate 60 bpm, no fever
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention or carotid bruits, lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally; cardiac exam: systolic ejection murmur 2/6 at the left base; lower extremities: no palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses; ulcerated lesion measuring 2x3 cm on the right lateral foot near the fifth metacarpal joint, no cellulitis, tender to palpation in that area, presence of granulation tissue and slight purulent discharge

A (Assessment):

* Non-healing ulcer of the right foot in a diabetic patient
* History of coronary artery disease with prior MI and stent placement
* No current evidence of cellulitis or systemic infection
* Possible peripheral vascular insufficiency affecting wound healing
* Well-controlled cardiac status on ongoing medications

P (Plan):

* Order arterial ultrasound of the lower extremities to assess blood flow
* Refer to podiatry for specialized wound care and management of the foot ulcer
* Coordinate with primary care physician to optimize diabetes control
* Continue aspirin therapy for cardiovascular protection
* Consult with a vascular surgeon regarding potential procedures such as artery stenting or bypass surgery to improve blood supply
* Await further vascular assessment to guide treatment decisions

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right flank pain for approximately one week, with blood in urine
* History of present illness: Constant right-sided flank pain that has moved slightly to right lower side, no pain during urination, N/A for nausea and vomiting, felt some nausea, experienced pain over the weekend during Easter break, no fever or chills
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Family history: Father had kidney stones and may have passed several
* Social history: Participated in Easter activities, limited activity due to pain

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, no fever (exact values not provided)
* Physical exam: Mild tenderness to palpation in the abdomen, no rebound or guarding; right costovertebral angle tenderness; slight pain upon abdominal palpation
* Test results: CT scan showing a 0.5 cm stone in the proximal right ureter, no hydronephrosis observed

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone in the right ureter, measuring 0.5 centimeters, located in the proximal ureter; inflammation of the kidney suggested by tenderness

P (Plan):

* Advise increased fluid intake to promote passage of the stone
* Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg as needed for pain
* Provide a strain for urine to monitor stone passage
* Order blood urea nitrogen, serum creatinine (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture
* Plan follow-up in 1 to 2 weeks; if symptoms persist, consider further treatment such as lithotripsy
* Educate patient about signs of infection and when to seek urgent care

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Itchy scalp with dandruff
* History of present illness: Having persistent itchy, scaly, and erythematous patches on the scalp for several years, worsening over the past six months; no new hair products or chemicals used recently; tried over-the-counter treatments such as Head and Shoulders and castor oil with no significant improvement; no associated symptoms like joint pain, fever, or weight loss; family history possibly includes sister with dry scalp
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: No significant emotional or environmental stressors reported
* Family history: Possible sibling with similar scalp symptoms

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 130/68 mmHg, heart rate 98 bpm, respiratory rate 18, temperature 97.7°F
* Physical exam: Demarcated scaly erythematous plaques diffusely present across the back of the scalp, with visible dandruff
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging findings reported

A (Assessment):

* Scalp psoriasis

P (Plan):

* Prescribe clobetasol 0.05% solution to be applied twice daily on affected scalp areas
* Continue use of T-gel shampoo
* Educate patient on application technique and importance of adhering to twice-daily steroid application during flare-ups
* Advise to follow up in three months or sooner if condition worsens
* Instruct patient to use steroid solution as needed during flare-ups
* Provide education on the chronic nature of psoriasis, flare management, and importance of ongoing treatment adherence

transcription:
[doctor] hey elijah how are you
[patient] i'm doing okay
[doctor] so i see here that your primary care provider sent you over it looks like you were doing some yard work yesterday and dropped a landscape brick on your foot can what so what's going on with your right foot today
[patient] it's a little sore today but you know i hurt my foot before but this is the first time where i'm actually being seen for it
[doctor] okay so you say you've injured your right foot before tell me a little bit about that injury
[patient] twenty years ago i broke my ankle i had to put in a cast but that seems to be okay but you know sometimes it'll give me trouble once in a while it feels a little sore it swells up at times
[doctor] okay
[patient] and my other ankle too is sore sometimes and i've had surgery for that too and you know one of those things where you know it might give out once in a while but i'm not sure that's related to what the you know break dropping on my foot but you know either way my foot's a little sore
[doctor] okay alright so when you dropped that brick on your foot were you able to get up and keep working or did you have to get off your you know not stop weightbearing and and get off that foot can you tell me a little bit about after the traumatic incident
[patient] i you know it was a little sore i called a few names you know god damn why is this in my foot but you know i kept working putting it around a little bit but now it's got swollen so i got to see my doctor he told me i had to go see you here i am so tell me what's going on with it
[doctor] so what have you been doing for the pain since the initial insult
[patient] lucken it up
[doctor] okay have you taken any medications safe for example tylenol or ibuprofen for the pain
[patient] no i feel like taking the medicine
[doctor] okay and then just out of curiosity you said you were doing some landscaping have you been over to landscapes warehouse new here in town my wife and i were just over there this last weekend and picked up a whole bunch of stuff you had a chance to make it over there yet
[patient] no not yet i heard about it though i might have to make a trip once my foot heals
[doctor] alright that sounds good now just out of curiosity can you rate your pain for me right now zero being none ten being the worst pain you've ever been in your life
[patient] eleven out of ten
[doctor] okay and then have you experienced any numbness or tingling of that foot since the incident
[patient] yeah the whole foot is numb
[doctor] okay
[patient] but been now for a long time
[doctor] okay i'm gon na do a quick physical exam now your vitals look good and i would like to do a focused exam of your right foot the there is some bruising on the bottom part of your foot and on the top part as well and i do appreciate the associated swelling and i also recognize that you do have tenderness to palpation for midfoot now for your neurovascular exam of your right foot your capillary refill is brisk in less than three seconds i do note a strong bounding dorsalis pedis pulse with motor and sensation is intact for that foot i also like to call out the fact that it matches bilaterally which is important i'm gon na go ahead and review the diagnostic imaging results so we did a x-ray of that right foot and i do notice dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a three millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and presence of bony fragments so let me tell you a little bit about my assessment and plan now your right foot pain is due to a lisfranc fracture which is a fracture to your second metatarsal bone and the top of your foot this is where the metatarsals meet those cuboids okay so it where the bones come together in your foot now there are a lot of ligaments in your foot so i do want to order an mri just to assess if there is any injuries to those ligaments now based on your exam and looking at the x-ray you're most likely going to need surgery now the reason why this is important is if we have poor bone alignment or ligament healing you can this can lead to losing the arch in your foot you could becoming flat-footed and also developing arthritis now what's gon na be key here is the surgery is going to allow those bones and ligaments to heal properly we are going to put them back into place using plates and screws now the key thing is going to be it's going to be outpatient surgery so it's going to be same day i'll see you in the morning and then you'll be discharged home that evening and we will do a follow-up i wan na see you in twenty four hours post procedure but then i'll see you again in two weeks you're gon na be in a cast and i'm gon na have you use crutches you're not gon na be able to weight-bear on that foot for six to eight weeks what we'll do is we'll advance your ambulating gradually based on how you heal and based on how you tolerate the procedure i know i have covered a lot of material quickly but this is really gon na be the best course of action for you to have a good outcome now do you have any questions come answers concerns before i have the nurse come in finish the paperwork and get you set up for your procedure which we are going to do tomorrow if you're agreeable to that
[patient] what about putting in a cast can i just stay in the cast
[doctor] you could but what we found is the best outcome is aligning those bones with plates and screws to make sure that they heal properly so you have the best outcome possible
[patient] so if the surgery is going to be tomorrow when am i going to get my mri
[doctor] so what what we will do is the good news is we have an outpatient mri facility downstairs and i'm going to send the order down and we'll get you your mri this afternoon
[patient] can i think about it and we have some time
[doctor] sure
[patient] okay
[doctor] alright thanks elijah
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right foot soreness and swelling after dropping a brick on it
* History of present illness: Injury occurred after dropping a brick onto the right foot during yard work, initially sore with swelling developing later, pain rated 11/10, numbness present since incident, no medications taken
* Past medical history: Previous ankle fractures (20 years ago), surgeries for ankle issues, occasional soreness, swelling, and giving way
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Bruising on the dorsal and plantar surfaces of the right foot, swelling, tenderness to palpation at midfoot, neurovascular exam: brisk capillary refill, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, motor and sensation intact, bilateral comparison normal
* Test results: X-ray shows dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal, 3 mm separation of the first and second metatarsal bases, presence of bony fragments

A (Assessment):

* Lisfranc fracture of the right foot

P (Plan):

* Order MRI to assess ligament injury
* Surgical fixation with plates and screws recommended to realign bones and promote proper healing
* Outpatient same-day surgery scheduled
* Postoperative follow-up in 24 hours and again in two weeks
* Cast immobilization, non-weight bearing on the affected foot for 6 to 8 weeks, with gradual weight-bearing progression
* MRI to be performed at outpatient MRI facility this afternoon
* Patient advised to consider the surgical plan, with option to stay in a cast if preferred

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right eye twitch
* History of present illness: Eye twitching noticed for a couple of weeks, occurring several times an hour on some days, and not at all on others, usually without pain, sometimes accompanied by a sensation of facial movement and urge to blink, lasts several seconds, seems to not bother the child; no associated symptoms such as fever, chills, cough, headache, or sleep problems; no prior seizures or similar movements; no family history of seizures or Tourette's syndrome; child enjoys soccer and normal activities; reports no recent illnesses or troubling behavior
* Past medical history: No significant past medical history
* Social history: Plays soccer weekly, enjoys shopping for dresses and McDonald's chicken nuggets, experiences social interaction with peers, no mention of stressful events or other behavioral concerns
* Family history: No history of seizures, no known Tourette's syndrome

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Awake, alert, and oriented; speech clear and fluent; gait steady; cranial nerves intact; no focal neurologic findings; sensation intact; reflexes 2+ symmetric at biceps, triceps, knees, and ankles; eye movements normal; no abnormal movements observed during exam
* Test results: Video recording of eye twitch provided, observed to involve the entire side of her face, lasts several seconds, frequent blinking; neurological exam unremarkable

A (Assessment):

* Transient tics / Tourette-like movements (as clinically diagnosed, describing involuntary facial movements and blinking, with no evidence of seizure activity or other neurological deficits)

P (Plan):

* No medication or topical treatment recommended at this time.
* Reassurance provided to the family that tics are common in children and typically transient, often waxing and waning, without impact on overall development or activities.
* Advise to ignore the tics to prevent reinforcement or worsening.
* Monitoring for worsening or new symptoms; consider treatment if the tics become problematic or persistent beyond a year.
* No further testing or referrals indicated at this point.
* Follow-up as needed.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Recurrent lower respiratory infections
* History of present illness: Last week, patient experienced cough with mucus, shortness of breath, and low-grade fever; symptoms improved over the weekend. Reports frequent episodes of pneumonia approximately every month or every other month over the past six months, lasting from a few days to up to a week. Noted worsening symptoms when unloading hay on the farm.
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Farmer, helps unload hay, does not wear a mask during these activities, no smoking, no living with smokers, no known seasonal allergies
* Family history: Ten siblings, no specific medical history provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation 99% on room air
* Physical exam: Breathing slightly fast, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops, lung exam: fine rales present, no wheezes, no finger clubbing
* Test results: Chest x-ray shows some round glass opacities

A (Assessment):

* Recurrent lower respiratory infections
* Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (farmer’s lung) suspected, likely caused by inhalation of bacteria or mold from hay

P (Plan):

* Prescribe oral steroid to reduce lung inflammation
* Order a chest CT scan to confirm diagnosis
* Order pulmonary function test to assess respiratory impairment
* Advise elimination or protection from hay exposure—preferably avoid hay or wear a respirator when unloading hay
* Educate patient about likely cause and prevention strategies
* Follow-up to evaluate response to treatment and further management

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left big toe pain and redness
* History of present illness: Pain has been intermittent for about two weeks, worse last week during a trade show convention, described as throbbing and occasional sharp stabbing pain, worsened by walking and pressure at night, with increased redness and warmth
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Not riding a bike, is a runner, does not recall injury, takes ibuprofen twice daily with no relief
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Left big toe is red, warm, tender to palpation, with limited range of motion, approximately 10-20 degrees of plantar flexion causing pain, joint grinding sensation when moved, tenderness on lateral side, palpable bone spur, limited dorsiflexion
* Imaging: X-ray shows a large bone spur on the top of the big toe joint and significant cartilage loss, consistent with arthritis (hallux rigidus)

A (Assessment):

* Hallux rigidus (arthritis of the big toe joint) with bone spur and cartilage loss

P (Plan):

* Prescribe orthotic insert for shoe support
* Initiate anti-inflammatory medication: meloxicam (once daily)
* Advise patient to monitor for gastrointestinal symptoms; stop medication and contact if heartburn or stomach pain occurs
* Follow-up in two weeks to assess response; if inadequate improvement, consider intra-articular injections or surgical options such as joint debridement or fusion
* Educate patient about possible surgical procedures if needed in the future
* Encourage continuation of regular activities and use of orthotics to test treatment efficacy

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Difficulty breathing during sports, mood disturbances
* History of present illness: Experiences shortness of breath, chest tightness, wheezing, and cough during aerobic activity, especially in the presence of smoke; uses inhaler with symptom relief but side effects include shakiness; symptoms occur almost every time during aerobic workouts; reports feeling sad, tired, decreased motivation, and social withdrawal; recent increase in stress related to academic pressure
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Engages in water polo; no mention of smoking habits but observes symptoms around others who smoke
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Lungs clear to auscultation, no abnormal findings noted; eyes: slight fluid in ears; ears: some fluid, no other abnormalities; mouth/throat: normal, no tonsils; abdomen: normal on palpation; reflexes: normal
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results available

A (Assessment):

* Asthma, symptoms triggered by exercise and exposure to smoke, partial controlled with inhaler
* Allergic rhinitis, suspected due to fluid in ears and reaction to smoke
* Mood disturbance, likely related to stress and academic pressure

P (Plan):

* Initiate daily medication: Singulair (montelukast)
* Continue use of albuterol inhaler as needed post-symptom onset
* Education on inhaler side effects and sitting after inhaler use
* Follow-up in approximately six weeks to assess response to Singulair
* Recommend starting therapy with a counselor or therapist for mood issues, with screening questionnaires and follow-up in a few weeks

[doctor] that's
[patient] high school teams
[doctor] that's awesome so just out of curiosity with the left foot have you experienced anything like numbness or tingling or or any strange sensation
[patient] no i have not
[doctor] okay now if it's okay with you i would like to do a quick physical exam i reviewed your vitals and everything looks good blood pressure was one eighteen over seventy two heart rate was fifty eight respiratory rate was fourteen you are afebrile and you had an o2 saturation of ninety nine percent on room air on your heart exam your regular of rate and rhythm do n't appreciate any clicks rubs or murmurs no ectopic beats noted there on auscultation listening to your lungs lungs are clear and equal bilaterally so you're moving good air i'd like to do a focused foot exam on your left foot so i do see some bruising on the bottom of your foot and on the top of your foot as well now there is associated swelling and i do appreciate tenderness to palpation of your midfoot and you are positive for the piano key test on a neurovascular exam of your left foot you have a brisk capillary refill of less than three seconds dorsalis pedis pulse is intact and strong and you do have motor and sensation that it's intact to light touch now i would like to do a review of the diagnostic imaging that you had before you came in so i do notice a subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a three millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and the presence of a bony fragment in the lisfranc joint space so lem me talk to you a little bit about my assessment and plan now for for the first concern of right foot pain your right foot pain is due to a lisfranc fracture which is a fracture to one of your second metatarsal bones at the top of your foot where the metatarsals meet your cuboids now there are ligaments at the top of your foot so i'm gon na be ordering an mri to assess for injury to any of these ligaments now based on your exam and from what i'm seeing on your x-ray you're most likely going to need surgery of that foot now the surgery will place the bones back in their proper position and using plates and screws will hold them there while they heal and this is gon na allow those bones and ligaments to heal properly it is a day surgery and you will be able to go home the same day and then i'm going to have you follow up with me here in the clinic you'll be in a cast and you will need to use crutches and you will not be able to use that left foot for about six to eight weeks now after that six to eight weeks you will gradually start walking on your foot based on how you tolerate it and we'll see how you do at that point so i do believe you're gon na need surgery i i'm recommending this because there are significant complications to your foot if we do not do this poor bone and ligament healing can lead to losing the arch of your foot and you're becoming flat-footed you also have a high likelihood of developing arthritis in that foot so what i'm gon na do unfortunately you'll be out the rest of the season but we are gon na get you fixed up and ready for next season if you're okay with all of this i'm gon na have the nurse come in and get you started on your paperwork and then i will see you on monday morning and we will get your foot taken care of
[patient] alright thank you
[doctor] you're welcome
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Foot pain
* History of present illness: Pain after falling onto the left foot during playing soccer, pain worsens with activity, keeps foot elevated and iced, taking ibuprofen, pain level without medication 3, with medication 7-8, no numbness or tingling reported
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Long-term soccer player since age 4-5, played in local league and school teams
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 118/72 mmHg, heart rate 58/min, respiratory rate 14/min, afebrile, oxygen saturation 99% on room air
* Physical exam: Bruising on the bottom and top of the left foot, swelling, tenderness to palpation of midfoot, positive piano key test, neurovascular status intact (capillary refill <3 seconds, dorsalis pedis pulse strong and palpable, motor and sensation intact), lungs clear and equal bilaterally, regular rate and rhythm without murmurs or rubs
* Imaging review: Subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal, 3 mm separation of the first and second metatarsal bases, bony fragment in the Lisfranc joint space

A (Assessment):

* Lisfranc fracture of the left foot with dorsal displacement of the second metatarsal base, separation of metatarsal bases, and bony fragment in Lisfranc joint

P (Plan):

* Order MRI to assess for ligament injury
* Recommend surgery to realign bones and stabilize with plates and screws, performed as day surgery
* Postoperative instructions: cast application, crutches use, no weight-bearing on left foot for 6-8 weeks
* Follow-up in clinic for ongoing management and monitoring of healing
* Educate patient on potential complications including arch collapse and arthritis if untreated
* Continue rest and elevation, avoid weight bearing, and adhere to surgical plan

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left inside knee pain following injury playing basketball
* History of present illness: Fell to the ground during basketball game 7 days ago, injured on the inside of the knee, with swelling and effusion, tenderness on palpation of the medial aspect, pain increased with movement, no heard or felt pop, initially managed with ice and ACE wrap
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus, takes 500 mg metformin twice daily, checks blood glucose every morning
* Social history: Plays basketball recreationally, no additional social history provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Swelling and ecchymosis on the inside of the right knee, palpable fluid (effusion), tenderness on medial palpation, decreased range of motion, pain with flexion and extension, no pain on lateral pressure, negative varus and valgus stress tests
* Test results: X-ray shows good bony alignment, no fractures, small effusion present in the knee

A (Assessment):

* Right knee injury, likely medial collateral ligament strain
* Effusion with swelling, decreased range of motion
* No evidence of fracture on X-ray
* No suspicion of ligament tear based on physical exam, but follow-up needed

P (Plan):

* Continue use of ACE wrap and apply right knee brace for support
* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling
* Recommend light walking and continuation of exercises with brace
* Refer for physical therapy to strengthen knee muscles
* Advise to follow up in 7 days for reevaluation, possible further imaging (MRI or CT) if swelling worsens or symptoms persist
* Discontinue NSAIDs (Motrin/Advil) if previously taken
* Monitor blood sugars closely due to decreased activity
* Encourage patient to avoid playing basketball until follow-up and healing
* Reinforce the importance of ongoing diabetes management and follow-up with primary care physician
* No questions from patient

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Difficulty swallowing, chest pain when swallowing, occasional epigastric pain
* History of present illness: Has been experiencing difficulty swallowing certain foods and pain when swallowing down in the chest for several weeks; discomfort mainly with larger food pieces; occasional epigastric pain; has gained weight over the last month; diet has included pizza and burgers; stressful moving situation; no weight loss reported; no nausea, vomiting, diarrhea; no blood in stool or dark tarry stool
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Recently moved from West Coast to East Coast, experiencing stress related to the move; dietary stress from eating fast foods; considering driving long trip; no alcohol or caffeine intake noted here
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 133/70 mmHg, heart rate normal, oxygen sat 100%, respiratory rate 19, no fever
* Physical exam: Mouth no ulcers or thrush, tonsils midline, no neck adenopathy or thyromegaly; abdomen nondistended, active bowel sounds, tenderness to palpation in epigastric area; no Murphy's sign, peritoneal signs, rebound tenderness; lungs clear bilaterally, no rash, no lesions or bruising, eyes reactive to light

* Test results: Barium swallow showing two areas of mild narrowing in the mid and lower esophagus, consistent with esophagitis

A (Assessment):

* Acute esophagitis

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Protonix 40 mg once daily in the morning
* Prescribe Carafate 1 gram four times daily for one month
* Schedule upper endoscopy for further evaluation
* Advise dietary modifications: decrease alcohol and caffeine, avoid citrus, spicy foods, and fruits until symptoms improve
* Recommend eating slowly and thoroughly chewing food
* Emphasize importance of healthy eating post-move for better well-being
* Follow-up in one week for endoscopy
* Patient has no questions

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
* History of present illness: Difficulty sleeping for about two weeks, feeling like choking and unable to catch breath a few minutes after lying down, worse at night, no shortness of breath during exertion, weight gain of about ten pounds, ankle swelling, increased cough with some yuck in the morning
* Past medical history: Diabetes, back pain, CHF, COPD
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Neck swelling with mild JVD, lung crackles and rales in both bases, intermittent wheezing, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, abdomen slightly distended, bilateral 1.5+ pitting edema in ankles, no calf tenderness or Homan’s sign, neurologic exam normal, tenderness on paraspinal areas of lower back
* Test results: Pulse oximetry 92% in office, hemoglobin A1c 7.5%

A (Assessment):

* Congestive heart failure exacerbation
* Diabetes with suboptimal control
* Back pain due to muscular strain or musculoskeletal cause

P (Plan):

* Increase Lasix dose from 20 mg to 60 mg for 4 days; monitor weight daily
* Use inhalers: albuterol and atrovent; refill if needed
* Order repeat hemoglobin A1c
* Arrange follow-up in a few days after labs; reevaluate and adjust management accordingly
* Prescribe naprosyn and flexeril for back pain; recommend exercises; consider physical therapy if pain persists
* Educate patient about avoiding hospitalization if possible and to monitor symptoms closely

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Pain in the left ankle
* History of present illness: Fell off a curb while walking, land on the outside of the ankle, pain has persisted for a couple of days, pain level about 8/10 without medication, 7/10 with ibuprofen, pain described as stretching and tenderness without hearing a pop, able to walk after injury but painful, has tried elevating, icing, and taking ibuprofen
* Past medical history: No previous substantial injuries to the ankle
* Social history: Regular walking habit, has not yet visited local trails but plans to do so, activities limited due to ankle pain
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Stable, slightly elevated blood pressure (exact value not specified)
* Physical exam: Ecchymosis and swelling over lateral malleolus, tenderness on lateral palpation, soft tissue swelling, no joint laxity, no bony tenderness, neurovascular exam normal with brisk capillary refill less than 3 seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulses, motor and sensation intact, bilateral comparison normal
* Test results: X-ray review shows no fracture or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Left ankle sprain of the lateral ligament complex
* No fractures or bony abnormalities identified on X-ray

P (Plan):

* Continue RICE protocol (rest, ice, compression, elevation)
* Apply an air cast to stabilize the ankle
* Prescribe crutches to avoid weight bearing, continue weight-bearing as tolerated
* Continue NSAIDs for pain and swelling
* Follow-up in 2 weeks to reassess symptoms and recovery progress
* Encourage patient to visit local trails once healed
* Educate on symptom monitoring and when to return earlier if worsening pain or new symptoms develop

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right ankle pain after a fall
* History of present illness: Slipped on ice last night, heard a pop, constant throbbing pain rated 6/10, warm to touch, able to bear some weight but limping, pain unrelieved by ibuprofen, no numbness or tingling, no previous injury to this ankle
* Past medical history: No prior injury to this ankle, play soccer in high school
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, heart rate and SpO2 98%
* Physical exam: Ecchymosis and swelling on lateral malleolus, tenderness to palpation on anterior lateral soft tissue, no ligament laxity on anterior drawer and inversion stress tests, no bony tenderness, neurovascular exam: capillary refill <3 seconds, dorsalis pedis pulse strong, sensation intact
* Imaging: X-ray shows no fractures or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Right ankle sprain

P (Plan):

* Keep leg elevated when seated, continue icing five times daily for 20 minutes, provide an air cast for stabilization, prescribe crutches, advise staying off the leg for 1–2 days and walking as tolerated thereafter, expected healing time approximately 2–3 weeks, no doctor's note for work due to low activity requirement, advise follow-up if pain persists or worsens, consider MRI if significant symptoms continue.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Lower back pain
* History of present illness: Started four days ago after bending over while working in the yard, pain across lower back radiating down the left leg, no leg weakness or numbness, tingling in certain positions, no loss of bowel or bladder function, no previous back surgeries, occasional back pain in the past, tried ibuprofen with some relief
* Past medical history: Diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol
* Social history: Engaged in yard work despite reluctance, diet somewhat high in sweets, trying to improve diet
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/70 mmHg
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no bruits, lungs clear, no rales or wheezing, heart with systolic ejection murmur (2/6), abdomen soft, back tenderness on the left paraspinal area, straight leg raise negative, reflexes normal, lower extremity edema 1+ nonpitting in ankles, no calf tenderness, negative Homan’s sign, neurological exam normal
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided at this time

A (Assessment):

* Back pain, muscular sprain
* Diabetes, generally controlled (Hemoglobin A1c 7.1%)
* Hypertension, controlled (BP 120/70 mmHg), with leg edema possibly related to medication

P (Plan):

* Prescribe naprosyn 500 mg twice daily, flexeril 10 mg twice daily, and refer to physical therapy for lower back muscles
* No initial x-ray; start with conservative management; re-evaluate if no improvement
* Orders: Hemoglobin A1c, CBC, BMP, EKG, chest X-ray
* Discontinue norvasc 5 mg and start hydrochlorothiazide 10 mg once daily for leg edema
* Follow-up in two weeks to review lab results and assess back pain and edema
* No further refills needed; patient has a year’s worth previously

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain
* History of present illness: Traumatic injury two weeks ago while skiing, twisting the right knee after running into a tree on a black diamond slope, with increasing pain (scale 1-10, occasionally reaching 11), swelling, stiffness, and feeling of instability, worse with walking, especially longer walks
* Past medical history: Previous surgery on right knee (reconstructed at age 14 after feeling a pop during gymnastics)
* Social history: Skiing approximately three times a week, uses THC gummies from grandmother for pain
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Mild swelling, bruising, stability limited, tenderness on medial aspect of right knee, no pain on outside of knee, pain radiating to ankle with patellar movement, pain with dorsiflexion of ankle, no pain with plantar flexion, slight limp observed, knee flexion painful when pulled away from body, no fracture on x-ray, mild degenerative changes, presumed posterior cruciate ligament strain
* Test results: X-ray shows no fracture, signs of mild arthritis

A (Assessment):

* Right knee strain of posterior cruciate ligament, possible mild degenerative joint changes, postoperative status of right knee reconstruction (history of previous surgery)

P (Plan):

* Continue bracing right knee to reduce stress
* Refer for physical therapy, starting three times a week to rebuild strength
* Advise patient to avoid skiing and gymnastics for now
* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily to reduce swelling and inflammation
* Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily as needed for pain
* Counsel patient to listen to their body and ease activity levels
* Follow-up as needed with physical therapist or for reassessment

transcription:

[doctor] okay . all right . and do you have any history or any back problems before ?

[patient] yes .

[patient] no .

[patient] no .

[doctor] okay . and do you have any other , um , medical problems ?

[doctor] okay . and that's all ? okay . um , so what we're gon na do is i'm gon na give you , um , just continue the motrin at 800mg , three times a day , with food . i want you to use some ice and heat , alternating on your back . but i do want you walking .

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Back pain
* History of present illness: Onset after falling and bumping back into staircase railing during a surprise birthday party, twisting motion involved, more pain on the right side, worsened with twisting and when lying flat
* Past medical history: Lumbar fusion
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Tenderness when twisting the back, pain elicited on certain movements, no numbness or radiation to legs, normal sensation to touch, leg lifts do not cause pain or shooting down legs
* Imaging: X-ray shows previous fusion at T4, no abnormal findings, no compression fractures or significant abnormalities detected
* Additional findings: No evidence of radiculopathy or pinched nerve, stiffness with rotation noted

P (Plan):

[patient] . that's doing really well . i've been getting full range of motion and it's felt a lot better .

[doctor] squeeze my fingers for me . good . okay . is it painful if i move your patella like that ?

[patient] all right .
[doctor] your second problem is your chronic back pain , that's been doing really well . um , keep swimming , that's okay after this gets better .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] um , but i think , um , i think that's been under control . but if it flares up go ahead and , uh , give me a call , okay ?
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] um , your third problem is your depression . that's been stable . we're gon na keep you on your current medication , not gon na change anything at this point , okay ? and as far as your carpal tunnel goes , that's relatively stable , so , um , uh , no changes there as well . okay ? so anything else i can do for you ?

[patient] all right .
[doctor] hey dragon , finalize the report .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sudden onset right knee pain during swimming
* History of present illness: Experiencing increasing right knee pain while swimming breaststroke over the past month; pain starts after a few laps and has worsened from being able to swim 10 laps to experiencing discomfort earlier
* Past medical history: Carpal tunnel (history of release), chronic back pain, depression
* Social history: Recently increased swimming activity
* No reports of injury, fall, twist, or trauma
* No symptoms of leg pain radiating downward
* No concerns about self-harm or harming others

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: 
  - Right knee: Pain with range of motion, pain with patellar compression (patellar inhibition)
  - No swelling, no joint effusion observed
  - Patella tender to palpation
  - Patellar movement causes pain
  - Leg held out with resistance causes pain
  - Grip strength: Equal
  - Cardiovascular and respiratory exams: Heart regular, lungs clear
  - No lymphadenopathy
  - Thyroid: Normal
  - Neuro: No other abnormalities noted
* Imaging: X-ray of right knee shows normal findings, no abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Chondromalacia of the patella (suspected secondary to overuse from increased swimming activity)

P (Plan):

* Prescribe ibuprofen 600 mg four times daily with food
* Recommend straight leg raising exercises to strengthen quadriceps
* Advise avoiding lunge exercises and the breaststroke swimming stroke temporarily; consider other strokes with straight legs or rest
* Follow-up in a couple of weeks if symptoms persist
* Continue current management of chronic back pain, depression, and stable status of carpal tunnel
* No additional interventions at this time

[doctor] okay , and that's the 250/50 dose , correct ?
[patient] yes , correct .

[patient] mm-hmm .

[patient] yes .
[doctor] okay . so you can do things like go on a walk or going to the grocery store no problem , and just use it for more exertional stuff ?
[patient] yes . like , if i'm gon na go for a run or something like that i'll really just take it before as a preventative .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] and i've been trying to use my daily if i can a little less because i'm trying to go into the military soon .
[doctor] no kidding , that's great .
[patient] yeah , so i have to be able to operate basically at a certain fitness level without an inhaler .

[doctor] okay .

[patient] i do .
[doctor] great . and any urgent care or er visits at all for breathing over the past year ?
[patient] nope .

[patient] nope .
[doctor] okay . and now , military wise , what's the time frame of when you'll be completing some of these exertional tests ? like , what are your next steps ?
[patient] so , hopefully i'm going to be enlisted early spring of 2022 . so that gives me about six to seven months to get to a point where i'm able to exert my body where i do n't really need the inhaler . or at least show them that i have it under control .
[doctor] now when you were in the other room you completed a breathing test , correct ?
[patient] correct .
[doctor] okay , great . so now let me ask you about the allergies , 'cause i know typically you'll use the zyrtec in the spring , summer and fall , correct ?
[patient] yeah , i do n't really ... um , or i'm sorry , i use it more during the spring and fall . i do n't really have to use it too much in the summer .
[doctor] do you use it more just as needed in the summer ?
[patient] yeah , that's right .
[doctor] okay . and have you been taking the zyrtec every day recently since you're right in the mix of spring ?
[patient] not every day , but i do take it on days i know i'm going to be outside a lot . um , i do tend to work outside about three days a week so i'll definitely take it on those days .
[doctor] and does it seem to work pretty well still ? are you happy with it ?
[patient] yeah , it does , it works great .
[doctor] wonderful , good to hear . and then i'm assuming you're staying away from the peanuts . uh , last year you had told me it worked with ... uh , you worked with enterprise rent-a-car and one of the cars had a lot of peanuts in it that you were cleaning out and that gave you hives , uh , when you had touched it , is that correct ?
[patient] yep , that's correct .
[doctor] okay . and has there been anything like that since that experience ?
[patient] no , i do n't think so . i definitely became more cautious after that , so i usually wear , uh , wear long sleeves and change my gloves every time now . so i have n't had a reaction , but i imagine that i probably came into contact with cars that had peanuts in them , but they just d- did n't touch my skin .
[doctor] super . and it sounds like you're really smart about it .
[patient] yeah , and the airplanes , they have peanuts . they give everyone too , so .
[doctor] okay . and you have an epipen that k- that you keep with you , correct ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] okay . and i'm assuming you're going to need refills , um , i can call you in a new set for the year . typically of course , they expire within a year .

[doctor] okay .
[patient] and i remember having them and nothing happened , but i usually just tend to stay away from them , um , really if i can help it .
[doctor] okay . so sometimes when people have a peanut allergy , the nuts in general just are n't very important to them , so it is very common to avoid both . um , so let's do this . i'll have helen come in and i would love to complete a breathing test on you . if your breathing numbers are looking great we can work on getting you , uh , something lower than wixela . if you look at all of our asthma regimens it is a stepwise process , and wixela is a combination of two medications in one . and , well maybe you do n't need both of'em . uh , maybe you just need one of'em . so we can work our way backwards .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and so the breathing test will help give us some- some more guidance , we will look at the results in just a moment .
[patient] all right , and so this past year i did get into the bad habit of vaping and smoking , but i have been trying to cut that out . so i should be good , and , um , now i only do just a little bit and i am trying to quit . so i am sure that might have an effect .
[doctor] it can . um , so what we can do today is compare your results with prior results , probably before you started smoking or using the vape .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] yeah . and we'll see where you stand at that point .
[patient] all right , that sounds good .
[doctor] well let me go ahead and listen , so hop on up here for me .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right so your ears look good , a little bit of wax on both sides . can i see inside your mouth ? big ahh .
[patient] ahh .
[doctor] good . okay let me take a peek in your nose . all right , good . you can put your mask back on .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and go ahead take a big breath in and out . good , your lungs sound terrific . i'll listen to your heart , breathe quietly . okay very good .
[patient] awesome .
[doctor] so your breathing test is about the same as it was a couple years ago , and actually looks a little bit better . you may not remember but when we last completed the test in 2019 , uh , do you recall if you were feeling lousy at the time ?
[patient] i think it was the smoke . there were so many fires at that point and i remember coming in and looking out the window and all you saw was the orange and the smoke .
[doctor] yes , you're absolutely right , that was a bad year . that was my first fall here and i was really alarmed . well that explains why at that time your numbers were a little bit lower and today they look better . here's what i think , so you'll have kaiser currently , correct ?
[patient] correct .
[doctor] okay . most insurances do limit what we can use .
[patient] yeah i do know that .
[doctor] okay so option one would be to continue using wixela like you're using it now . we would classify it as off-label and you can use it once a day instead of twice a day , which is fine . some people do that because they just need it once a day , so that's an option . option two would be to actually back up to an inhaler that just has one med .
[patient] mm-hmm
[doctor] so the one that kaiser covers is alvesco . the thing about alvesco , though , is that it would be two puffs in the morning and two puffs at night . so it's a bit more work . um , it's not breath activated but we could step down the lowest dose to see how you do . some of the newer guidelines for asthma that were published this year is recommending trying to treat people with inhalers like wixela or alvesco only when you're ill , or say during smoke season . so minimizing their use to those periods of time versus all year . unless you found out that you're getting
[ inaudible 00:09:25 ] sick having issues every month , then that would indicate would pull back too much .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] that we had too much , yeah .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] um , so we could step back and possibly get you to the point where you just use those inhalers , uh , when you're ill or it's smoke season , but at the first step to do any of that would be to try to drop down to just alvesco .
[patient] okay , that actually sounds really good .
[doctor] okay great . so i will call that in for you , it will be the lower dose , 80 mcg , and you'll have to do two puffs twice a day .
[patient] all right
[doctor] okay and that'll be on the box when i call it in . you can put the wixela off to the side , but do n't throw it away just in case the alvesco does n't work well for you .

[doctor] is your pharmacy still the same or did you update it with helen ?
[patient] yeah i believe she updated it . it should be kaiser permanente broadway .
[doctor] okay perfect . i'll make sure it's the alvesco and then i'll renew your albuterol and epipen as well .

[doctor] you're welcome . uh , then the zyrtec , do you pick it up over the counter or do get- do you get it as a prescription ?

[doctor] and do the alvesco two puffs twice a day and your albuterol if you need it . the zyrtec 10 milligrams as you need it and continue to stay away from peanuts and tree nuts and i'll refill your epipen .

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: No specific current complaints; routine follow-up for asthma, allergic rhinitis, and food allergy
* History of present illness: Asthma managed with Wixela 250/50 (once in the morning and once at night), rarely uses albuterol for exertional symptoms, taking it 3-4 days per week, uses Zyrtec seasonally, primarily in spring and fall, avoids peanuts, and tolerates almonds and cashews
* Past medical history: Asthma, allergic rhinitis, food allergy (peanut allergy, tolerant to almonds and cashews)
* Social history: Recently used vaping and smoking but has been reducing
* Family history: No information provided
* Interval history: Written consent obtained today to use Dax for documentation

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Ears with a little wax, clear oral and nasal exam, lungs sound excellent, no abnormal findings on auscultation, no distress observed
* Test results: Spirometry performed today; results about same as or slightly better than previous in 2019; ACT score is 21

A (Assessment):

* Asthma, well-controlled on Wixela
* Allergic rhinitis, seasonal, controlled with Zyrtec
* Food allergy: Peanut allergy, tolerated almonds and cashews
* No active contraindications or urgent issues identified

P (Plan):
