SOAP:
S (Subjective):  
- Chief complaint: Chest pain, occurring with walking, described as dull pressure, lasting approximately three months  
- History of present illness: Chest pain triggered by walking, not present at the moment, no radiation, no associated symptoms such as shortness of breath, sweating, or clamminess  
- Past medical history: Diabetes, high blood pressure (not formally diagnosed yet)  
- Social history: Exercise attempt, diet includes sodas  
- No reports of nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or medication side effects

O (Objective):  
- Vital signs: No information provided  
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distension, no neck swelling, no carotid bruits, clear lung sounds, systolic ejection murmur (2/6), regular heart rate and rhythm, equal pulses, soft abdomen, no tenderness, guarding, or masses, mild bilateral lower extremity swelling (+1 nonpitting edema), no calf tenderness

- EKG: Normal, no signs of heart attack observed

A (Assessment):  
- Chest pain: Suspected unstable angina considering history of diabetes, potential high blood pressure, and family history of heart disease  
- Diabetes: Well-controlled with current metformin dose, HbA1c last checked at 7, no recent eye exam before current appointment  
- High blood pressure: Not diagnosed definitively; trend of elevated readings noted, potential contributing factor to chest pain

P (Plan):  
- Refer to cardiology for further assessment, including stress test  
- Prescribe aspirin (81 mg daily) and nitroglycerin (as needed for chest pain, up to three pills every five minutes, with instructions to go to hospital if pain persists)  
- Continue metformin 500 mg twice daily, recheck HbA1c in two weeks  
- Maintain diabetic eye exam, appointment scheduled in two weeks  
- Initiate hydrochlorothiazide for blood pressure and edema, monitor blood pressure at home with logs, follow-up in two weeks for medication adjustment if needed  
- Educate patient on medication side effects and importance of monitoring  
- Advise to seek immediate care if chest pain does not resolve within five minutes after taking up to three nitroglycerin doses

SOAP:
S (Subjective):  
- Chief complaint: Knee pain lasting about six months  
- History of present illness: Deep achy pain behind kneecaps, sometimes with creaking sounds, worsened when getting up from seated position, after watching TV, and going up/down stairs; relieved with rest  
- No history of swelling, redness, or injury; no previous knee injuries, but history of arm fracture in sixth grade  
- Activity level: Previously ran 5-6 miles daily outdoors; now unable to run even half a mile due to knee pain  
- No other relevant medical history or recent trauma reported

O (Objective):  
- Vital signs: No information provided  
- Physical exam: Normal gait, tenderness on palpation of bilateral retinacula, positive patellar grind test, ability to squat painful, no erythema, ecchymosis, warmth, or effusion; strength 3/5 for bilateral leg abduction, other lower extremity muscles 5/5; neuro exam normal with symmetrical patella and Achilles reflexes  
- Imaging: X-rays of knees show no fractures or osteoarthritis

A (Assessment):  
- Patellofemoral pain syndrome

P (Plan):  
- Continue use of ibuprofen or anti-inflammatory medications as needed  
- Refer for physical therapy focusing on lower extremity exercises to improve strength, mobility, and correct running mechanics  
- Advise to avoid running temporarily and gradually return based on progress  
- Follow-up to assess progress and adjust treatment accordingly

SOAP:
S (Subjective):  
* Chief complaint: Low back pain  
* History of present illness: Started a couple of weeks ago after lifting a box of books, described as achy and sharp, with radiation down the left leg, worsening over time  
* Aggravating factors: Bending forward causes pain  
* Alleviating factors: Taking ibuprofen and Tylenol sometimes helps  
* No numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation reported  
* No weakness, bladder or bowel control issues reported  
* Activity level: Inconsistent exercise, sedentary job, feels less active due to pain  
* Family history: Father has back pain  
* Social history: Does not smoke, played soccer as a midfielder, supports Tottenham Hotspur team  
* No previous discussions of surgery; first consideration of surgical options  
* No significant impact on work, but decreased activity level suggested  
* No symptoms of redness, bruising, or overlying skin abnormalities on back exam  

O (Objective):  
* Vital signs: Blood pressure 130/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min  
* Physical exam: Heart rate and rhythm normal, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops; lungs clear bilaterally; back exam shows midline tenderness at L4-L5 disc space, right paravertebral tenderness; no overlying skin abnormalities; able to bend forward and backward with pain on forward flexion  
* Neurological exam: Supine straight leg test positive for radicular pain down the left leg; sensation, patellar, and Achilles reflexes normal and symmetrical; no weakness or sensory deficits  

A (Assessment):  
* Lumbar back pain at L4-L5 disk space  
* Disk herniation with radiculopathy (nerve impingement) as evidenced by MRI findings and radiating pain  

P (Plan):  
* Recommend lumbar epidural corticosteroid injection under fluoroscopy and NSAID management to reduce inflammation and pain  
* Educate patient about risks and obtain consent after providing informational paperwork  
* Schedule procedure for the same day if patient agrees  
* Advise patient to monitor for any worsening symptoms or adverse effects  
* Follow-up as needed to assess response to treatment

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left knee pain
* History of present illness: Knee pain started about a week ago after falling while running with niece, with twisting injury, hearing a pop, pain on both sides of the knee, more on the inside, described as throbbing and starting as 4/10 pain that has worsened
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Tenderness on the inside of the knee, edema, effusion, moderate range of motion, pain on flexion and extension, negative Lachman’s test, negative valgus and varus tests
* Test results: Knee X-ray normal, no fractures or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Left knee pain, likely from medial collateral ligament strain (MCL)

P (Plan):

* Advise ice application 3-4 times daily for 20-30 minutes to reduce swelling
* Recommend avoiding running or strenuous activity for approximately three weeks
* Follow-up in about one month; advise to contact office if symptoms worsen or if additional imaging (MRI) is needed to evaluate for more serious injuries

* Hyperlipidemia, well-controlled
* Coronary artery disease, under control

P (Plan):

* COVID-19: Quarantine for 10 days, avoid household contact, supportive care, monitor symptoms, call if condition worsens
* Hyperlipidemia: Continue crestor 20 mg daily, maintain diet, repeat lipid panel in 6 months
* Cardiovascular health: No chest pain, exercising, plan for stress test in 6 months
* No additional medications prescribed at this time
* Follow-up as needed

[doctor] okay . who do you go see ?
[patient] i go to liberty road , the group up there .
[doctor] okay . the , um , the optimum optometrists , right ?
[patient] they keep changing doctors each time i go .
[doctor] a new doc each time ?
[patient] yeah . i got a really nice one i used to see a year ago .
[doctor] was that dr. sanchez ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] okay . and you saw him not too long ago ?
[patient] yeah . i just got my prescription from him . well , see , i had the iodine for my eyes .
[doctor] cataracts , yep , okay .
[patient] so he did that and then i had to wait for a month to get healed up and then he wrote my prescription .
[doctor] perfect . and then you've got the high blood pressure .
[patient] yeah . a couple of weeks ago , it was 116 on the dot .
[doctor] okay . well , we will recheck it . you're on a combination of medications . you are on the met- met- uh , metoprolol , 50 milligrams once a day , you're on the lisinopril with hydrochlorothiazide , at 20 , with 25 milligrams once a day , and you're on the amlodipine , 10 milligram once a day . are you taking all of those ?
[patient] well , yeah .
[doctor] perfect . and then you've got the high cholesterol and the vascular disease in your legs . you're on atorvastatin . are you tolerating it okay ?
[patient] yeah , but honestly , my feet feel like hell .
[doctor] yeah .
[patient] all the time , my legs are bugging me ; i ca n't do much walking .
[doctor] okay . yeah , the feet i think is what we call peripheral neuropathy .
[patient] also , i have the pain up to my hip .
[doctor] okay . you have pain in the hips and upper legs ?
[patient] yeah , all of it .
[doctor] okay . so those do seem relatively stable , right ? and are you trying to get the walking in ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] okay . and you are smoking still ?
[patient] yeah , still smoking .
[doctor] not ready to quit ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] it's a bad combination .
[patient] i know . i'll think about it .
[doctor] okay . now , let's do my review of systems . you're not having any headaches or dizziness ?
[patient] headaches or dizziness , no .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] nothing , feeling totally normal .
[doctor] good , good . and the vision is better with the cataract surgery ? that's been good ?
[patient] yeah . not happy with this lens ; it's kinda funny . the other one is good .
[doctor] hmm , sometimes they can go in and clean up the eye with laser , but we'll see what they say .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . no shortness of breath or coughing ?
[patient] i've been coughing here lately because i've been congested .
[doctor] what does it look like when it comes up ?
[patient] it's relatively clear .
[doctor] no fever , chills , no shortness of breath ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . no chest pains or pressure or tightness ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] nausea , vomiting , gi symptoms ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . peeing okay ?
[patient] not good . it's , you know , i'm old ; it takes me a little more time .
[doctor] slower stream but stable ?
[patient] yes , but i do pee ...
[doctor] okay .
[patient] . several times per day .
[doctor] mm-hmm . how many times do you have to get up at night ?
[patient] not too bad , just once in a while .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] then i have to pee by morning . i do tend to drink my drinks in the evening .
[doctor] okay . all right , let's have a look at you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] physical exam : carotids are normal , pulse is no buits . heart exam : rhythm is regular , normal rate , s1 and s2 are crisp . i do not hear any murmurs today , okay . have you lean forward for me . take some deep breaths , in and out . okay , lungs are clear . i do n't hear any rasps or wheezing today .
[patient] my coughing got better this morning .
[doctor] you cleared out the lungs ? all right , let me take a look at your feet .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . extremities are without edema . pulses are palpable on the dorsalis pedis posterial tibial . she has thickened nails .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] yeah . mildly dry skin , no skin breakdown . l- let me know if you can feel this .
[patient] okay . i closed my eyes . yeah , yeah , okay .
[doctor] mildly decreased sensation in the tips of the first and second toes . okay , we're done with your exam .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . so again , try to keep the feet moisturized .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] you do have a little bit of periphe- peripheral neuropathy . um , there is a medication we can use if they get really bad , but you're already on so many medications .
[patient] my girl that i talk to and stuff , she uses on her feet ; she really likes it . it's , like , a foot scrub or some type of cream . i put it on when i think of it after the shower . so i could get my own instead .
[doctor] that sounds good . so for now , your sugars , we're gon na check your ... we're going to recheck your blood work today , but the sugars last time we checked , the a1c , your blood sugar average was above nine . i really want you to increase the glimepiride . so the ones you have at home , the two milligram , take two of them twice a day .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . watch for low sugars , weak , shaky , sweaty . if that happens , let us know , and i do n't expect it to .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . the new prescription that i'm going to write is gon na be for the , uh , four milligram pill . so when you get the new one , just one pill twice a day . also , continue the metformin , okay ? blood pressure , when i rechecked it , i got 140 over 60 s- so the numbers at home are better , so we're gon na continue the combination of medications . we'll check kidney function today .
[doctor] for your cholesterol though , you're on the high dose of atorvastatin or lipitor to protect the arteries , so we really wan na keep you on that .
[patient] yeah , no problem .
[doctor] i want you to quit smoking , but we've had this battle before .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] hmm . and then , we will leave everything else the same . we'll get the labs today and we'll see you back here in four months . sound good ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] great . have a good day , ma'am . take care of yourself .
[patient] thank you . you too .
[doctor] bye .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up visit for diabetes, hypertension, high cholesterol, peripheral neuropathy
* History of present illness: Patient reports no recent changes; does not feel well-controlled blood sugars (A1c previously 9.9), occasional cough due to congestion, sensation of foot numbness and leg pain, infrequent urination, and smoking habit. She has no headaches, dizziness, chest pains, shortness of breath, or nausea.
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, cataracts with recent eye exam, peripheral neuropathy
* Social history: Smokes cigarettes, drinks only club soda and seltzer water, limited carbohydrate intake, no regular alcohol consumption
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 116 mmHg (recorded previously)
* Physical exam: Carotids normal, pulses palpable, heart with regular rhythm, no murmurs, lungs clear, extremities without edema, thickened nails, mild dry skin, decreased sensation in toes, no skin breakdown
* Test results: Blood glucose and A1c not current; recent blood pressure 116/— mmHg; lab recheck pending

A (Assessment):

* Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (A1c previous 9.9, increased glimepiride planned)
* Hypertension, controlled with current medications
* Hyperlipidemia, stable on atorvastatin
* Peripheral neuropathy, mild
* Cataracts, post-surgery
* No other diagnoses explicitly stated; patient smoking noted

P (Plan):

* Increase glimepiride to 4 mg twice daily, monitor for hypoglycemia
* Continue metformin
* Recheck blood work and A1c at next visit
* Continue current antihypertensive medications: metoprolol 50 mg daily, lisinopril with hydrochlorothiazide 20/25 mg daily, amlodipine 10 mg daily
* Monitor blood pressure; recheck at follow-up
* Continue atorvastatin
* Advise to quit smoking
* Suggest moisturizing the feet and consider topical treatments for peripheral neuropathy if symptoms worsen
* Schedule follow-up in 4 months

transcription:
[doctor] patient mrn : abc123 . date of birth : january 1st , 1960 . patient is a 60 year old , right-handed male , referred today for evaluation of numbness and tingling .
[doctor] hello , mr. cook . how are you doing this morning ?
[patient] hi , dr. martinez . this weekend was a bit rough . i've had this numbness and tingling for a few weeks now .
[doctor] so it's in both of your hands ?
[patient] yes , ever since my car wreck last december when i broke them ... well , once they healed , i mean , i noticed it more , the tingling and the numbness .
[doctor] and you still wear the splint only on the right wrist ?
[patient] no , i also wear the left sometimes . the right is just worse , but the splint helps . both have really gotten worse over the last month . when i broke them , my right wrist was definitely in worse shape . i've also been having some s- mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident , and they told me it was a contusion .
[doctor] and where would you say the tingling and numbness is ?
[patient] on this side , it goes from here and here up to about here . on the other side , it's from here to here .
[doctor] i see . so on the right side , you're pointing from the middle and ring finger , all the way up the forearm . and on the left , the symptoms extend from the pinky and ring finger . and is there any pain or just tingling and numbness ?
[patient] eh , it's mainly just sore . sometimes they throb , but overall , they feel weaker too , especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens more when they hurt , but when it goes away , the tingling is dull .
[doctor] and when do you feel these symptoms ?
[patient] well , really , i guess , just more so at night , and they come and go throughout the day .
[doctor] okay . and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ?
[patient] like , feeling something ? no , not that i can really think of . though , in general , they may be less sensitive than they should be , but i can still feel . they also gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should .
[doctor] and are you still on the coreg for hypertension and the lexapro for anxiety ?
[patient] yes , i'm still taking those . i had prediabetes too , but i got it under control by changing my diet .
[doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , correct ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] all right , thank you , mr. cook . okay , first , we'll go over your review of systems . correct me if i'm wrong in any of this .
[doctor] constitutional , you have fatigue and weight gain ; gi , you have excessive appetite and bloating ; eyes have floaters ; cardiovascular shows shortness of breath and leg swelling ; endocrine , you're always hungry ; skin , you have some nail bed changes , dryness , itching ; musculoskeletal , you have gout and muscle pain . and the remainder of the review of systems is negative .
[patient] yep , that's all correct .
[doctor] all right , we're going to go ahead and do the neurologic examination . let's look at the right hand first . can you feel this ?
[patient] yeah , but a little less on these two fingers .
[doctor] sensation is normal , except pin prick sensation diminished in third and fourth fingers on the right .
[doctor] and how about on the left ?
[patient] um , yeah , but these two a little less .
[doctor] sensation is decreased in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left
[doctor] okay , let's test your reflexes now . reflexes are 1+ and symmetric ; 2+ knees ; toes are downgoing bilaterally .
[doctor] all right , i'm going to tap on your right wrist . do you feel anything ?
[patient] yeah , it feels like a zing up my wrist and something into my elbow too .
[doctor] and how about the left side ?
[patient] yeah , same on that side too .
[doctor] tinel sign positive at both wrists and both elbows . rest of exam is normal .
[doctor] all right , so what i am seeing today is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome or , potentially , this could also be bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . however , your symptom presentation suggests car- bilateral carpal syndrome , as the nerve in your wrists are aggravated by your past trauma . this is causing the pain and tingling you were describing to me .
[patient] okay , so how do we make it better ?
[doctor] first , i want to determine exactly where the nerve irritation is coming from . we'll need to schedule you for a nerve test , which is called an emg test . they will measure the responsiveness of your nerves to truly pinpoint where you are having your issues .
[patient] that sounds fine to me .
[doctor] great . after the tests are complete , you can return here for a follow-up visit . if you're still having symptoms , we can consider a referral to our hand clinic , possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release se- surgery . you could also refer ... we could also refer you to an orthopedist for the same treatment .
[patient] sounds good , doc .
[doctor] all right , keep wearing your splints , and i will see you after those studies .
[patient] thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in both hands for a few weeks; worsened over the last month
* History of present illness: Numbness and tingling started after healing from wrist fractures sustained in a car wreck last December; symptoms extend from the middle and ring fingers on the right and from the pinky and ring fingers on the left; symptoms are worse at night and fluctuate during the day; sensations include soreness, occasional throbbing, muscle weakness, and dull tingling; worse on the right side; patient reports wearing splints on both wrists for support; some mild neck stiffness; symptoms are relieved somewhat by splints
* Past medical history: Prediabetes controlled by diet, hypertension (on coreg), anxiety (on lexapro)
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Sensory testing revealed decreased pinprick sensation in the third and fourth fingers on the right, and in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left; reflexes 1+ and symmetric; knee reflexes 2+; toes downgoing bilaterally; Tinel sign positive at both wrists and both elbows; rest of exam normal
* Additional findings: No visual findings related to floaters; no other physical exam findings noted

A (Assessment):

* Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
* Potential bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Schedule nerve conduction study (EMG) to localize nerve irritation
* Follow-up after testing to assess symptoms
* Consider referral to hand clinic for injections or surgical release if symptoms persist
* Possible referral to orthopedist for further management
* Continue wearing wrist splints

transcription:
[doctor] patient shirley taylor . date of birth 5/4/1961 . mrn 0000123 . patient is a 60 year old right-handed female new patient referred by dr. jacob ward for evaluation of bilateral hand numbness and tingling . please note that i personally reviewed the ct brain with and without contrasting did 2/5/21 . uh , no metastatic disease . no acute intercranial abnormalities .
[doctor] hello ms. taylor . how are you doing this morning ?
[patient] hi dr . lopez . this weekend was a bit rough . i've had this numbness and tingling for a few weeks now .
[doctor] so , in both of your hands ?
[patient] yeah . ever since my car wreck last december when i broke them . well , once they heal , i mean , i noticed it more , the , the tingling and numbness .
[doctor] are you still wearing the splint only on your right wrist ?
[patient] no . i wear the left one also sometimes . the right one's just worse . the splint seems to help . both have gotten worse over the last month . when i broke them though , my wrist was definitely in worse shape than it is today . i've been having some mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident , and they told me it was a contusion .
[doctor] okay . and where exactly on the right side would you say the tingling and numbness is ?
[patient] on the right , i can really notice it from my middle and ring finger all the way up to my forearm , and on my left , a bit more the pinky and the ring and not the middle .
[doctor] all right . and , um , is there is pain or , or just tingling and numbness ?
[patient] uh , mainly just sore . sometimes they throb , but overall , they feel weaker too , especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens some more , but when they hurt , you know , it goes away and then the tingling's just dull .
[doctor] what kind of activities ?
[patient] well , really , i guess , just more so at night , and then it just kind of comes and goes throughout the day .
[doctor] okay . and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ?
[patient] uh , like , like feeling something ? no , not that i can think of really . in general , they might be less sensitive than they should be , but i can still feel . they gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should be .
[doctor] okay . looks like your medical history is notable for chronic kidney disease , gout , hypertension , anxiety , gerd , and diabetes .
[patient] well , i had pre-diabetes , but i got in under control changing my diet .
[doctor] okay . good . and are you still on the carvedilol 25 milligrams two times a day for hypertension and lexapro 10 milligrams a day for anxiety ? looks like your allergic to sulfa drugs as well . is that correct ?
[patient] yeah , i'm still taking those and sulfa just causes me to break out in a rash .
[doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , right ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] all right . thank you ms. taylor . i'll be right back for your exam . i want to look up that medication you mentioned for your nerve pain .
[patient] all right . thanks .
[doctor] review of systems , please make the following changes . uh , constitutional , patient reports fatigue and weight gain . gi , um , excessive appetite and bloating . eyes , floaters . uh , cardiovascular , shortness of breath and leg swelling . endocrine , positive diabetes , always hungry . skin , nail bed trenches , dryness , itching . musculoskeletal , gout , muscle pain . neurological , parasthesia , bilateral hands .
[doctor] um , please use the default normal neuro-physical exam with the following changes . sensations normal except pin prick sensation diminished in the third and forth fingers on the right . and the fourth and fifth fingers on the left . reflexes are one plus and symmetric , two plus knees , toes are down going bilaterally , tinel's sign positive at both wrists and both elbows .
[doctor] let's move onto assessment and plan , bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome , question of bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . i discussed my impression with the patient , i will schedule her for emg , ncv . if her symptoms do not resolve , we can consider hand clinic referral for possible symptomatic injections or carpal tunnel release surgery although she can pursue these uh , through her current orthopedist . i encouraged her to wear her splints , returned for emg , ncv . end of note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Bilateral hand numbness and tingling
* History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in both hands for a few weeks, worse over the last month, occurring primarily at night and intermittently throughout the day; sensation described as soreness and dull tingling, with weakness especially when using hands; tingling from the middle and ring fingers to the forearm on the right, and ring and pinky fingers on the left; no loss of sensation but decreased sensitivity; symptoms began after hand fractures from a car wreck last December; mild neck stiffness, history of head contusion from the accident; no mention of other neurological deficits
* Past medical history: Chronic kidney disease, gout, hypertension, anxiety, GERD, pre-diabetes (controlled by diet)
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Sensation normal except pinprick sensation diminished in the third and fourth fingers on the right, and fourth and fifth fingers on the left; reflexes one plus and symmetric, knees and toes downward linear reflexes bilaterally; Tinel's sign positive at both wrists and elbows
* Test results: CT brain with and without contrast (2/5/21) showed no metastatic disease or acute intracranial abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
* Question of bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Schedule electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction velocity (NCV) testing
* If symptoms do not resolve, consider referral to hand clinic for possible symptomatic injections or carpal tunnel release surgery, which she can pursue through her current orthopedist
* Continue wearing splints
* Follow-up after EMG and NCV testing

transcription:
[doctor] michelle king , date of birth 01/05/1986 , mrnq27631 . new patient visit for acid reflux . past medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies .
[doctor] hello , are you mrs. king ?
[patient] i am .
[doctor] i'm dr. phillips . very nice to meet you .
[patient] you as well .
[doctor] how can i help you today ?
[patient] well , my primary doctor , dr. scott , he referred me here .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i've just got really bad acid reflux .
[doctor] okay . can you tell me more about it ?
[patient] yeah . though i mean i ... right now , i take 40 milligrams of omeprazole twice a day . some days , it is fine , but others are just really bad .
[doctor] what do you feel ?
[patient] it feels like burning .
[doctor] in your chest ?
[patient] yes , in my chest and also in my throat .
[doctor] in your throat and chest . all right . any difficulty with swallowing ? feels like food or liquids kinda get stuck ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . that's good . any abdominal pain ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] nausea or vomiting , changes in bowel movements ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] constipation , diarrhea , rectal bleeding ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] okay . very good . and how long have you had this problem ?
[patient] i've had acid reflux since i was around 12 , but it has gotten worse over the past few years .
[doctor] okay . and how long have you been on the omeprazole ?
[patient] on the way , it is now i think about a year .
[doctor] okay . do you find that it's done anything for you in the past ?
[patient] i mean , i can tell it's helped because some days , i'll be fine , and then some days , i eat something and it feels terrible .
[doctor] are there any things that make your symptoms worse that you can pinpoint , like food choices or stress ?
[patient] sure . probably stress and food choices sometimes .
[doctor] okay . what things bother you ?
[patient] spicy foods , um , so i try not to eat them too often , but sometimes even drinking a soda can cause it .
[doctor] we do know that caffeine and caffeinated beverages will do that , even sodas . um , even just the carbonation can cause that . how about tomato-based products or citrus products ?
[patient] yeah , sometimes , but i still eat them .
[doctor] okay . it's reassuring that you are n't having any difficulty swallowing , though . how's your weight been ? pretty stable ?
[patient] i'd say pretty stable , although i have n't had much of an appetite for the past two months . i have been under a lot of work stress .
[doctor] what do you do for work ?
[patient] i'm a paralegal .
[doctor] okay . and any family history of gi issues ?
[patient] um , my grandmother had esophageal cancer .
[doctor] on your mom or dad's side ?
[patient] mom's side . and my mom had some issues like acid reflux , and she was taking some medication that coats the lining of your stomach .
[doctor] okay . have you ever had an upper endoscopy ?
[patient] i think maybe when i was younger .
[doctor] but not in the last 10 years ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] have you ever tried any medication other than omeprazole ?
[patient] um , at one point i was on omeprazole and ranititine -dine . it did help . but other than that , those are the only medications i have taken .
[doctor] okay . have a seat here , and let me listen to your heart and lungs , and then we can talk about a plan for you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so normal physical exam per my new patient template , except for well-healed abdominal surgical scars noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ?
[patient] i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around one month old .
[doctor] hm , gotcha . okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several-year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole , 40 milligrams twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated bev- beverages , citrus , and tomato-based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd , even though you're taking the ppi .
[patient] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods .
[doctor] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms .
[patient] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me .
[doctor] so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally , we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium .
[patient] that's fine with me . i'm definitely open to trying whatever .
[doctor] perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 milligrams twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i'll also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd , or upper endoscopy , to look for potential causes of the gerd . we'd sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth , down your throat , through your stomach , and end in the small intestines . we'd look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything .
[patient] okay . can i schedule that today ?
[doctor] yeah . you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary , stress , and medication changes . how does all of that sound ?
[patient] that sounds good .
[doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the checkout desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment .
[doctor] please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms pers- persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph-impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Severe acid reflux
* History of present illness: Patient reports burning sensation in chest and throat, worsened over past few years, despite taking 40 mg omeprazole twice daily for about a year; symptoms fluctuate with certain foods and stress; no difficulty swallowing, nausea, vomiting, or bowel changes; past acid reflux since age 12, worsening recently; identifies trigger foods such as spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, tomato-based products; experiences increased symptoms with stress and work-related anxiety; weight stable but decreased appetite over past two months.
* Past medical history: Anxiety, seasonal allergies
* Family history: Grandmother with esophageal cancer; mother with history of acid reflux and medication use
* Social history: Paralegal, high work stress
* No information provided about smoking, alcohol, or other substance use.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Normal physical exam except well-healed abdominal surgical scars; surgical history from infancy due to intestinal twist
* No abnormal findings noted on physical exam

A (Assessment):

* Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), chronic, poorly controlled with current medication
* Possible underlying functional etiology of GERD
* No evidence of dysphagia or weight loss; family history of esophageal cancer considered in risk assessment

P (Plan):

* Dietary modifications: Avoid spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, and tomato-based foods
* Stress reduction strategies to address triggers
* Medication change: Switch from omeprazole to nexium 40 mg twice daily
* Procedure: Schedule upper endoscopy (EGD) to evaluate for potential ulcers, precancerous or cancerous conditions, and obtain biopsies if indicated
* Follow-up: Return for office follow-up after EGD to discuss results and ongoing symptom management
* Additional considerations: If symptoms persist despite trial of nexium and EGD is normal, consider trial of proton pump inhibitor Protonix and perform pH-impedance study to distinguish functional etiology and hypersensitivity

transcription:
[doctor] . next patient is michelle king . date of birth : 05/07/1982 . please use toc template . she was admitted to district regional hospital on 06/29/2021 , and was discharged on 07/02/2021 . the patient is a 39-year-old female with history of quadriplegia due to , uh , prior spinal cord injury . she was experiencing increasing concerns for spasms and lightheadedness , significant constipation , and reported diaphoresis . she was evaluated in the emergency department where she was , uh , febrile and had significantly elevated white blood cell count of 23,000 . there were concerns for ongoing urinary tract infection , but she was treated with iv antibiotic therapy . she had labile blood pressure , headache , and vomiting . in the end , she slowly improved . she does have a supra-pubic catheter . cultures were obtained and reviewed . she was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms . she presents today to follow up regarding these concerns . hi , michelle . how are you doing ?
[patient] not too bad . and yourself ?
[doctor] i'm good , thanks . so , it looks like you had an infection , right ?
[patient] yeah . but you know , i really do n't think it was a uti .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i told them when i went to the er ... is that your phone ?
[doctor] it is , yeah . it listens to you and me and it does all of my documentation . it's pretty good stuff . um , tell me what's going on .
[patient] it is , in my humble opinion , that i was just constipated and that was what was causing my blood pressure to be so high . and i hardly pooped when i was there . then when i got home i had a massive poop and i felt much better . i told them that when i was admitted , and they did x-rays and everything , but they said , " no , " as they did n't think that was n't ... that was it . but you know , i felt so much better when i got home and finally pooped .
[doctor] okay . um , and the white cell count was the only thing that i think they were kind of concerned about because it was a little high .
[patient] so i wondered if automatic dysreflexia can affect the white count ?

* Past medical history: Quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury, supra-pubic catheter, constipation, previous elevated white blood cell count
* Social history: Hesitant about COVID-19 vaccination; believes her hospitalization was related to dysreflexia caused by constipation
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

A (Assessment):

* Quadriplegia due to spinal cord injury
* COVID vaccine status: Hesitant, unvaccinated, concerns about side effects and "vaccine injury," but acknowledged as high risk for COVID-19 complications

P (Plan):

* Schedule follow-up in 2-3 weeks for updated fasting labs including CBC and cholesterol panel
* Continue bowel regimen with Miralax and lactulose as needed
* Discussed the importance of COVID-19 vaccination; recommended vaccination considering high risk due to quadriplegia
* Provided education on dehydration, constipation management, and COVID-19 prevention
* Addressed patient's concerns about vaccine safety and side effects; encouraged informed decision-making

[doctor] okay , this is a six-week post-op meeting exam for her . her gait was antalgic with a slight limp and decreased velocity . she's not using an assistive device . right knee focused exam has a healed surgical scar , mild swelling , tenderness- tenderness .
[doctor] . on the area of the incision . range of motion is zero to 120 degrees . everything else normal . radiographs were three views of the right knee taken today and show implants in stable position .
[doctor] no evidence of loosening or early complications . thanks .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: No current pain, still experiencing numbness on the right knee.
* History of present illness: Patient reports numbness on the right side of the knee six weeks after right medial unicompartmental arthroplasty. No other problems or pain.
* Past medical history: No information provided.
* Social history: Works for UPS, unable to return to full duty due to work restrictions.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided.
* Physical exam: Right knee has a healed surgical scar, mild swelling, tenderness at the incision area, gait is antalgic with a slight limp, decreased velocity, no assistive device used, range of motion from 0 to 120 degrees, everything else normal.
* Test results: Radiographs show implants in stable position, good alignment from front and side views, no evidence of loosening or early complications.

A (Assessment):

* Postoperative status six weeks after right medial unicompartmental arthroplasty
* No evidence of loosening or early complications
* Persistent numbness likely due to nerve healing process
* Gait disturbance (antalgic gait, slight limp)

P (Plan):

* Continue physical therapy focusing on strength, range of motion, and endurance
* No lifting greater than 5-10 pounds, no standing or sitting longer than 30 minutes
* Provide a note to excuse the patient from work for another six weeks permitting sitting for the shift with breaks
* Follow-up telemedicine visit scheduled in six weeks to monitor progress
* Discuss return to work and driving at the next visit based on recovery status
* Advise patient to avoid heavy labor tasks until further clearance

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney
* History of present illness: Presented after episodes of right-sided abdominal pain, initial suspicion of appendix; experienced worsening pain and vomiting over several days; later findings of atrophic right kidney, cysts, and swelling of lymph nodes; reports persistent stomach pain and burning sensation, especially after eating; complains of difficulty starting urination and burning when urinating without visible blood; reports no current fevers or blood in urine
* Past medical history: No prior kidney issues diagnosed, childhood hospitalizations for recurrent infections with antibiotics and fluids, possible prior kidney involvement since childhood
* Social history: Active in softball, plans to join drill team, practices hydration habits
* Family history: Father with kidney transplant due to obstructive neuropathy, grandfather with end-stage renal disease and dialysis, great-aunt with kidney disease, mother with breast cancer, family history of kidney disease and related conditions

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Well-appearing female, alert and oriented, sitting comfortably, no acute distress, lungs and heart sounds normal
* Test results: Physical exam within normal limits; ultrasound findings include a small (atrophic) right kidney, cysts on her kidney and ovaries, swelling of lymph nodes; urine analysis, blood pressure, and blood tests not explicitly detailed but advised to monitor; kidney function appears preserved on current assessment

A (Assessment):

* Atrophic right kidney with cysts and signs of prior infection
* No current evidence of renal dysfunction or high blood pressure
* Symptoms of urinary burning and difficulty with urination, possibly related to sensitivity or mild infection
* No diagnosis explicitly confirmed; ongoing monitoring recommended
* Family history of kidney disease and transplant in father, with previous suspect of congenital or acquired kidney issues
* No definite diagnosis of active infection or kidney failure; condition under surveillance

P (Plan):

* Monitor kidney size and function with annual ultrasound
* Perform urinalysis periodically to check for proteinuria or hematuria
* Maintain blood pressure within normal limits
* Avoid non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; use Tylenol if needed
* Encourage hydration with at least two liters of water daily, especially during activity
* Continue healthy diet and active lifestyle
* Follow up with primary care or local nephrologist for ongoing management
* Contact healthcare provider if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop

* Chief complaint: Lower back pain

* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

A (Assessment):

* Post-surgical lower back pain, likely muscular pull or strain, no evidence of fracture or nerve impingement on physical exam

P (Plan):

* Prescribe physical therapy for muscle and spinal alignment support
* Prescribe meloxicam for pain management
* Refer to pain management for further evaluation of pain and narcotic use discussion
* Prescribe demerol for pain control
* No other issues reported or addressed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: No specific current complaints; patient reports feeling better but is struggling and finds it a scary time
* History of present illness: Recently had a heart attack with stent placement in the right coronary artery; feels better since surgery with no chest pain now; experiences shortness of breath when walking up and down stairs; reports that medication adherence has been maintained
* Past medical history: Heart attack, stent placement, mild mitral regurgitation
* Social history: Watches diet, occasionally eats pizza, sleeps and rests adequately, enjoys being a Denver Nuggets fan
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/60 mmHg
* Physical exam:
  - Neck: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits
  - Heart: Slight systolic ejection murmur (3/6) heard at the left base
  - Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally
  - Musculoskeletal: Cardiac catheter site on right wrist is clean, dry, intact, with no hematoma, palpable radial pulse
* Test results:
  - Blood tests ordered: Liver function studies, lipid panel
  - Echocardiogram: Mild mitral regurgitation, ejection fraction approximately 50%

A (Assessment):

* Inferior myocardial infarction, status post stent placement
* Mild mitral regurgitation
* No other explicitly stated diagnoses or suspected conditions

P (Plan):

* Continue aspirin lifelong
* Continue brilinta for at least one year
* Continue toprol (metoprolol) 50 mg once daily
* Continue crestor 40 mg once daily
* Repeat echocardiogram in 6 months
* Order liver function tests and lipid panel
* Recommend gradual resumption of swimming, with caution
* Enroll in cardiac rehab for exercise and dietary counseling
* Follow-up in 6 weeks
* No issues with medication cost reported
* No current restrictions on activity besides gradual return to exercise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain following a fall from a tandem bike approximately two weeks ago
* History of present illness: Knee injury caused by falling onto the curb, sustained after hitting a curb during a bike fall, with persistent pain that has not improved over two weeks; pain is worse with walking uphill or on incline, and sometimes sensation of shifting; current pain persists despite use of ibuprofen
* Past medical history: No prior knee problems reported
* Social history: Works in a children’s hospital as a baby rocker, occasionally walks dog, does not participate in athletic activities currently, swims sporadically
* No information provided on family history or other social habits

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Tenderness on the medial joint line, no tenderness over popliteal space, epicondyles, or other areas; abrasions over medial patella (dried, about one week old); full extension with brief discomfort and clicking; full bilateral flexion; valgus stress test shows medial collateral ligament is intact; lateral collateral ligament intact; posterior drawer test shows slight laxity on the right knee; anterior drawer and Lachman negative; patella tracks normally, no crepitus; tenderness localized on medial joint line; no signs of instability on lateral side; no obvious deformity or swelling otherwise

* X-ray findings: Normal bone edges, no fractures, no bone spurs, no joint space narrowing, patella tracking normal on radiographs

A (Assessment):

* No definitive diagnosis provided; suspected posterior cruciate ligament injury based on physical examination and clinical suspicion
* No definite evidence of meniscal tear or cartilage injury noted on exam or radiographs
* No data suggesting fracture, ligament rupture requiring surgery, or other pathology

P (Plan):

* Obtain MRI to evaluate for possible posterior cruciate ligament injury or other internal derangement
* Continue NSAIDs (ibuprofen) up to three times daily, or switch to a prescription medication for analgesia as discussed
* Apply ice packs several times daily
* Fit patient with a knee brace for stabilization
* Refer to physical therapy for initial evaluation and guided rehabilitation
* Recheck in four to six weeks to assess recovery and stability
* Advise initial few visits to physical therapy, then evaluation of progress at home
* Discussed possibility of surgical intervention if symptoms persist after conservative management
* No further questions; follow-up plan set

O (Objective):

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Abdominal pain
* History of present illness: Started about 10 days ago with mild right-sided discomfort, worsening over the last few days, intensity around 4-5/10, sometimes up to 7-8/10; worsened after meals, localized to right side, mild radiating to the left, associated with nausea and heartburn, tenderness on palpation, pain worse in certain positions
* Additional symptoms: Fatigue, decreased appetite, no vomiting, no diarrhea, no blood in stool or urine, no urinary symptoms
* Past medical history: Chronic migraines, hypertension
* Medications: Excedrin migraine, sumatriptan (as needed), lisinopril 20 mg daily
* Social history: No recent travel or unusual exposures
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Mild to moderate tenderness in right upper quadrant, equivocal Murphy's sign, no tenderness in right lower quadrant, no CVA tenderness, normal cardiovascular exam aside from unchanged grade 3 systolic ejection murmur, rest of abdominal exam unremarkable
* Laboratory tests: Pending blood tests (CBC, chem 12, urinalysis, pregnancy test), ultrasound of right upper quadrant

A (Assessment):

* Acute right upper quadrant abdominal pain, possibly due to gallstones or gallbladder infection
* Chronic migraines, well controlled
* Hypertension, adequately controlled on lisinopril

P (Plan):

* Order blood tests (CBC, chem 12, urinalysis, pregnancy test) and right upper quadrant ultrasound
* Advise patient to avoid eating until further results are available
* Continue excedrin migraine as needed, continue sumatriptan for breakthrough migraines (refill prescribed), advise to avoid alcohol and caffeine, get adequate sleep
* Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily, refill prescribed
* Refill prescription for sumatriptan
* Follow up in approximately 4 weeks after reviewing test results
* Monitor for any development of fever or worsening symptoms; consider emergency department if symptoms progress

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Hacking cough for three days
* History of present illness: Started three days ago after being around sister with similar symptoms, gradual onset cough with productive green phlegm, associated with sore throat and nasal congestion, no fever, no shortness of breath, not responding to over-the-counter cough medication
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus (well controlled, blood sugars around 120), hypertension (blood pressure elevated), seasonal allergies (springtime sneezing and runny nose), tolerated recent start of metformin 500 mg without issues, no diarrhea
* Social history: Recent vacation, no recent sick contact besides sister
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 144/72 mmHg, otherwise vitals appear generally good
* Physical exam:
   - Sinuses: No frontal sinus tenderness, bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness
   - Oral cavity: Erythema of the pharynx, symmetrical tonsils without exudates
   - Neck: Anterior cervical lymphadenopathy
   - Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, systolic ejection murmur (2/6) at left base
   - Lungs: Clear auscultation, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi
   - Lower extremities: No edema

A (Assessment):

* Upper respiratory infection, likely viral
* Uncontrolled hypertension, currently elevated
* Diabetes mellitus type 2, well controlled
* Allergic rhinitis (seasonal)

P (Plan):

* For cough: Continue supportive care—drink plenty of fluids, rest, try over-the-counter cough remedy such as Coricidin HBP, monitor symptoms
* COVID-19 testing: Will perform COVID test to rule out infection
* Diabetes: Continue metformin 500 mg daily, schedule follow-up for hemoglobin A1c testing in 3 months
* Hypertension: Increase hydrochlorothiazide to 25 mg once daily, recommend regular blood pressure monitoring multiple times weekly
* No other medications or interventions at this time; patient educated about symptom monitoring, hydration, and follow-up; no questions from patient

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left shoulder pain for a few weeks
* History of present illness: Pain started without trauma, associated with active lifestyle and basement renovation, constant pain worsened when sleeping on left side and when raising arm overhead, relieved somewhat by Tylenol, pain level 7 without medication and 2-3 with Tylenol, difficulty sleeping on left side
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Active lifestyle, recent basement renovation, house living for some time, pandemic-related home renovations
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Limited active and passive range of motion in left shoulder, tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at sternoclavicular or clavicular joints, good hand grip bilaterally, neurovascular exam normal with brisk capillary refill less than 3 seconds, motor and sensation intact
* Imaging: X-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

* Left shoulder pain, most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy

P (Plan):

* Order MRI of the left shoulder
* Refer for physical therapy for 6 to 8 weeks
* Continue Tylenol as needed
* Consider steroid injection if symptoms do not improve
* Follow-up in approximately two weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain
* History of present illness: Sudden onset of right knee pain with swelling and difficulty walking after playing basketball yesterday; sensation of knee popping; pain on the inside of the knee; tolerable pain level about 4/10; swelling decreased overnight; took Tylenol with minimal relief; able to bear weight but favors the leg
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Social history: Played basketball for the first time in two years; dietary habits described as eating anything; unsure about blood pressure readings but reports ranges in the 140s–150s over 80s
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure approximately 140/80 mmHg
* Physical exam: Right knee tender to palpation on the medial side, with edema, ecchymosis, redness; pain with bending and straightening; no varus or valgus instability; lungs: clear, heart: grade two systolic ejection murmur; weight, height, temperature: No information provided
* Test results: X-ray of right knee normal; no fractures or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Right knee pain, suspected MCL strain or possible tear
* Hypertension, poorly controlled (BP around 140/80 mmHg)
* Diabetes mellitus, suboptimal control (A1c 7.2%; inconsistent medication adherence)

P (Plan):

* Continue Tylenol for knee pain; prescribe meloxicam 15 mg for pain and swelling; put right knee in immobilizer and advise off-weight bearing for several weeks; plan for MRI to assess for MCL tear
* Advise patient to start daily blood glucose monitoring; maintain a log for review
* Refer to nutrition for dietary improvement
* Up medication for hypertension to Norvasc 10 mg daily
* Schedule follow-up in two weeks
* Educate patient to limit sugar intake from strawberries due to diabetes; discuss lifestyle modifications to improve blood pressure and glucose control

* Recurrent streptococcal pharyngitis
* Suspected glomerulonephritis
* No other diagnoses explicitly stated

P (Plan):

* Advise fasting before labs; tests to be done as soon as possible

* Follow-up in one week, preferably by phone if results are normal; in person if further discussion needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Cough and recent fall causing right knee pain
* History of present illness: Cough started about a week ago with yellow sputum, worsening over the last two days, no fever or chills, feeling warm but no temperature taken, associated congestion and sinus pressure, no shortness of breath, no other respiratory symptoms
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Social history: Works as a teacher, not a sports fan, no other household illnesses
* Additional: Twisted right knee after falling down 4-5 stairs while coughing this morning; knee pain mostly inside, able to walk with a slight limp, no inability to walk or significant instability, no current pain medication, taking over-the-counter cough remedies

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Temperature 98.4°F, blood pressure 125/62 mmHg, heart rate 85 bpm, oxygen saturation 97% on room air
* Physical exam: 
  - Face: Pain to palpation of bilateral maxillary sinuses
  - Nasal exam: Erythema and edema of bilateral nasal turbinates with yellow discharge
  - Throat: Uvula midline, no erythema, edema, or exudate
  - Neck: Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy
  - Lung: Coarse rhonchi bilaterally that clear with cough
  - Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
  - Right knee: Pain to palpation, decreased flexion and extension, ecchymosis on medial side, no effusion, slight limp

A (Assessment):

* Viral upper respiratory infection with mild bronchitis
* Right medial collateral ligament strain from fall
* Hypertension
* Diabetes

P (Plan):

* Cough: Supportive care with over-the-counter medications, prescribe guaifenesin 600 mg twice daily, monitor symptoms, and consider chest x-ray if symptoms worsen
* Right knee: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily, order right knee x-ray, refer to physical therapy
* Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily, order lipid panel
* Diabetes: Order hemoglobin A1c, advise monitoring blood sugar levels, report values via patient portal

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Headache and high blood pressure
* History of present illness: Headaches on top of the head that come and go for about a month, throbbing, relieved somewhat by Tylenol; associated dizziness and blurry vision; headaches correlate with elevated blood pressure
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes mellitus
* Social history: Frequently eats McDonald's fast food, particularly Big Mac and fries; indulged in Easter candy, possibly affecting blood sugar
* Family history: No information provided
* Medications: Not regularly taking chlorthalidone, possibly every other day; takes metformin approximately every other day

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, lungs clear bilaterally, systolic ejection murmur (grade 2/6) present since last year, slight bilateral edema of upper extremities, one plus pitting edema in both legs
* Additional findings: No shortness of breath reported

* Uncontrolled hypertension
* Elevated blood sugar level (approximately 170 mg/dL)

P (Plan):

* Physical exam: Monitor systolic murmur and edema
* Patient education on medication adherence, diet modifications, and blood sugar monitoring
* Nurse to complete examination; scheduler to arrange follow-up appointment

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Back pain for about two years
* History of present illness: Started after falling and hitting his back while playing basketball, pain has persisted since then, severity around 7/10, sharp with throbbing sometimes, radiates down the left leg, occasional numbness in toes, worsens with standing for a while, improves when lying on side, associated with weakness when standing too long, one episode of incontinence (bowel), previous ineffective treatments (injections, physical therapy, pain medication)
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Family history: Distant relative (fourth cousin) with scoliosis
* Social history: Smoked in the past, currently does not smoke, sedentary lifestyle, significant weight gain (~80 pounds in a year), no current activity, weight concerns linked to family history

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No overlying erythema or ecchymosis on the back, midline tenderness at L4-L5, right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness, pain with lumbar flexion and extension, positive straight leg test on the right, decreased light touch sensation at right lateral thigh (L4 dermatome), symmetric reflexes (patella and Achilles)
* Diagnostic results: MRI shows disk desiccation, disk bulge with paracentral disk herniation causing moderate right foramenal stenosis

A (Assessment):

* Lumbar radiculopathy secondary to L4-L5 disk herniation

P (Plan):

* Recommend a corticosteroid spinal injection under fluoroscopy, with pre-procedure anxiolytic medication if needed
* Will consider reduction of pain medication after injection if effective; initial pain medications previously ineffective
* Advise monitoring pain, reassessment if symptoms persist
* Discussed possibility of surgery if conservative measures fail
* Instruct patient to schedule the procedure at the front desk
* No further questions from the patient

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Vision changes, trouble with right eye, difficulty adjusting in dark environments, perceiving straight lines as wavy
* History of present illness: Wavy perception of straight lines (door frame, paneling), worsening over three to four months, difficulty reading and adjusting in dim environments, no mention of pain or other symptoms
* Past medical history: High blood pressure, no medication adherence
* Social history: Smokes approximately a pack of cigarettes daily despite attempts to quit, eats out frequently, including recent visit to an Italian restaurant
* No family history or other relevant social and medical history provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: 
  - Eye exam: Posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes, clear cornea, no new vessels in anterior segment, cup-to-disc ratio 0.2 right eye, 0.3 left eye
  - Fundus exam: Right eye shows retina attached 360°, drusen in macula, retinal thickening, subretinal fluid, hemorrhage, RPE changes in fovea; left eye shows similar RPE changes without hemorrhage or subretinal fluid, retina attached
  - Diagnostic test results: Drusen deposits under RPE, subretinal fluid, choroidal neovascular membrane, fluorescein angiography shows focal leakage consistent with neovascular (wet) age-related macular degeneration

A (Assessment):

* Neovascular (wet) age-related macular degeneration

P (Plan):

* Administer monthly intravitreal injections of lucentis (ranibizumab) following local anesthesia
* Educate patient on the purpose of injections and potential for slight residual vision loss
* Nurse to prepare patient for injection today
* Reinforce the importance of medication adherence for blood pressure management
* Encourage smoking cessation efforts
* Schedule follow-up to monitor treatment response and disease progression

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain and swelling following injury during skiing
* History of present illness: Swelling and pain in the right knee after a fall while skiing on Saturday, felt a pop, pain worsened with flexion and extension, full range of motion but tight and painful, minimal ability to walk
* Past medical history: No previous knee injuries
* Social history: Went skiing at Mount Saint Helens, Washington; trip involved outdoor activities including skiing, hiking, kayaking, and maple syrup tourism
* No additional complaints reported

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Edema and ecchymosis around the right knee, pain to palpation, pain with flexion and extension, full range of motion despite tightness, no bony abnormalities on x-ray
* Additional exam: Bruising on the right shoulder, tenderness when raising the shoulder, no mention of other injuries

A (Assessment):

* Right knee contusion

P (Plan):

* Rest, ice application 2-3 times daily for 20 minutes, NSAIDs such as ibuprofen every 6-8 hours as needed
* No fracture detected on x-ray
* If symptoms do not improve, consider physical therapy
* Obtain X-ray of the right shoulder to rule out additional injury
* Follow-up as needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath, painful swallowing
* History of present illness: Noticed shortness of breath over the weekend, inability to walk down the street without shortness of breath, dry cough, no phlegm, no fever, painful swallowing especially when breathing, difficulty taking in liquids due to pain but able to drink Ensure and milkshake
* Past medical history: Stage three non-small cell lung cancer, recent chemotherapy with cisplatin and a topicide, recent radiation therapy
* Social history: Takes dogs for daily walks, owns a Doberman, support from husband and daughter, feelings of devastation and trying to adapt

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Normal, oxygen saturation normal
* Physical exam: No cervical or subclavicular lymphadenopathy, regular heart rate and rhythm, faint bilateral lung crackles, erythema on anterior chest (likely radiation dermatitis), no lower extremity edema
* Test results: Chest X-ray shows mild radiation pneumonitis, no additional laboratory or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

* Lung cancer, ongoing chemotherapy and radiation therapy
* Radiation pneumonitis
* Odynophagia due to radiation-induced inflammation

P (Plan):

* Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation doses; plan for further testing and possible tumor resection after treatment completion
* Prescribe prednisone 40 mg once daily for 5 days to treat radiation pneumonitis
* Prescribe lidocaine swallow squishy for painful swallowing, to be used four times daily
* Provide patient education on medication use and symptom management
* Follow-up in two weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left flank pain radiating to groin, persistent for two weeks
* History of present illness: Pain starts in right flank, radiates to groin, varies in intensity (1-4/10), episodic, influenced by activity and fluid intake, no accompanying hematuria or dysuria, pain radiated to testicle once, no nausea or vomiting, no fever, chills noted, pain persists despite ibuprofen
* Past medical history: Kidney stones, prior surgeries, passed stones independently within a week
* Family history: Multiple family members with kidney stones
* Social history: No alcohol or drug use reported

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Slightly elevated blood pressure (exact value not specified)
* Physical exam: No abdominal tenderness on palpation, CVA tenderness on right side; no signs of abdominal inflammation or distension
* Test results: CT scan shows a 0.5 cm stone in the proximal right ureter, no high flow nephrosis observed

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone (nephrolithiasis), confirmed by imaging, located on the proximal right ureter
* No evidence of obstructive nephropathy

P (Plan):

* Continue high fluid intake aiming to pass the stone
* Continue ibuprofen for pain management; prescribe tramadol 50 mg for breakthrough pain
* Advise patient to use a strainer during urination to catch the stone
* Order BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to assess for infection
* Re-evaluate in 1-2 weeks depending on symptom persistence
* Discuss potential further treatment options such as lithotripsy if the stone does not pass
* Prescribed medication details provided by nurse; follow-up appointment scheduled in two weeks
* No further questions from patient

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath
* History of present illness: Shortness of breath lasting about one week, worse with walking stairs and quickly, alleviates with coughing, no recent overnight awakening due to breathlessness, increased nighttime urination, history of similar episode six months ago, feels okay but not great
* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease with prior heart attack (2018), stent placement in right coronary artery, ejection fraction around 35%, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, foot pain episode in past week
* Social history: Holiday dietary indiscretion, no mention of smoking or alcohol
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 135/80 mmHg
* Physical exam: Jugular venous distention up to 9 cm, bibasilar crackles with occasional rhonchi on lung exam, systolic ejection murmur (3/6) at left base, bilateral 1-2+ pitting edema
* Test results: No results provided

A (Assessment):

* Acute heart failure exacerbation
* Coronary artery disease
* Stage 3 chronic kidney disease
* Possible gout flare
* No other diagnoses explicitly stated

P (Plan):

* Increase Lasix dose from 40 mg to 80 mg daily; take in the morning, consider a second dose around 4 pm if needed, monitor weight, call in 2 days or earlier if symptoms worsen
* Order chest x-ray to evaluate for pulmonary causes
* Order echocardiogram to assess heart function and murmur
* Continue follow-up with nephrologist, avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil), use Tylenol for pain; order complete metabolic panel to monitor kidney function
* Counsel on salt intake, refer to dietitian for dietary guidance
* Order serum uric acid to evaluate for gout
* No other medications or therapy prescribed at this time
* Patient questions addressed, reassurance provided

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Heart murmur, leg pain, dizziness, fatigue
* History of present illness: Recently diagnosed with a new heart murmur; reports severe leg pain for about a month, fluctuating ankle swelling for approximately 6 months, and gradual weight loss over the past year; experiences shortness of breath with exertion, dizziness, and fatigue related to medication use and activity level; no chest pain or palpitations; no recent fevers or chills
* Past medical history: No specific details provided; history of surgeries, including some unspecified
* Family history: Son had a heart attack, older sister had a heart problem, brother had a stroke; no personal smoking or drug allergies
* Social history: No smoking
* Current medications: Levothyroxine, amlodipine, lisinopril, simvastatin, meclizine (as needed)

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific values provided
* Physical exam: Elderly, otherwise no acute distress; cardiovascular exam shows normal S1 and S2, regular rhythm, systolic murmur grade 4/6 at right upper sternal border radiating mildly to carotids; neurologic gait normal; bilateral ankle swelling; no signs of volume overload
* Test results: EKG shows sinus rhythm with frequent PVCs and anterior septum infarct pattern; no specific lab or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

* Probably one cardiac murmur, diana has a 4-6 systolic murmur at the upper right sternal border with mild radiation to the carotids: most likely representative of aortic stenosis
* Her symptoms could be due to severe aortic stenosis; however, her S2 is relatively preserved, which would be more consistent with moderate stenosis
* Diastolic dysfunction noted in outside records suggest prior echocardiogram
* PVCs on EKG, with sinus rhythm and frequent PVCs, possibly related to underlying cardiac condition
* Bilateral leg swelling, likely related to fluid retention or venous issues
* Lightheadedness and dizziness, possibly related to aortic stenosis, medication effects, or arrhythmias
* No chest pain, no atrial fibrillation symptoms, no recent fevers or chills

P (Plan):

* Schedule echocardiogram to assess cardiac structure, valve function, and severity of aortic stenosis
* Consider ischemic evaluation or heart monitoring depending on echocardiogram results and severity of stenosis
* Continue current antihypertensive therapy with amlodipine and lisinopril
* Discuss possibility of discontinuing statin therapy with primary care provider due to leg pain, potential for TAVR evaluation following echocardiogram
* Continue levothyroxine for hypothyroidism
* Address bilateral leg swelling and leg pain, follow-up after echocardiogram to evaluate further management
* Potentially initiate heart monitor to evaluate PVC burden if symptoms develop
* Follow-up in 3 to 4 weeks after echocardiogram to review results and plan next steps

[patient] okay , so is there anything we can do to help it ? [doctor] yes , i would like to start with a topical therapy first . every morning you will wash your face with a mild cleanser . then use a moisturizer label noncommittogenic with sunscreen , spf 30 or higher . this means it wo n't clog your pors . now in the evening , wash your face with the same cleanser and allow it to dry . apply adapalene 0.1 % cream in a thin layer to the areas you generally get acne . i want you to start off using this a few nights a week and slowly work up to using it every night . if it , it is , excuse me , if it is very expensive or not covered by insurance , you can try differin gel over the counter . you can follow that with clean and clear bursa gel and a thin layer where you generally get acne and then a noncommunogenic moisturizer . your topical retinoid wo n't cause sun sensitivity so you will need to wear sunscreen when you are outside . it may also cause some dryness or irritation . [patient] okay . i can do that . [doctor] you also have multiple benign moles on your arms , legs , back , and abdomen . this means they all look normal with no worrisome features . we will see if you have any progress over the next 6 months and follow up at that time . [doctor] okay . if you have questions or concerns before your next visit , please call the office . [patient] thank you , doctor , we will .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Acne on the face for approximately 2 years
- History of present illness: Acne present most every day, mild to moderate, primarily on forehead, central cheeks, and chin; no associated symptoms such as itching, bleeding, or pain; no significant flare with periods; no notable flare with sports or sweating
- Past medical history: No additional past medical history
- Social history: Lives with parents and sister, attends seventh grade, plays basketball, volleyball, and tap; uses SPF 30 sunscreen in summer

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Multiple benign navy-colored nevi on trunk and extremities, skin-colored papules, open and closed comedones, erythematous papules on the face (primarily on forehead, some on central cheeks and chin); chest and back relatively spared; remainder of examination normal

A (Assessment):

- Mild to moderate face acne, primarily comedonal with small inflammatory component

P (Plan):

- Initiate topical therapy: morning - wash face with mild cleanser, apply moisturizer with SPF 30 or higher; evening - wash face, dry, apply adapalene 0.1% cream to affected areas, starting a few nights per week and gradually increasing frequency; if cost or coverage is an issue, suggest over-the-counter Differin gel followed by Clean & Clear Busa gel and moisturizer; advise sunscreen use during outdoor activities; monitor for dryness or irritation
- Follow-up in 6 months to assess progress
- No concerns about benign moles; continue observation
- Educate patient and parent about potential side effects and sun protection
- No questions from patient

SOAP:

* Chief complaint: Pain in the left shoulder and left elbow

O (Objective):

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Runny nose, nasal congestion, cough, ear pulling, irritability
- History of present illness: Onset last night around suppertime; clear mucus now; mild fever of 100.3°F; decreased appetite last night and this morning; difficulty sleeping; increased irritability; no barky cough seen yet
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: Older sister and nephew had illnesses (sinus infection), exposure to sick contacts
- Review of symptoms: Runny nose, nasal congestion, cough, ear pulling, irritability, low-grade fever, decreased appetite, difficulty sleeping

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Rectal temperature 100.3°F
- Physical exam: Ears appear normal, no signs of ear infection; nasal congestion with clear mucus; no abnormal findings noted on exam
- Test results: No additional lab or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

- Likely viral upper respiratory infection (common cold), possibly viral sinus infection; no evidence of bacterial infection at this time; no mention of other diagnoses

P (Plan):

- Continue saline mist in the nose, use humidifier, and baby Vicks on feet for symptom relief
- Administer Tylenol (acetaminophen) as needed for fever
- Observe for development of barky cough; if occurs, give half a teaspoon of the sister’s medication for 5 days
- Use Zarbee’s for cough if needed, dosage for under 1 year old
- Avoid giving honey; use Gave instead
- Prescribe same medication as his sister for symptom management, on hand in case symptoms worsen
- Continue cradle cap shampoo (regular strength Head and Shoulders or Selsun Blue or Nizoral A.D.) twice weekly, brush gently, avoid eyes
- Follow-up appointment in 1 week to reassess symptoms and condition
