[patient] okay , so looking at the measurements , it looks like one breast is a little lower than the other , yeah . okay . well , thank you so much . it looks like i have all the measurements that we need . you can go ahead and cover up now . okay . [doctor] so i think you are a great candidate for a breast reduction . when we talk about a breast reduction , what happens is that we remove the tissue out of the breast . [patient] okay , that's fine . and we would then lift them and elevate the nipple position in order to help with your back pain , neck pain and because i'm a plastic surgeon , of course i want them to look nice as well . wow . [doctor] so typically when you do the breast reduction , we make an incision around the nipple straight down and then underneath and it kinda looks like an anchor below . [patient] then straight down and underneath and through that incision , we're able to to lift the breast and we'll take off any extra fat and brush breast tissue , so that way it becomes smaller in size . and i noticed that you would like to be a b cup , so i do tell every patient , we can make you a small as your blood supply allows and what that means is we must move the nipple without cutting off any of it's blood supply during the surgery . okay . well , thank you for explaining that . you're welcome . and in your case , you'll probably be a small c a b cup might be a little bit small , but we'll see once i'm doing the , the procedure for you . okay . [doctor] and typically the surgery takes about 3 hours you will have drains one in each side and that helps prevent fluid from building up in the breast and that stays in for about a week and then we will remove them in the clinic . [patient] and you'll have a clear plastic tape over your incision that should help with the scars and we've seen that patients who have lighter skin , the scars will tend to be red at first and then it takes about a year for a scar to mature in line . okay . well i'm not too worried about the card . okay and i do like to keep patients overnight , it's just going to be for one night in the hospital , [doctor] and we just wan na make sure your pain is controlled , make sure you're not nauseated , all of that stuff . some patients wan na go home that same day , [patient] but you know that some people get nauseated and the last thing that i want is for you to be vomiting at home alone without the , the support here at the facility . okay . yeah , that sounds good . okay . and then about 30 % of patients say that they can not breast feed after a breast reduction and the reason is the breast is made up of fat and it's also made up of a gland and the gland is what produces the milk , okay . and so in order to reduce the size of the breast , we have to take out both the fat and the glands , so it just depends on how much is left , whether you can breast-feed in the future and then also the breast will change over time if you gain weight , they will get larger , things like that . yeah , okay . and if you have children they will change as well . they will enlarge especially if you can breast feed , but they will go back down will appear a little bit deflated . yeah i do n't know if i'm interested in breast feeding . okay the hormones of pregnancy though will change the breast , so that's just something to be aware of and i tell all younger patients that . okay , yeah , absolutely . and then typically nipple sensation is fine after a breast reduction , but there is a slight chance that you will have an alteration in the nipple sensation or not have any sensation in the nipple , generally the nipple is just fine unless it is a massive reduction and it's quite normal after surgery to be a little bit bruised and then it just takes some time for that to go away . yeah , okay . but other than that you know most patients are very happy after the breast reduction because of the symptoms of the back pain , the neck pain , you can feel relief almost immediately . so do you have any questions julia about the process or anything like that ? no , not really . [doctor] okay and , and i do think you are a good candidate for it and i think you will benefit from it as well . [patient] good . i look forward to the release . i think you just have to do it when you are ready when you know that you feel like it's a good time because it is a commitment and you will have some activity restrictions for about 6 weeks after surgery and no heavy lifting and i do say no driving for 2 to 3 weeks and the drain stay in like i said for about a week . okay well i am ready as soon as my insurance is switched over . okay . well i think from this point if you want to , we can take photos today while you're here . i have all the documentation now and the note about your symptoms and that's what the insurance company is going to look for , so thank you for answering those questions . so once we have the new provider , we'll go ahead and get that submitted and then when they approve it , what the office will do is they'll work with you on a surgery date and then we'll meet again right before the surgery to answer any last minute questions . [doctor] and go over the instructions in more detail and things like that . [patient] okay . well , i will notify the office as soon as i have the insurance information . that sounds great and then we can get it all in process and it was so nice to meet you and catherine will be right in to get your photos . julia jones is a 25-year-old female with symptomatic macromycinia presenting for evaluation of breast reduction . the patient has attempted nonsurgical treatments with minimal relief and is an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty . her minimum required resection based on a bsa of 2.65 with the schnur scale is 1792 g which should be attainable . given her extremely large breasts and the measurements above , there is potential for using a free nipple graft . physical exam findings of breast . inspection reveals asymmetrical breasts with severe ptosis bilaterally . [doctor] there is no nipple retraction or discharge bilaterally . no breast tenderness , masses or axillary lymphadenopathy is palpable . [patient] julia jones is a 25-year-old female with symptomatic macromastia presenting for evaluation of breast reduction . the patient has attempted nonsurgical treatments with minimal relief and is an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction and mammoplasty . her minimum required resection based on a bsa of 2.65 , [doctor] with the schnur scale is 1792 g which should be attainable . given her extremely large breasts and the measurements above , there is potential for using a free nipple graft . physical exam findings of breast . inspection reveals asymmetrical breasts with severe ptosis bilaterally . there is no nipple retraction or discharge bilaterally . no breast tenderness , masses or axillary lymphadenopathy is palpable .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Breast size and symptoms related to macromastia
* History of present illness: Considering breast reduction for 6-7 years, experiencing back pain, neck pain, discomfort when exercising, and shoulder indentations from bra straps; sometimes experiencing nipple tingling and sensation changes; sweating underneath breasts; activities limited due to size; occasional nipple pain; no history of rashes or lactation issues; has attempted nonsurgical treatments with minimal relief; interested in surgery when insurance processed
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Occasional wine consumption, studying psychology
* Family history: Breast cancer in mother (diagnosed at age 40)

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Inspection reveals asymmetrical breasts with severe ptosis bilaterally; no nipple retraction or discharge bilaterally; no breast tenderness, masses, or axillary lymphadenopathy palpable; nipples alive with some tingling sensation reported; no skin rashes observed
* Measurements: One breast slightly lower than the other

A (Assessment):

* Symptomatic macromastia with severe ptosis, bilateral, suspected
* Candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty; her minimum resection estimate is 1792 grams based on BSA of 2.65 and Schnur scale; potential for use of free nipple graft given extreme size and measurements

P (Plan):

* Proceed with scheduling the breast reduction surgery once insurance coverage is confirmed
* Take photographs for documentation and insurance submission
* Send documentation of symptoms and physical exam findings to insurance for approval
* Discussed surgical process, including incisions (around the nipple, vertical, and inframammary fold), tissue removal (fat and gland), and potential for nipple grafting
* Explained typical postoperative course, drain management, scar maturation, and activity restrictions (no heavy lifting or driving for several weeks)
* Educated patient about possible changes in nipple sensation and breastfeeding limitations
* Follow-up planned after insurance approval for surgery scheduling and preoperative instructions

transcription: [patient] judy gomez , mrn 869723 , date of birth 5/7/1961 . she is in office today for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis . hello judy , how're you doing today ? [doctor] i'm doing good , thank you , how are you ? [patient] i'm great , thanks , so how have you been since the last time , i know the last time we were talking about decreasing your prednisone dose , correct ? [doctor] yes , i'm just on one now and that seems to be enough . [patient] that's great to hear . [doctor] yeah , there are a couple of days there , i took an extra one just because there was a little extra pain in my feet and i do have a desk job , so when i have a day off where i'm moving around a lot , they do tend to hurt a bit more . [patient] okay , how many times did you do that ? [doctor] it was n't often maybe once a week . [patient] okay so it sounds like we are still on track for discontinuing the prednisone , we'll do that today and you can let me know how it goes on your next visit and how about the methotrexate , do you think that helped with your joint pain ? [doctor] yeah , definitely because i went to get my covid shots but from the letter i got about it , it said that it could interfere with the vaccine , you know , reduce the efficacy , so i did n't take it on the week that i got the first shot . [patient] okay and what happened ? [doctor] i felt absolutely horrible until i took it again a week later . [patient] i'm sorry to hear that and , and what did you do about the second dose ? [doctor] well i called into the hotline because i was in so much pain with the first one and they said no , just go ahead and take it , so i did . [patient] okay , that's good then . we do have to keep an eye out on it since it's a high risk medication . do you have an appointment to get your blood drawn for the next time ? [doctor] no , they did n't give me one . [patient] okay . so we can do that for you too . so what questions do you have for me , judy ? [doctor] well i just wanted to know why i was getting all these bruises here so like when i bump myself , i do n't know where they are coming from . [patient] okay , that's probably from the prednisone , it can increase bruising . [doctor] okay , i did n't know that . i do n't even feel it when it happens , they just show up . [patient] yeah , unfortunately that can happen but we are working on discontinuing that , so let's see if the bruises do go away . [doctor] okay , that sounds good , thanks . [patient] okay judy , please sit up here and i'll take a look , shoes and socks off please . [doctor] alright . [patient] alright , let me see here , okay , so where is it hurting , in your joints right here ? [doctor] yeah , a little also in my feet joints as well . [patient] okay and how about when you bend the knee like this ? [doctor] well , it hurt before we increased the methotrexate , but it's doing pretty good now . okay , good . can you flex your toes please ? [patient] good range of motion also ridges and nails that's from the psoriasis . [doctor] yeah , they've been like that for a long time now . [patient] okay . alright miss gomez it looks like we are moving along with your treatment nicely . we will stop your prednisone and continue with the methotrexate . make sure you stop by the front desk and make an appointment for the blood work and i'll see you in 3 months . [doctor] alright , it sounds good . thank you so much . it was great to see you . [patient] it was great seeing you too . thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Bruising
* History of present illness: Bruises appearing all over, especially after bumping into objects; joint pain in feet and knees, previously increased with methotrexate adjustment, now improving; taking prednisone occasionally (once a week) for psoriatic arthritis, feeling some pain in feet, especially on days off with more movement; no issues reported with psoriasis skin condition.
* Past medical history: Psoriatic arthritis
* Social history: Desk job; no additional social history provided.
* Family history: No information provided.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided.
* Physical exam: Bruises visible; joint tenderness in feet and knees; good range of motion in toes; skin ridges and nail changes consistent with psoriasis.
* Test results: No laboratory results available (blood work not yet performed).

A (Assessment):

* Psoriatic arthritis
* Medication side effect: Bruising likely from prednisone
* No other diagnoses explicitly stated.

P (Plan):

* Discontinue prednisone today
* Continue methotrexate therapy
* Schedule blood draw for laboratory monitoring
* Follow-up in 3 months for reassessment
* Patient education on side effects of prednisone (bruising)
* Advise monitoring of bruises and joint symptoms

transcription: [doctor] kelly wood , date of birth february 15 , 1979 . established patient here for renal ultrasound because of hematuria . urine dipstick today negative for leukocytes , nitrates , protein , ketones , bilirubin and glucose color yellow and clear . urobilinogen 0.2 , ph 5.5 , and specific gravity 1.020 . there is a trace amount of blood in the urine and intact . renal ultrasound , impression , right kidney is 10 cm in length by 5 cm wide . there are no stones , masses , or hydronephrosis . the left kidney is 10.8 cm in length and 5 cm wide . there is a 6 mm left renal stone nonobstructing . 533 ml prevoid and 0 ml post void . hi mrs. wood , i see you just finished your ultrasound . [patient] yes ma'am . [doctor] well , it looks like you have 1 stone in the left kidney , but it's not obstructing anything . [patient] i knew it had to be a kidney stone . i passed what looked like two small stones last week after i scheduled this appointment and then for the past 6 weeks , i've had a few episodes of bright red urine , the color of like cherry cholestee , and last week i was constantly having to pee , and it hurt something terrible . [doctor] how bad was your pain on a scale of 0-10 , zero being no pain and 10 being worst as you can imagine . [patient] at the time i'd say an eight . [doctor] are you having any flank pain now or tenderness in your lower back ? [patient] no , after passing those stones , things have felt a lot better . [doctor] that's good to hear . now , it looks like you're only taking alavert 10 mg a day and have no drug allergies . is that correct ? [patient] that's right . [doctor] alright , well let's take a look at you today . let's use my default pe . well mrs. wood , we know that the blood in your urine was due to the kidney stones . fortunately you passed two last week and the blood has nearly subsided . you do still have 1 stone in the left kidney . since it's not obstructing or causing pain , i do n't recommend any surgical intervention at this time . [patient] i would like to know what i can do to stop getting these stones . [doctor] as we discussed last time , the formation of kidney stones can not be attributed to a particular cause . but several factors increase the risk such as dehydration , family history , certain foods , digestive tract disease , and certain medical conditions . [patient] yeah i know i do n't drink near the amount of water that i should . i drink more mountain dew than anything . [doctor] you should drink about half of your body weight in ounces of water a day . [patient] so if i weigh 250 pounds , i should drink . [doctor] that would be 125 ounces of water a day and you should avoid drinking sugary drinks like mountain dew . [patient] okay . is there any food i should n't eat ? [doctor] great question . you should avoid food rich in sodium , oxalate , and animal protein . so that would be salty , processed foods because they are high in sodium . ideally you should consume less than 1000 mg of sodium a day and reduce the amount of beef , poultry , fish , and pork . [patient] what's oxalate ? [doctor] it's an organic acid found in plants that when digested , it binds to minerals that stones are formed from foods like spinach , chocolate , beets , rubar , and soy products . [patient] well , i'll do whatever it takes to try to avoid getting these stones again . [doctor] great and here is a handout that you can look over . it goes over the dietary recommendations and what to avoid . [patient] okay , good . i like to have things in writing to help you remember . [doctor] perfect . well , if you have any more questions , if you do n't have any more questions , you're all set , i wo n't need to see you back until next year as long as you do n't have any more issues like bleeding or pain . if you do have any issues , you can always call the office sooner and if you experience any severe pain or bright red blood in your urine , you should go to the emergency room . [patient] alright , well , let's hope we do n't have to do either of those and i see you next year . [doctor] yes , so let's hope . come right this way and i'll walk you to check out . update pe abdomen , no flank pain and to gu . normal vaginal exam . primary diagnosis is hematuria . secondary diagnosis is chronic urolithiasis . thank you . this is complete . mrs. wood encounter .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):  
- Chief complaint: Hematuria and episodes of bright red urine over the past 6 weeks  
- History of present illness: Passed two small stones last week, had a pain level of 8/10 during episodes, experienced frequent urination and severe pain, but currently without flank pain or lower back tenderness  
- Past medical history: No specific mention other than kidney stones  
- Social history: Drinks more Mountain Dew than water, does not drink enough water, acknowledges the need to increase water intake and avoid sugary drinks and certain foods  
- Family history: No information provided  
- Review of systems: No additional complaints reported

O (Objective):  
- Vital signs: No information provided  
- Physical exam: Abdomen unchanged, no flank pain; normal vaginal exam  
- Urinalysis: Dipstick negative for leukocytes, nitrates, protein, ketones, bilirubin, glucose; urine color yellow and clear; urobilinogen 0.2; pH 5.5; specific gravity 1.020; trace blood detected; urine intact  
- Ultrasound: Right kidney 10 cm by 5 cm, no stones or masses, no hydronephrosis; left kidney 10.8 cm by 5 cm, contains a 6 mm nonobstructing stone; prevoid volume 533 ml, postvoid 0 ml

A (Assessment):  
- Hematuria  
- Chronic urolithiasis

P (Plan):  
- No surgical intervention recommended at this time since the stone is nonobstructing and not causing pain  
- Advise increased water intake to approximately 125 ounces daily if weighing 250 pounds, and avoiding sugary drinks like Mountain Dew  
- Dietary recommendations to avoid foods high in sodium, oxalate, and animal protein (e.g., spinach, chocolate, beets, rhubarb, soy), with less than 1000 mg sodium daily  
- Provided educational handout on dietary modifications to prevent stone formation  
- Instructed patient to return if experiencing severe pain or bright red blood in urine, or if other issues occur  
- Follow-up: No scheduled visit needed until next year unless new issues arise

[doctor] okay yeah are you able to move your arm very well or not
[patient] yeah there is no restriction with my arm it just i definitely feel some pain on the outside of it
[doctor] okay and are you having pain all the time or just or does it come and go
[patient] just whenever i move it if i'm sitting still i really do n't notice anything but whenever i move it then i can definitely feel some pain

[doctor] okay
[patient] of course

[patient] i well let's see i've been putting an outdoor shower in we're extending our patio putting making some flower boxes putting down some you know for stone and all the flower beds so my wife's really put me to work i got a laundry lift

[patient] yeah
[doctor] yeah i bet that is sore now tell me this have you experienced any numbness in your arm or your hands or
[patient] no not really no numbness that i can think of
[doctor] okay alright so see i'm gon na i'd like to do just a quick physical exam and i've reviewed your vitals those look good your no fever so that's good you're ninety seven . eight and your heart rate looks good at sixty two respirations sixteen your blood pressures one sixteen over eighty four that looks fine your oxygen saturation is real good at ninety nine percent so that all looks good so let's take a look at your left at your right shoulder so you have limited active and passive range of motion and there is some tenderness at the great tuberosity of the humerus there is no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acro acromioclavicular joints you do have a good hand grip okay and on neurovascular exam of your right arm your capillary refill is less than three seconds and your sensation to touch is intact so i've reviewed the results of your shoulder x-ray and there is no fracture so that's good so let me tell you a little bit about my assessment and plan so for your first problem the right shoulder pain your symptoms are most likely due to this rotator cuff rotator cuff tendinopathy that means you that you injured injured the tendons of the muscles that help make your shoulder muscles i think we had to go ahead and order just an mri since you have had some problems before as well to make sure there's nothing else going on with it and i also want to refer you to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks and so during that time continue the tylenol and if your symptoms do n't improve we can go ahead and consider a steroid injection of your shoulder which could provide some relief do you have any questions about your plan
[patient] no that sounds good
[doctor] okay alright yeah a lot of patients it's very successful with the physical therapy so i really hope that will do it and so we'll just start there okay
[patient] sounds great
[doctor] okay thanks
[patient] thanks
[doctor] did you have any other any other problems any other injuries that that went along with this or
[patient] my both my my feet are actually really sore too i obviously have been doing a lot of other yard work so you know it's kinda it's really stiff and stuff and they you know my ankle joints as well my wife seems to think that i do n't drink enough water so it could be something along that lines but i do n't know they're kinda this they just they're really sore and stuff so i've been trying to put them up and kinda put ice on them keep them elevated and it seems to be helping out a little bit but
[doctor] yeah so if you do n't feel that you did anything to injure it we might start just maybe do some epsom salts have you tried soaking your feet in epsom salts that will tend to kinda pull out what's going on in there and just help your those muscles to relax and the soreness to to go away you might try that
[patient] okay that sounds like a plan that sounds good
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right shoulder pain for a few weeks, bilateral foot soreness
* History of present illness: Right shoulder soreness following yard work and household projects, tender on the outside, worsens with movement, bothers him at night due to sleeping on that side; bilateral foot soreness, stiffness, and soreness related to yard work, possibly dehydration
* Past medical history: Previous right shoulder injury playing baseball
* Social history: Engaged in yard projects including lifting, stone laying, flower beds, outdoor shower installation
* No information provided about family history

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 116/84 mmHg, heart rate 62 bpm, respiratory rate 16/min, oxygen saturation 99%, temperature 97.8°F
* Physical exam: Limited active and passive range of motion of the right shoulder, tenderness at the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints, good hand grip, neurovascular exam of right arm shows capillary refill less than 3 seconds, sensation intact
* Imaging: Shoulder X-ray showed no fracture

A (Assessment):

* Right shoulder pain: rotator cuff tendinopathy
* Bilateral foot soreness: No diagnosis explicitly stated

P (Plan):

* For right shoulder pain: Order MRI, refer to physical therapy for 6–8 weeks, continue Tylenol, consider steroid injection if no improvement
* For bilateral foot soreness: Recommend soaking feet in Epsom salts, elevate and ice as needed
* Follow-up as needed; no additional medications prescribed at this time

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Hypertension and palpitations
* History of present illness: Recently experienced high blood pressure and palpitations in March, possibly related to panic attack after consuming coffee and skipping breakfast; reports using new primary care medication for hypertension; blood pressure monitoring at home shows readings around 146-155 mmHg.
* Past medical history: Hypertension
* Family history: High blood pressure (hypertensive family)
* Social history: Plays treadmill walking, reports good salt intake control, avoiding excessive salt

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific measurements provided during exam
* Physical exam: Heart and lungs normal, no tenderness or painful areas on palpation, ankles and feet examined for swelling with none observed
* Test results: Thyroid profile from March 1, 2021, not explicitly detailed here; potassium 4.0 mmol/L (last week), no repeat testing recent

A (Assessment):

* Resistant hypertension, on three medications (benicar hct, amlodipine, and maxed out regimen)
* No other explicit diagnoses or suspected conditions noted

P (Plan):

* Initiate spironolactone to target possible hyperaldosterone-driven resistant hypertension, monitor potassium and sodium levels with blood tests in 2 weeks
* Continue current medications (benicar hct and amlodipine)
* Advise maintaining low salt diet (target <2000 mg/day), increase potassium intake, and regular exercise (walking)
* Educate on medication side effects: electrolyte disturbances, dehydration, gynecomastia, dizziness
* Schedule follow-up in 2 weeks to assess blood pressure and labs
* If blood pressure remains uncontrolled, refer to resistant hypertension clinic for further evaluation and potential procedures such as renal denervation

[doctor] for assessment and plan , perioral dermatitis , rosacea including ocular rosacea and copy and paste her patient instructions . i recommend that she gently wash her eyelids once a day with gentle cleansers such as vanicream , also use bruder mask as needed .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Persistent erythematous papules on bilateral medial cheeks with slight redness around and underneath nostrils
* History of present illness: Rash has improved but not completely resolved; plateaued after switching from twice daily to once daily doxycycline; patient reports feeling good after topical treatments; has been using doxycycline, sulfacetamide wash, and metrocream
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Fitzpatrick skin type IV; faint erythematous papules on bilateral medial cheeks; mild redness around and underneath nostrils; no dryness or skin thinning noted on examination
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Perioral dermatitis
* Rosacea including ocular rosacea

P (Plan):

* Continue using face wash (Vanicream or petroleum jelly for moisturizing)
* Continue topical metrocream (calcineurin inhibitor) applied twice daily until rash resolves, then once daily for one week
* Increase doxycycline to twice a day until rash resolves, then once a day for one additional week
* Stop doxycycline after completing the course or if rash resolves sooner; continue use of face wash and metrocream for maintenance
* Discontinue elidel cream and clindamycin from medication list
* Use gentle eyelid cleansers daily for ocular rosacea
* Follow up in 4 weeks
* Avoid new skincare products or anti-aging treatments; contact provider before trying any new products

transcription: [doctor] next patient is grace ross , date of birth 8/23/1997 . miss ross is a new patient . she is here today for a full spectrum std testing . the patient states that she is having symptoms of discomfort , a change in discharge , and odor in her vaginal region . she says that the right side of her vagina is starting to become painful . she denies any fevers or chills . she reports that she recently learned , her partner has been in sexual encounters with other people and she wants to be evaluated for all stds . hello mrs. ross , i'm dr. diaz , it's good to meet you . [doctor] yeah , i'm sorry to hear that . of course , we can do that today . well , let's see , how do you feel ? do you have any symptoms ? [patient] well i started noticing some weird discharge last week . [doctor] mm-hmm . [patient] it smells different , it's not the same color or consistency as usual later . [doctor] right right .. [patient] that part did n't even face me until i noticed that the right side of my vagina was hurting . [doctor] mm-hmm . [patient] just sore you know but . that has n't gone away . [doctor] yep . no , that does sound like a cause for concern . how long have you been with him ? [patient] hmmm we've been dating for 3 years . [doctor] mm-hmm . [patient] as far as i can . figure he started cheating on me i think about 3 months ago . [doctor] uh uh okay do you , have you ever had an irregular pap smear ? [patient] well yeah , i did , but it was back whenever i was 20 or so , it has n't and i have n't had one since . [doctor] okay and when was your last pap smear ? [patient] about 6 months ago , it came back normal though . [doctor] okay good okay well let's see , let's take a look at you and then we'll get some samples for std testing okay ? alright . you will hear me talk through your exam so that i can get it all documented . use my general physical exam template . pelvic exam demonstrates no external lesions , normal labia , majora and labia , minora , normal physiological discharge with normal color and smell . miss ross , i'm going to touch you now . you will feel my fingers in the speculum in your vagina . you'll feel some pressure now . cervix is normal . vaginal wall is normal . no cervical motion tenderness and no adnexal tenderness or masses noted . swabs were done for std testing . okay miss ross , everything looks good from a visual standpoint . i'm going to send off std testing for gonorrhea , chlamydia , trichomonas , and i will have you give some blood for syphilis , hiv , and hepatitis c. some of these tests will take longer than others . we will call you if we see anything , but if you have n't heard anything , you can call us in 3 days for results . [patient] okay . sounds good . thank you so much . [doctor] of course , my pleasure and if everything is normal , i'll see you again at your next annual checkup . assessment is screening for std plan discussed with patient and please add that she is high risk due to an abnormal pap smear in the past and the recent discovery of her sexual partner having multiple partners for some period of time . end of recording .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Discomfort, change in discharge, and odor in vaginal region
* History of present illness: Recently noticed abnormal discharge with different smell, color, and consistency, started last week; right side of vagina became painful, persistent soreness; no fevers or chills reported
* Past medical history: Irregular pap smear in the past, last pap smear 6 months ago with normal results
* Social history: Dating for 3 years; partner has been unfaithful for approximately 3 months
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Pelvic exam demonstrated no external lesions, normal labia majora and minora, normal physiological discharge with normal color and smell; cervix normal; vaginal wall normal; no cervical motion tenderness, no adnexal tenderness or masses observed

A (Assessment):

* Screening for sexually transmitted diseases
* High risk due to previous abnormal pap smear and partner’s multiple partners

P (Plan):

* Swabs taken for gonorrhea, chlamydia, trichomonas
* Blood tests ordered for syphilis, HIV, hepatitis C
* Patient advised to call in 3 days if no contact regarding test results
* Follow-up planned at next annual checkup if test results are normal

[doctor] and are you also taking the full dose of the hydrochlorothiazide ? do you have any chest tightness or pressure or any shortness of breath ? [patient] yeah , i'm taking the full dose of that medicine too and no , none of those symptoms . [doctor] okay . anything else i should be aware of or that we should be checking ? [patient] hmmm no . [doctor] okay . good . are you doing the blood pressure checks at home ? [patient] yes , yes , i am . [doctor] okay , good . what kind of numbers are you seeing ? [patient] well , in the morning i'm seeing lower numbers than in the evening where i run anywhere from like 130-145 or 150/95-100 on the bottom . [doctor] okay . [patient] but in the evenings if i sit there for a while and then take it , it goes down . kind of like when i come here , it's always high , but then it goes down . in the mornings , it's generally more normal where it's supposed to be . [doctor] uh uh . [patient] hmmm also i'm taking my medicine in the morning when i get up instead of in the evening . [doctor] yeah so it sounds like we are not too far out of where we want to be . [patient] right . [doctor] mm-hmm . okay . well , let me get a listen to your heart , go ahead and hop up here . [patient] okay . [doctor] use my general exam template . alright , go ahead and take some deep breaths . okay , good . any fever , cough , shortness of breath , or sore throat ? no . any recent travel or contact or exposure to the coronavirus ? [patient] nope . [doctor] have you received your corona virus vaccine ? [patient] yes on february 9 . [doctor] okay great alright well i'm just going to look at your ankles and feet , i'm looking for any signs of swelling . [patient] okay . [doctor] alright , well everything looks good . you can go ahead and sit up miss taylor . alright , so the good news is everything is looking okay . i think we both agree if you were able to stop drinking . your blood pressure would cease to be an issue for you . yeah , i agree with that . they will let us discuss the potential medicine to help you with that . what it does is it blocks some of the brain receptors that alcohol stimulates and it tricks the brain into thinking it does not need alcohol thereby cutting down the urges . [patient] the urge to drink or they constant thinking about it ? [doctor] it actually will help with both . [patient] okay , so is it like a one time thing ? [doctor] generally the shot is given about once a month , it can also be given as a daily pill but the shot does tend to work a bit better . [patient] yeah , i have taken things like this in the past and if it is a pill , i know i wo n't take it . with the shot , it's not like you can undoke it . [doctor] yeah , that's true and the shot has been shown to work , it is more just a matter of getting you in to get your shot a month later with the nurse . [patient] yeah , sure , sure . [doctor] okay , so it's called naltrexone . i think the other name might be vivitrol . like i said , the research on it is pretty good . [patient] i think i may have taken the naltrexone before . [doctor] okay , yeah , maybe you have . [patient] yeah , if it was available in a pill form , then i'm almost certain i tried it before . [doctor] okay . if this sounds good though , we can go ahead and get you started with the shot . i am looking and it looks like we have you coming back in on may 17 for your first shot . does that sound good ? [patient] yeah , yeah , that sounds great . are there any possible side effects ? [doctor] yeah , some people will experience some nausea , headache , dizziness , anxiety , anxiety , tiredness and trouble sleeping but generally the side effects are mild and should go away within a few days . [patient] okay . [doctor] then we can schedule you for a follow-up in june to see how you're doing . [patient] alright , that sounds good . [doctor] alright , great , well otherwise , stay with your current medicines , keep checking your blood pressure , and let's see if we can stop the alcohol for good . let us know if you have any questions or any issues come up after you received the first dose . [patient] alright , sounds good . thank you . [doctor] you're welcome . have a good rest of your day . [patient] you too . [doctor] miss taylor is drinking alcohol 4 to 5 days/week to excess . no tobacco , no substance abuse . skin is moist . good trigger . on exam , she is alert , pleasant , in no acute distress . she is not diabetic . there is no tremor . no cva tenderness . chest clear to percussion in a suscultation . unlabored breathing . cardiac rhythm regular . no murmur , no gallop . jv flat with a head at 90 degrees . she does not appear anxious , agitated , or depressed . my impression , alcohol use disorder . she would like to start naltrexone which we have previously discussed . she will take the injectable form and start on may 17 . we reviewed side effects and risks , the potential benefit of alcohol cessation would be highly beneficial to her for many reasons . hypertension , she is taking lisinopril 10 mg daily and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily . quite possibly her blood pressure will improve completely with cessation of alcohol . her target bp is 130-140/70-80 . i will see her back week of june 14 which is likely around the time of her second naltrexone injection . i recommend upgrading influenza vaccination and shingrix . # 2 , she did defer this .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for hypertension and alcohol use disorder
* History of present illness: Patient reports drinking alcohol 4-5 times a week to excess; has been abstinent for a couple of days since Monday; expresses interest in starting medication (naltrexone) for alcohol cessation
* Past medical history: Hypertension, mild hypercholesterolemia, alcohol use disorder
* Social history: Significant alcohol use disorder, no tobacco or substance abuse
* Family history: No information provided
* Additional information: Patient reports taking her blood pressure medications, half of lisinopril and full dose of hydrochlorothiazide; notes blood pressure readings are generally lower in the morning and higher in the evening; monitors blood pressure at home

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific blood pressure measured at the visit; physical exam: Alert, pleasant, in no acute distress; skin moist
* Physical exam: No tremor, no CVA tenderness, lungs clear to percussion and auscultation, unlabored breathing, cardiac rhythm regular with no murmur or gallop, JVP flat with head at 90 degrees; no signs of anxiety, agitation, or depression
* Laboratory/other: No lab results provided; CMP and CBC unremarkable; previous labs include normal CMP and CBC

A (Assessment):

* Alcohol use disorder
* Hypertension, controlled but likely to improve with alcohol cessation

P (Plan):

* Initiate naltrexone injection (Vivitrol) on May 17 to aid alcohol cessation, with follow-up in June for second dose
* Educated patient on side effects of naltrexone: nausea, headache, dizziness, anxiety, tiredness, trouble sleeping (generally mild and temporary)
* Continue current antihypertensive medications: lisinopril 10 mg daily and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily
* Blood pressure target: 130-140/70-80 mmHg
* Schedule follow-up around week of June 14
* Recommend upgrading influenza and Shingrix vaccinations (patient deferred)
* Emphasized benefits of alcohol cessation for blood pressure control and overall health

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Functional abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
* History of present illness: Reported flare-ups of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, worsened by spicy foods, alcohol, and certain foods eaten out, with symptoms occurring both during weekdays and weekends. Noted increased frequency of bowel movements (2-3 times daily), with formed stools and episodes of diarrhea after eating out or drinking alcohol. Cramping and sharp pains persist. Patient reports avoiding heavy foods but recently consumed fried chicken without significant issues.
* Past medical history: IBS diagnosed in August 2019, previously treated with Bentyl.
* Social history: Drinks tequila or dark liquor, occasionally martinis; eats pasta and fried chicken; experiences bloating and discomfort related to diet and alcohol intake.
* No information provided regarding past medical history or other social/family history beyond IBS.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided.
* Physical exam: Patient is alert, cooperative, and appears stated age. Abdomen soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly. Lung auscultation normal, heart with regular rate and rhythm.
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided; bowel sounds normal.

A (Assessment):

* Irritable bowel syndrome with functional abdominal pain, aggravated by dietary and lifestyle factors (spicy foods, alcohol, fatty foods, portion sizes).

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Citrucel (fiber supplement): use tablet form twice daily for regularity.
* Prescribe Bentyl 20 mg: take 1 tablet 30-45 minutes before leaving home and before eating out, up to four times daily; refill provided.
* Advise avoidance of greasy, fatty, and sugary foods; reduce alcohol intake.
* Continue Zofran as needed for nausea, with instructions to drink plenty of water.
* Discussed addition of long-term neuromodulator (Elavil 25 mg at bedtime) to reduce symptoms and flare-ups, taking into consideration potential side effects like sleepiness.
* Follow-up in approximately 1 month via MyChart email to assess response, side effects, or need for medication adjustment.

transcription: [doctor] okay , so our next patient is christopher watson , date of birth 4/12/1934 . mr . watson is a 86-year-old male who returns in follow-up for adult hydrocephalus . this is his first visit since undergoing shunt shunt surgery , excuse me , in august 1 , 2020 . i have followed mr . watson since may 2020 when he first presented with 8 to 10 years of progressive gait impairment , cognitive impairment , and decreased bladder control , we established a diagnosis of adult hydrocephalus with a spinal catheter protocol in june 2020 and he underwent shunt shunt surgery on august 1 , 2020 . medtronic strata programmical shunt in the ventriculoperitoneal configuration was programmed at a level of 2.0 was placed . good morning mr . watson , who is the nice lady you have with you today ? [patient] hi document this is my daughter theresa , she is the one who helps me keep things straight . [doctor] mr . watson , have you been sick or been hospitalized since your shunt shunt surgery 3 months ago ? [patient] not that i recall . no , he has n't . he has been doing much better . [doctor] good . i'm glad to hear that . before surgery , you were having some progressive problems that affected your walking , thinking , and bladder control . are these symptoms better , worse , or unchanged ? his walking has improved . he is now able to walk to the dining room just fine but he could not do that before surgery . he still has times where i have to help him . [patient] that's impressive mr . watson ? [doctor] yeah , i guess . now his bladder control did improve some after surgery but now seems to have leveled out , so he is wearing diapers . [patient] no issues with sores from wearing the diaper and any decreased or painful urination ? [doctor] no , not at all . and how about cognition ? [patient] i think i'm better . i do n't feel lost when talking to someone anymore . [doctor] dan and i both think my sister , hannah summarized it best . she said i feel like i can have a normal conversation with him again . not so wonderful . now , have you had any headaches or pain where the shunt is ? [patient] no , has n't bothered me 1 bit . [doctor] okay and any pain in your belly at all ? [patient] ca n't say that i have . [doctor] okay . sounds like you have been improving . alrighty , mr . watson , i'm gon na step out of the room while my resident comes in to do a few tests for me . is that alright ? [patient] sounds good . [doctor] okay . i'm going to go out and review the ct scan you had last month and then we will chat about it when i come in . alrighty mr . watson , so you definitely have made some improvements since the shunt surgery . now on ct scan though , i do believe i see a tiny bit of blood fluid collection in the right parietal region . [patient] now i do n't believe that that's causing any symptoms and i , it actually was n't documented by the radiologist when he read the ct scan . [doctor] what does that mean ? just that i would like to leave the shunt set for another 2 to 3 months before we go in changing it . like i said , if you're not having any headaches or pain and you have improved , so that's all good for me . so really there is , there is nothing to worry about . alright , so i'll come back in 3 months . [patient] yep , that's right . [doctor] i do have a question for you though . [patient] yeah , of course . [doctor] do you think i will be able to drive again ? man , mr . watson , i knew you were gon na ask me that one . i think at this point , it's unlikely that your movement , speed will improve to the level that would be needed for you to pass the driver's safety evaluation . now , i will say that i do occasionally have patients who surprise me . by improving over a 9 to 12-month range and that , that definitely could be you , you could definitely pass it at that point . so if you improve and we can continue to talk about that , then you know i think it could be possible , and i would be happy to recommend it . now , you could definitely also enroll in a driver's safety program without my recommendation , so you could kind of do that preemptively and then we could continue to watch for your improvement as we go . [patient] okay . i kinda figured that anyway but i just thought i'd ask i do n't like to burn anyone when i just need to run to the store , but i also know that i need to be safe . [doctor] yeah , your safety is our # 1 priority and you know i'm sure your daughters do n't mind as much , right ? they wan na keep you here and have you safe , but i overall am very pleased with how much you have improved . [patient] and so i'm sure when we talked again in 3 months , we'll continue to be on that upper trajectory of improvement . [doctor] i sure hope so don . [patient] we really appreciate all that you've done . do we make the appointment upfront ? [doctor] yeah , that would be great . the girls upfront will take care of you and get you settled for 3 months from now and you both take care , alright ? [patient] thanks . [doctor] thank you . hmmm alrighty so ros is constitutional significant for impaired ability to carry out daily functions negative for fever or unintentional weight loss . gu is significant for urinary incontinence and wearing a diaper . negative for genital sores , decreased or painful output . neurological significant for continued walking impairment , and cognitive impairment . negative for headaches , recent falls , or hallucinations . psychiatric is negative for depression , excessive worrying , or mood swings . let's go ahead and use the short pe , vitals let's see blood pressure is 124/80 , heart rate 64 , respirations 18 , weight 174 pounds and pain is 0 out of 10 . mr . watson is a pleasant and cooperative man who is able to converse easily through though his daughter does add some details . the shunt site was clean , dry , and intact with a confirmed setting of two . [patient] he was tested for recent remote memory , attention span and concentration and fund of knowledge . he scored a 26 out of 30 on the mmse when tested with spelling and 25 out of 30 when tested with calculations . [doctor] of note , he was able to get two of the three memory words with cueing and the third with multiple choice . this was a slight improvement over his initial score of 23 out of 30 with calculations and 24 out of 30 with spelling . and at the time he was unable in the previous testing , excuse me , he was unable to remember any memory words and cueing without and only one with multiple choice . gait tested using the tinetti assessment tool . he was tested without an assistive device and received a gait score of 6-8 out of 12 and a balance score of 12 out of 16 for a total score of 18-20 out of 28 . this is slightly improved from his initial score of 15-17 out of 28 . cranial nerves , pupils are equal . eoms are intact . face symmetric . no dysarthria . motor normal for bulk and strength , coordination slow from no finger-to-nose . of note , the ct ct scan from the head of 10/15/2020 shows a frontal hornstan at the level of . firm and of menroma of 4.6 cm with a third ventricular contour that is flat with a span of 10 mm . by my reading , there is a tiny amount of blood in the right frontal region with a tiny subdermal collection . this was not noticed or noted by the radiologist who stated in any extra axial fluid collections . there is also substantial small vessel ischemic change . diagnosis adult hydrocephalus , gait impairment , urinary incontinence , and urgency , and cognitive impairment .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for adult hydrocephalus
* History of present illness: Patient reports improved gait, some improvement in bladder control, and better cognition since shunt surgery; no headaches, pain, or visual changes; no recent hospitalizations; cognitive and gait improvements noted by patient and daughter
* Past medical history: Adult hydrocephalus diagnosed 8-10 years ago, shunt surgery on August 1, 2020
* Social history: No additional information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 124/80 mmHg, heart rate 64/min, respirations 18/min, weight 174 pounds, pain 0/10
* Physical exam: Shunt site clean, dry, and intact, programmed at level 2.0; gait score 6-8/12, balance score 12/16, total 18-20/28, slight improvement from initial; cranial nerves: pupils equal, extraocular movements intact, face symmetric, no dysarthria; motor: normal bulk and strength; coordination slow; cognitive testing: MMSE 26/30 (spelling), 25/30 (calculations), slight improvement from previous scores; MMSE memory words: 2/3 with cueing, 1/3 with multiple choice.
* Test results: Gait and balance assessments performed; MMSE with slight improvements; CT scan shows tiny blood fluid collection in right parietal region (not noted by radiologist), no symptoms related to this; CT head from 10/15/2020 shows frontal horn stenosis, 4.6 cm, with flat third ventricular contour (span 10 mm), small vessel ischemic change

A (Assessment):

* Adult hydrocephalus
* Gait impairment
* Urinary incontinence and urgency
* Cognitive impairment
* No explicit suspected or confirmed new diagnoses

P (Plan):

* Continue current shunt setting at level 2.0, monitor for symptoms
* Plan to leave the shunt in place for 2-3 months before any adjustment
* Follow-up in 3 months for reassessment
* Review upcoming CT scan; no immediate intervention needed unless symptoms develop
* Educate patient and daughter on signs of shunt malfunction or infection
* No additional medications or interventions specified
* Discussed driving safety; unlikely to pass safety evaluation at present, but possibility of future improvement; consider enrolling in driver safety program
* Appointment scheduled in 3 months

[doctor] okay . range of motion slightly diminished . i'm going to press here , okay ? and how about here ? hmmm i see some pitting around the knee and ankle . normal capillary refill in the toes . does any of this area hurt ? [patient] just like an old bruise . [doctor] so i can feel that the knee is hot and that means there is something going on like some inflammation so we can give you another steroid injection for that . i also want to get an x-ray of that knee so we can see where all the swelling is coming from . yeah sounds good to me . [patient] okay and do we set up physical therapy for you last time you were here ? [doctor] no i was doing some years ago , but that was the other knee . okay so i think we will set that up for you now . we will also do an x-ray on that knee i can send you for a physical therapy and if nothing is helping then we really might need to get a surgery consult to see what we can do with that knee . [patient] okay . sounds like a plan . [patient] i mean i , i mean i love my salty snacks . [patient] and have you talked to your primary care doctor about this at all ? no , i think i would just come here first . okay . so i think try some of those things out first and if it does n't help , definitely make an appointment with them . [doctor] also as you know xeljanz is a high risk medication , so we need to check your cmp levels every couple of months so this time your levels are good but you make sure to make an appointment for the blood work for next time . [patient] alright i can do that . thank you so much doc . [doctor] yes of course well let me go ahead and get supplies and we'll get to work on your knee . fluid aspiration and steroid injection procedure . the risks , benefits , and alternatives were explained . the risks of steroid injection were explained including but not limited to hypopigmentation , soft tissue atrophy , tendon ruptures and transient hyperglycemia among others . verbal consent was obtained . the right knee was accessed through the lateral approach with 3 ml of initially clear fluid , then blood . blood tinged fluid . then the right knee was prepped in a standard fashion . the right knee was injected with 80 mg of triamcin alone . and 1 ml of lidocaine . the procedure was tolerated well with no complications . post procedure instructions were given . patient will follow up with his pcp . thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Swelling and pain in the right knee
* History of present illness: Swelling in the right knee has persisted for about 2 months since last steroid injection, with pain typically around 6/10, now about 3/10; swelling has spread to the entire leg, and the knee remains painful; worse after sitting for a while with difficulty getting up, stiffness noted; swelling has not responded fully to compression socks
* Past medical history: Rheumatoid arthritis; recent use of Xeljanz (11 mg daily), Celebrex (200 mg daily)
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Right knee shows swelling with pitting edema around the knee and ankle, temperature increased indicating inflammation, limited range of motion, slight pain upon pressure, normal capillary refill in toes, old bruise-like appearance around knee and ankle
* Test results: No imaging or lab results available at this visit

A (Assessment):

* Rheumatoid arthritis flare with localized inflammation in the right knee, suspected due to swelling and warmth
* Edema in the leg likely related to swelling and inflammation

P (Plan):

* Perform fluid aspiration of the right knee; initially obtained 3 ml of clear, then blood-tinged fluid
* Administer intra-articular steroid injection with 80 mg of triamcinolone and 1 ml of lidocaine following procedure
* Arrange for right knee X-ray to assess cause of swelling
* Set up physical therapy for the right knee
* Advise reducing salt intake and elevating legs to manage leg edema
* Educate on risks of steroid injection, obtain verbal consent
* Schedule follow-up with primary care physician for blood work (CMP levels) every 2 months due to Xeljanz therapy
* Encourage patient to seek further medical evaluation if swelling persists or worsens

SOAP:

* Vascular disease in legs
* Stable cataract status post-surgery
* Chronic smoking
* No evidence of acute respiratory infection or other new conditions

P (Plan):

* Increase glimepiride to 4 mg twice daily, monitor for hypoglycemia
* Continue metformin
* Recheck blood work including kidney function and blood glucose
* Continue current antihypertensive regimen: metoprolol 50 mg daily, lisinopril with hydrochlorothiazide 20/25 mg daily, amlodipine 10 mg daily
* Continue atorvastatin for cholesterol management
* Encourage smoking cessation; offer counseling options
* Advise feet moisturization and monitor for worsening peripheral neuropathy
* Reassess blood pressure and foot sensation at follow-up
* Follow-up visit in 4 months

transcription: [doctor] michelle king , date of birth 1/5/1986 , mrn q227631 . new patient visit for acid reflux . past medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies . [doctor] yeah . so i mean i , right now i take 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day . some days it is fine , but others are just really bad . what do you feel ? [patient] it feels like burning . [doctor] in your chest ? [patient] yes , in my chest and also in my throat . [patient] no , not really . [doctor] nausea or vomiting , changes in bowel movements ? [patient] no . [doctor] constipation , diarrhea , rectal bleeding ? [patient] nope . [doctor] okay . very good . and how long have you had this problem ? [patient] i've had acid reflux since i was around 12 , but it has gotten worse over the past few years . [doctor] okay and how long have you been on the omeprazole ? [patient] on the way it is now i think about a year . [doctor] okay . do you find that it's done anything for you in the past ? i mean i can tell it's helped because some days i'll be fine and then some days i eat something and it feels terrible . are there anything that make your symptoms worse that you can pinpoint like food choices or stress ? sure , probably stress and food choices sometimes . okay . what things bother you ? [patient] spicy foods so i try not to eat them too often but sometimes even drinking a soda can cause it . we do know that caffeine and caffeinated beverages will do that even sodas even just the carbonation can cause that . how about tomato based products or citrus products ? [doctor] yeah sometimes but i still eat them . okay . it's reassuring that you are n't having any difficulty swallowing though . how has your weight been ? pretty stable ? [patient] i would say pretty stable although i have n't had much of an appetite for the past 2 months . i have been under a lot of work stress . [doctor] what do you do for work ? [patient] i'm a paralegal . [doctor] okay and any family history of gi issues ? [patient] my grandmother had esophageal cancer . [doctor] on your mom or dad's side ? [patient] mom's side and my mom had some issues like acid reflux and she was taking some medication that coats the lining of your stomach . [doctor] okay . have you ever had an upper endoscopy ? [patient] i think maybe when i was younger . [doctor] but not in the last 10 years ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you ever tried any medication other than omeprazole ? [patient] at one point i was on omeprazole and ranitidine , it did help . [doctor] but other than that , those are the only medications i have taken . [patient] okay . have a seat here and let me listen to your heart and lungs and then we can talk about a plan for you . [doctor] okay . so normal physical exam per my new patient template except for a well-healed abdominal surgical scar is noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ? i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around 1 month old . gotcha , okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . [patient] and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole 40 mg twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ? [doctor] yes . and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated beverages , citrus , and tomato based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . [patient] so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd even though you're taking the ppi . [doctor] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods . [patient] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms . [doctor] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me . so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium . that's fine with me , i'm definitely open to trying whatever . perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 mg twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd or upper endoscopy to look for potential causes of the gerd . we sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth down your throat , through your stomach and end in the small intestines . [patient] we would look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything . [doctor] okay . can i schedule that today ? yeah , you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary stress and medication changes . how does all of that sound ? [patient] that sounds good . [doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the check out desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment . please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Acid reflux with episodes of heartburn
* History of present illness: Burning sensation in chest and throat, worse despite taking 40 mg omeprazole twice daily, triggered by spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, tomato-based foods, stress, and anxiety; symptoms have been worsening over few years, with poor control over past year
* Past medical history: Anxiety, seasonal allergies, prior abdominal surgery as a baby for intestinal twisting
* Family history: Grandmother with esophageal cancer on mother’s side
* Social history: Worked as a paralegal, reports recent decreased appetite over past 2 months due to stress
* No information provided regarding smoking, alcohol, or other substance use

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Normal findings except for a well-healed abdominal surgical scar noted; no signs of dysphagia, no unintentional weight loss
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results available at this time

A (Assessment):

* GERD with poorly controlled symptoms despite current medication
* Underlying functional etiology suspected
* Family history of esophageal cancer is noted
* No evidence of dysphagia or weight loss observed

P (Plan):

* Dietary modifications: Avoid spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, and tomato-based products
* Stress management strategies to address triggers
* Medication: Switch from omeprazole to Nexium 40 mg twice daily with prescription to be sent to pharmacy
* Diagnostic procedure: Schedule upper endoscopy (EGD) to evaluate for ulcers, precancerous or cancerous changes; procedure entails sedation, small camera passing through mouth to stomach and possibly small intestines, with biopsies if indicated
* Follow-up: Return to clinic after EGD for discussion of results and further management
* Additional considerations: If symptoms persist despite trial of Nexium and normal EGD, consider trial of Protonix and obtain pH impedance study to differentiate between acid reflux and hypersensitivity or functional GERD

* Chief complaint: Abnormal renal ultrasound with atrophic right kidney and ongoing abdominal pain
* History of present illness: Presents with a history of right-sided abdominal pain, burning sensation when eating, episodes of vomiting, diagnosed with atrophic right kidney, cysts on kidney and ovaries, history of severe infection in childhood, recent improvement in overall condition but persistent stomach discomfort
* Past medical history: Small right kidney, suspected past kidney infection, severe childhood infections (hospitalized multiple times at age 4), kidney problems possibly present since childhood, no current medication other than pepcid and allergy medication
* Family history: Father had kidney transplant and died of massive heart attack at 47, aunt (great aunt) had end-stage renal disease, family history of kidney disease, mother had breast cancer
* Social history: Active in softball and interested in joining drill team, maintains a healthy diet, drinks at least 2 liters of water daily

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Well-appearing, alert and oriented, sitting comfortably, lungs and heart sounds normal, no signs of acute distress, physical exam within normal limits
* Test results: No current lab or imaging results provided, but ultrasound shows a smaller right kidney and the left kidney is likely compensating; past records include findings of cysts, atrophic kidney, end-stage renal disease, chronic kidney disease stage V, diabetes, hypertension; genetic testing did not reveal clinically significant mutations; recent renal ultrasound shows atrophic right kidney, size monitoring recommended

A (Assessment):

* Abnormal renal ultrasound with atrophic right kidney
* Potential history of kidney infection and developmental kidney issues
* Family history of kidney disease, including father with renal transplant
* No active signs of current renal failure; kidneys currently functioning within acceptable limits
* No signs of infection or hematuria noted currently
* Suspected chronic kidney disease, stage V, due to familial and past medical history

P (Plan):

* Monitor kidney size and function with annual ultrasound
* Repeat urinalysis to check for proteinuria and blood in urine
* Continue current medications: pepcid and allergy medication
* Recommend avoiding NSAIDs like ibuprofen; suggest using acetaminophen (Tylenol) if needed
* Hydration: at least 2 liters of water daily, especially during active sports to prevent dehydration
* Maintain a healthy diet and active lifestyle
* Schedule follow-up with primary care provider or adult nephrologist closer to home
* Educate patient and family about signs of worsening renal function and when to seek medical attention
* Review family history and previous medical records for ongoing management considerations

transcription: [doctor] patient mrn abc 123 . date of birth january 1 , 1960 . patient is a 60-year-old right handed male referred today for evaluation of numbness and tingling . hello mr. cook , how are you doing this morning ? [patient] hi dr. martinez , this weekend was a bit rough . i've had this numbness and tingling for a few weeks now . [doctor] so it's in both of your hands ? [patient] yes , ever since my car wreck last december when i broke them , well once they healed i mean i noticed it more , the tingling and the numbness , [doctor] and you still wear the splint only on the right wrist ? [patient] no , i also wear the left sometimes , the right is just worse but the splint helps . both have really gotten worse over the last month and i broke them my right wrist was definitely in worse shape . i've also been having some mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident and they told me it was a contusion . [doctor] and where would you say the tingling and numbness is ? [patient] on this side , it goes from here and here up to about here on the other side , it's from here to here . [doctor] i see . so on the right side you're pointing from the middle and ring finger all the way up the forearm and on the left the symptoms extend from the pinky and ring finger and is there any pain or just tingling and numbness ? it's mainly just sore , sometimes they throb but overall they feel weaker too especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens more when they hurt , but when it goes away , the tingling is dull . [patient] and when do you feel these symptoms ? well , really i guess just more so at night and they come and go throughout the day . [doctor] okay and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ? [patient] like feeling something , no , not that i can really think of though in general they maybe less sensitive than they should be but i can still feel they also gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should . [doctor] and are you still on the coreg for hypertension and the lexapro for anxiety ? [patient] yes , i'm still taking those . i had prediabetes too , but i got it under control by changing my diet . [doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , correct ? [patient] no . [doctor] ri thank you mr. cook okay first we'll go over your review of systems correct me if i'm wrong in any of this constitutional you have fatigue and weight gain gi you have excessive appetite and bloating eyes have floaters , cardiovascular shows shortness of breath and leg swelling , endocrine , you're always hungry , skin , you have some nailbed changes , dryness , and itching , musculoskeletal , you have gout and muscle pain , and the remainder of the review of systems is negative . [patient] yeah , that's all correct . [doctor] alright we are going to go ahead and do the neurologic examination . let's look at the right hand first . can you feel this ? [patient] yeah , but a little less on these two fingers . [doctor] sensation is normal except pinprick sensation diminished in the third and fourth fingers on the right and how about on the left ? [patient] yeah but these two are little less . [doctor] sensation is decreased in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left . okay , let's test your reflexes now . reflexes are 1+ and symmetric . 2+ knees , toes are downgoing bilaterally . alright , i'm going to tap on your right wrist . do you feel anything ? [patient] yeah , it feels like a zing of my wrist and something into my elbow too . [doctor] and how about the left side ? [patient] yeah , same on that side too . [doctor] tinel's sign positive at both wrists and both elbows . rest of exam is normal . alright so what i am seeing today is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome or potentially this could also be bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . however , your symptom presentation suggests bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome as the nerves in your wrist are aggravated by your past trauma . this is causing the pain and tingling you were describing to me . okay . so how we make it better ? first , i want to determine exactly where the nerve irritation is coming from . we will need to schedule you for a nerve test , which is called an emg test . they will measure the responsiveness of your nerves to truly pinpoint where you're having your issues . [patient] that sounds fine to me . [doctor] great . after the tests are complete , you can return here for a follow-up visit . if you're still having symptoms , we can consider a referral to our hand clinic possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release surgery . you could also refer , we could also refer you to an orthopedist for the same treatment . [patient] sounds good document . [doctor] alright keep wearing your splints and i will see you after those studies . [patient] thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):  
- Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in both hands for a few weeks  
- History of present illness: Symptoms began after a car wreck last December involving wrist fractures; worsening over the past month; sensations extend from the middle and ring fingers up the forearm on the right, and from the pinky and ring fingers on the left; symptoms are worse at night and fluctuate during the day; sensation is generally preserved but decreased in affected fingers; associated with soreness, throbbing, weakness, and mild neck stiffness; no loss of sensation but decreased sensitivity reported.  
- Past medical history: Prediabetes managed by diet, hypertension (on Coreg), anxiety (on Lexapro), gout, muscle pain, nailbed changes, dryness, itching.  
- Social history: No information provided.  
- Family history: No information provided.

O (Objective):  
- Vital signs: No information provided.  
- Physical exam: Sensory examination shows decreased pinprick sensation in the third and fourth fingers on the right, and in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left; reflexes 1+ and symmetric; Tinel's sign positive at both wrists and elbows; rest of exam normal.  
- Test results: No laboratory or imaging results available at this time.

A (Assessment):  
- Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome suspected based on symptoms and positive Tinel’s sign.  
- Possible bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome as differential diagnosis.

P (Plan):  
- Schedule EMG test to identify the source of nerve irritation.  
- Follow-up consultation after test results.  
- Consider referral to hand clinic for possible injections or surgery if symptoms persist.  
- Continue wearing wrist splints.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Bilateral hand numbness and tingling
* History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in both hands for a few weeks, increasing over the past month since previous wrist fracture, worse at night and intermittently during the day, mostly from the middle and ring fingers up to the forearm on the right, and pinky and ring finger on the left. Occasional soreness and dull tingling, with weakness during use. No loss of sensation noted, but decreased sensitivity. Symptoms worsened after injury; tingling and soreness sometimes relieved by pain medication. No specific pain other than soreness; some throbbing.
* Past medical history: Chronic kidney disease, gout, hypertension, anxiety, GERD, prediabetes (under control with diet)
* Medications: Carvedilol 25 mg twice daily, Lexapro 10 mg daily, sulfa allergy (rash with sulfa drugs), nerve pain medication (unspecified)
* Allergies: Sulfa drugs (causes rash)
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Neuro: Sensations normal except diminished pinprick sensation in the third and fourth fingers on the right, and the fourth and fifth fingers on the left. Reflexes 1+ and symmetric. Knees and toes downgoing bilaterally. Tinel's sign positive at both wrists and elbows.
* Imaging/lab results: Reviewed CT brain without abnormalities, no metastatic disease, no acute intracranial abnormalities (dated 2/5/2021). No other test results provided.

A (Assessment):

* Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
* Question of bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Schedule EMG/NCV to evaluate nerve conduction
* If symptoms do not resolve, consider hand clinic referral for possible injections or carpal tunnel release surgery (can be pursued through current orthopedist)
* Advised patient to wear splints and return for follow-up EMG/NCV testing

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Fatigue, feverish sensations with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, sensation of cold, worsening anxiety and depression
* History of present illness: Persistent symptoms including fatigue, chills, dyspnea on exertion, wheezing, headaches, feeling cold easily, and increased anxiety and depression, ongoing for some time
* Past medical history: Iron deficiency anemia since age 13, hysterectomy in 1996; no recent colonoscopy (5-6 years ago), last colonoscopy was normal with no polyps; diagnosed with anemia in 2019
* Social history: Drinks alcohol once or twice a year, no recent use of iron or vitamin B12 supplements for a year, currently restarted iron (ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily) with vitamin C

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Heart and lungs auscultation normal, abdomen exam unremarkable with no tenderness
* Additional findings: No significant findings

A (Assessment):

* Iron deficiency anemia, longstanding, suspected secondary to gastrointestinal bleeding or malabsorption
* No other diagnoses explicitly mentioned or suspected

P (Plan):

* Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to investigate possible sources of bleeding or malabsorption
* Consider capsule endoscopy if initial results are inconclusive
* Continue iron therapy (ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily) with vitamin C (orange juice) for 8-12 weeks, then reassess blood work (CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, folate)
* Refer to hematologist for further evaluation and management of anemia
* Educate patient on bowel prep for procedures, advise to call if symptoms worsen
* Follow-up after procedures and hematology consultation
