transcription: [doctor] patient bruce ward , date of birth 5/21/1969 . please use my neuro consult template . this is a 52-year-old male with newly diagnosed pituitary lesion . [patient] the patient is seen in consultation at the request of dr. henry howard for possible surgical mr. ward presented to his primary care provider , dr . howard on 3/1/2021 complaining of worsening headaches over the past few months . he denied any trouble with headaches in the past . his past medical history is unremarkable . work-up for worsening headaches was initiated with brain mri and serology where pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered . i personally reviewed the labs dated 3/3/2021 including cbc , u and e's , coagulation , and crp all were normal . pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low tsh . all other results were normal . i personally reviewed pertinent radiology studies including mri of the brain with contrast from 3/4/2021 . [doctor] the mri reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm . the ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are are noted . hello mr. ward , nice to meet you . i'm dr. flores . [patient] hi doc , nice to meet you . [doctor] i was just reviewing your records from doctor howard and he has referred you because the work-up for headaches revealed a mass in your pituitary gland . [patient] i did review your mri images and . there . can you tell me about the issues you've been experiencing ? [doctor] yeah , sure , so i'm really getting fed up with these headaches . i've been trying my best to deal with them , but they have been going on for months now and i'm really struggling . where are the headaches located and how would you describe that pain ? [patient] located behind my eyes , it's like a dull nagging ache . [doctor] okay . was the onset gradual or sudden ? [patient] well this started about 3 months ago and they've been getting worse over time , at first it was like 3 out of 10 in severity and it just gradually worsened , now it's about 6 out of 10 in severity . the headaches do tend to be worse in the morning and feels like a dull ache behind the eyes . [doctor] they last a few hours at a time and nothing makes them better or worse . [patient] okay . can you tell me if the pain radiates or if you have any other symptoms specifically feeling sick , fever , rashes , neck stiffness , numbness , weakness , passing out ? no . i have n't been sick or felt sick . ca n't recall a fever or any kind of rash . no , no neck issues , no numbness , no tingling and i've never passed out in my life . but for some reason recently i seemed to be bumping the door frames . [doctor] okay , have you noticed any change in your vision or with your balance ? [patient] no , i do n't think so . my eyes were checked in the fall . [doctor] okay , let's see . do you have any other medical problems that you take medicine for ? [patient] no , i do n't have any medical problems and i do n't take any medicines . i tried tylenol a few times for the headaches , but it did n't work , so i stopped . [doctor] let's see . anyone in your family have any history of diseases ? [patient] i was adopted , so i really have no idea . [doctor] okay . what kind of work do you do and are you married ? [patient] i work as a computer programmer and i've been married for 25 years . we just bought a small house . [doctor] well that's nice . do you drink any alcohol , smoke , or use recreational drugs ? nope , i do n't do any of those and never have . [patient] okay . well , let me take a good look at you . now you hear me calling out some details as i perform the examination . these will be noted for me in your record and i will be happy to answer any questions you have once we are done . [doctor] sounds good document . [patient] alright the patient is alert , oriented to time , place , and person . affect is appropriate and speech is fluent . [doctor] cranial nerve examination is grossly intact . no focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities . visual acuity and eye movements are normal . pupils are equal and reactive . visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia . [patient] and color vision is normal . alright , mr. ward , i'm going to review these pictures from the mri with you . now this appears to be a benign pituitary adenoma , but there's no way to be sure without sending removed adenoma to pathology to make the diagnosis , which we will do . here you can see it's a well defined mass and it's pressing right here on what we call the optic chiasm and today when i was having you look at my fingers , you could n't see them off to the side . that's what we call bitemporal hemianopia and explains why you have been bumping into door frames . yeah i never noticed that i could n't see out of the side until you did that test and they closed my eye with both eyes really could n't tell . now because you're having this vision loss from the mask compressing the optic chiasm , the only option we have is to do surgery . okay , i understand . do you think i'll regain my vision ? [doctor] well , there is no guarantee , but it is a possibility . i'm gon na refer you to the eye doctor for a full exam and we will do what's called visual field test . [patient] this will knock out your peripheral vision or side vision prior to surgery and we can monitor after surgery to see if your vision is improving . [doctor] alright . and let's discuss the surgery a little more . we would do what's called a transsphenoidal approach to do the surgery . this is minimally invasive and we go to the sphenoid sinus . [patient] there are some risks i have to inform you of . risks of anesthesia including but not limited to the risk of heart attack , stroke , and death , risks of surgery include infection , need for further surgery , wound issues , such as spinal fluid , leak or infection , which may require a long prolonged hospitalization or additional procedure seizure , stroke , permanent numbness , weakness , difficulty speaking or even death . [doctor] well i guess we have to do it regardless . [patient] okay so i will have you see our surgery scheduler , deborah on the way out to get you set up . we will get this scheduled fairly quickly , so i do n't want you to be alarmed . she will also get you set up today or tomorrow to have the visual field test and you may not be able to see the eye doctor until after surgery but we have the presurgery , visual field test for comparison after surgery . [doctor] okay . i look forward to these headaches going away . i never thought it could be something like this going on . [patient] yeah . come this way , but that things lined up , please call if you think of any questions . [doctor] thanks doctor . [patient] diagnosis will be pituitary adenoma . mr . ward is a very pleasant 52-year-old male who has benign appearing pituitary adenoma incidentally discovered during work-up for worsening headaches . he is symptomatic with . [doctor] clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression therefore surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated . end of note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Worsening headaches over the past few months
* History of present illness: Headaches located behind the eyes, described as dull nagging ache, gradually worsening over approximately 3 months, severity now about 6/10, worse in the morning, lasting a few hours, no identified aggravating or relieving factors, no associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, visual changes (except recent visual field deficits), or neurological deficits
* Past medical history: No medical problems reported, unremarkable
* Social history: No alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use; employed as a computer programmer; married for 25 years; adopted, no family medical history
* No other relevant subjective symptoms reported

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Not provided
* Physical exam: Patient alert, oriented to time, place, person; affect appropriate; speech fluent; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal motor or sensory deficits in upper or lower extremities; visual acuity and eye movements normal; pupils equal and reactive; visual field testing indicates bitemporal hemianopia; color vision normal
* Laboratory tests: CBC, U&E, coagulation, CRP (all normal); pituitary hormone profile shows low TSH, others normal
* Imaging: MRI of brain with contrast (3/4/2021) reveals a pituitary lesion compressing the optic chiasm, well-defined mass, ventricles normal, no other abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression
* Bitemporal hemianopia, symptomatic from mass effect

P (Plan):

* Refer to eye specialist for full examination and visual field testing before surgery
* Discussed surgical removal via transsphenoidal approach, including risks (infection, need for further surgery, cerebrospinal fluid leak, seizure, stroke, numbness, weakness, difficulty speaking, death)
* Proceed with surgical intervention to decompress the pituitary gland
* Refer to surgery scheduler for appointment and preoperative evaluation
* Continue to monitor visual symptoms postoperatively to assess for potential improvement
* No additional medications or follow-up details provided

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left back pain
* History of present illness: Intermittent sharp and dull left back pain that moves and varies in intensity, started around the time of a routine visit to the primary care physician
* Additional symptoms: Increased water intake, wakening during the night to urinate more than usual, no fatigue or change in appetite, no pleuritic or systemic symptoms
* Past medical history: Recurrent strep throat (four episodes in five months), uncertain diagnosis of “fibroid”
* Social history: Occasionally bikes, no recent sports activity, no current participation in March Madness, school going well, good grades, works a job with no insurance, considering changing jobs
* Family history: Most siblings healthy, one brother smokes despite being told not to
* No recent sick contacts except general high prevalence of illness around

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Throat with no erythema, no tonsillar swelling, midline tonsils, no cervical lymphadenopathy, lungs clear with no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi, heart normal with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops, back tender to palpation on the left side, no tenderness on abdomen, no rebound or guarding

A (Assessment):

* No definitive diagnosis provided; suspicion of recurrent streptococcal pharyngitis possibly contributing to concern for glomerulonephritis, based on history and physical

P (Plan):

* Refer to ENT for evaluation of recurrent strep and consideration of tonsillectomy
* Order labs: lipid panel, urinalysis, CMP, CBC, vitamin D, TSH
* Encourage patient to have labs done as soon as possible, fasting required
* Provide note for time off from class and work due to tests and changing employment situation
* Follow-up in one week to review results; can be over phone if results are normal, otherwise in person for further discussion
* No immediate need for injection or vaccination today

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath, painful swallowing
* History of present illness: Reports shortness of breath over the weekend, unable to walk down the street without difficulty, has a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, experiences pain when swallowing, no fever, no phlegm, dry cough, difficulty taking in liquids due to pain
* Past medical history: Stage three non-small cell lung cancer, undergoing chemotherapy (cisplatin and etoposide), recent radiation therapy (45 gray), radiation pneumonitis diagnosis
* Social history: Takes dogs for daily walks, has a Doberman, supportive family (husband and daughter)
* Family history: No information provided
* Emotional state: Feels devastated by diagnosis, feels fortunate to have supportive family

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Normal
* Physical exam: 
  - Neck: No cervical or subclavicular lymphadenopathy
  - Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur
  - Lung: Faint bilateral crackles
  - Skin: Erythema on the anterior chest (left side) potentially due to radiation
  - Extremities: No lower extremity edema
* Test results: Chest X-ray indicates mild radiation pneumonitis

A (Assessment):

* Stage three non-small cell lung cancer
* Radiation pneumonitis
* Difficulty swallowing (odynophagia) related to radiation esophagitis

P (Plan):

* Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation dose (45 gray), plan for follow-up testing and potential tumor resection after treatment completion
* Prescribe prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days for radiation pneumonitis
* Prescribe lidocaine spray for sore throat and painful swallowing, to be used four times daily for symptomatic relief
* Encourage fluid intake with liquids like Ensure and milkshakes, monitor hydration
* Follow-up in two weeks to reassess condition and response to therapy

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sudden visual distortions and blurring of vision
* History of present illness: Decrease in vision when reading and perceiving straight lines as crooked; trouble adjusting to dim lights when in restaurants
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Smokes a pack of cigarettes daily, difficulties quitting; no other social history details provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes; right eye cornea clear, no MVI, cup-to-disc ratio normal; fundus of right eye shows retina attached 360 degrees, no tears or holes, RPE changes at fovea, drusen, subretinal fluid, exudates, hemorrhage; left eye cornea clear, no MVI, cup-to-disc ratio normal; fundus shows RPE changes at fovea, no hemorrhage or subretinal fluid, retina attached
* Diagnostic tests: OCT shows drusen deposit, RPE changes, subretinal fluid, choroidal neovascular membrane; fluorescein angiography reveals focal leakage consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration

A (Assessment):

* Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD)

P (Plan):

* Administer intravitreal injection of lucentis once a month to slow or stop visual decline; inform patient that disease may progress despite treatment; no questions from patient.

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left flank pain radiating to groin, persistent for two weeks
* History of present illness: Pain starts in right flank, radiates to groin, varies in intensity (1-4/10), episodic, influenced by activity and fluid intake, no accompanying hematuria or dysuria, no nausea or vomiting, no fever, sometimes radiated to testicle, no chills, intermittent pain, managed with ibuprofen
* Past medical history: Previous kidney stones, surgical interventions for kidney stones, passed stones naturally within about a week
* Family history: Multiple family members with kidney stones

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Slightly elevated blood pressure, otherwise normal
* Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender to palpation, CVA tenderness on right side
* Test results: CT scan shows a 0.5 cm stone in proximal right ureter, no hydronephrosis

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone (urolithiasis), size 0.5 cm, located in proximal right ureter, no evidence of obstruction or hydronephrosis, suspected based on clinical presentation and imaging

P (Plan):

* Continue pushing fluids to facilitate stone passage
* Prescribe tramadol 50 mg for acute pain management, with ibuprofen as breakthrough medication
* Instruct to continue use of urine strainer for stone capture
* Order BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to screen for infection
* Educate about possible need for lithotripsy if symptoms persist
* Follow-up in 1-2 weeks to reassess symptoms and stone status
* Nurse to deliver prescription for tramadol
* No additional questions from patient

SOAP:

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for chronic congestive heart failure with diastolic dysfunction, preoperative assessment for right knee replacement, overdue for colonoscopy
* History of present illness: Patient reports increasing dyspnea, weight loss of about 3-1/2 pounds since last visit in April, improved urinary urgency with oxybutynin, recent leg cramps relieved with pickle juice, no current leg or finger cramps, no heartburn symptoms, past anemia, and no recent issues with blood sugar; she reports no problems with her iron supplement and regular bathroom use

* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No family history of colon cancer

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Lungs: clear, no abnormal sounds noted
* Test results: Hemoglobin: normal, Potassium: 3.9, Creatinine: 0.7, BUN: 23 (slightly elevated), Magnesium: 1.7, Blood sugar (glucose): 169, last A1c: 5.5, EKG: to be repeated today, no x-ray or additional labs needed; Blood work: Hemoglobin normal, potassium stable, kidney function stable, magnesium slightly below desired range (~2), overall labs indicate tolerating torsemide well; BNP pending

A (Assessment):

* Chronic congestive heart failure with diastolic dysfunction, recent exacerbation, improved with medication adjustment
* Preoperative status for right knee replacement scheduled end of June; currently stable
* Overdue for screening colonoscopy; no family history of colon cancer
* No current anemia, controlled heartburn
* Blood glucose slightly elevated but not urgent; consider repeat A1c before surgery
* Slightly elevated BUN possibly indicating mild dehydration; stable kidney function
* Low magnesium level; plan to supplement

P (Plan):

* Continue current medications including torsemide, Lisinopril increased to 10 mg daily, monitor for side effects
* Repeat EKG today; consider repeating A1c prior to surgery
* Initiate magnesium supplementation twice daily to reach magnesium level ~2
* Discontinue clopidogrel one week before knee surgery; provide reminder and documentation
* Complete preoperative check-up within 2 weeks after surgery in early June
* Arrange for colonoscopy at County or Springfield within the next 30 days; inform patient it does not delay surgery
* No additional x-ray or labs needed at this time
* Follow-up as needed, and monitor BNP results when available

transcription: [doctor] patrick allen , date of birth 7/7/1977 . new patient visit . past medical history includes gerd , anxiety , depression , here for chronic abdominal pain , he had an abdominal ct on 1/23/2020 . impression is a normal ct of the abdomen . hello , are you mr. allen ? [patient] yes , i am . [doctor] hi , my name is dr. edwards , nice to meet you . [patient] nice to meet you . [doctor] welcome to the gi specialty clinic . [patient] thank you . [doctor] did you have any problems finding this ? [patient] no , i've been here with my sister once before . [doctor] good , so how can i help you today ? the referral i have is for abdominal pain and diarrhea . [patient] right so i've had been having this pain right here in my stomach like right around here . [doctor] so in the area of your mid abdomen just below the belly button ? [patient] correct . i've had the pain on and off for about 2 years . i finally went to the er and a a few months ago and they did a ct scan . [doctor] i saw that . [patient] yeah , they said they did n't really see anything on the scan . [doctor] yes , i agree , it looked normal . [patient] and the problem is i'm either constipated or have explosive diarrhea . [doctor] is the pain there all the time ? [patient] it's a nagging feeling and it just depends , sometimes it bothers me , sometimes it does n't . [doctor] has this been the case over the past 2 years as well ? [patient] more recently in the past couple of months at least with the constipation and diarrhea . [doctor] and before that , how were your bowel movements ? [patient] they were normal . [doctor] okay , so any blood in your stool ? [patient] nope . [doctor] do you feel like you have more constipation or diarrhea ? [patient] probably more constipation . [doctor] okay , so when you're constipated , do you not have a bowel movement or is the stool hard ? [patient] i usually do n't go , but when i do , it's hard . [doctor] and how often do you have a bowel movement when you are constipated ? [patient] about 3-4 times a week it's like when i need to go to the bathroom if i can massage it , it feels like it's moving some and i can eventually go . [doctor] okay and when you have a bowel movement , does the pain change ? [patient] yeah . it gets a little better . [doctor] and are you eating and drinking okay , any nausea or vomiting , heartburn or indigestion ? [patient] none of that . [doctor] okay , so tell me about the diarrhea . how often do you get it ? [patient] it kinda just depends on what i eat . i think i have a very sensitive stomach if i eat pasta with a creamy sauce i'm probably gon na have diarrhea . [doctor] okay and does it happen for multiple days in a row or is it just one time ? [patient] it's usually just one time and then it's over . [doctor] and how has your weight been , any fluctuation ? [patient] no , it's been pretty stable , although i could stand to lose about 25 pounds . [doctor] okay , and is there any family history of gi issues that you know of ? [patient] not that i can think of . well , actually my sister does have problems with her stomach too . she has irritable bowel syndrome and that is kind of what i always thought i had even though i have never been diagnosed with it . [doctor] okay and is there any family history of gi cancer or liver disease ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you ever had any surgeries on your abdomen ? [patient] i have never had any surgery . [doctor] okay , so your gallbladder , appendix , all of those are still intact ? [patient] yep . [doctor] and have you ever had a colonoscopy ? [patient] no . i thought that happened when you turned 50 . [doctor] well that's for colon cancer screening , but there are other reasons to have a colonoscopy like unexplained abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits . [patient] okay . [doctor] well , come have a seat here and lay back so i can examine you . [patient] okay . [doctor] i'm gon na start by listening to your belly with my stethoscope . [patient] okay . [doctor] and i hear bowel sounds in all four quadrants . [patient] what does that mean , is everything okay ? [doctor] it just means that i can hear little noises in all areas of your belly , which means your bowels are active and working . [patient] okay , good . [doctor] so now i'm going to push on your upper and lower abdomen , let me know if you have any pain . [patient] it hurts a little when you push right there on the left side near my belly button . [doctor] okay , i do feel stool in your lower colon which would coincide with constipation but i also feel a slight enlargement of your liver here on the upper right side . have you had any lab work done recently ? [patient] yes . i had a physical about 4 months ago and they i had blood drawn then . [doctor] okay and did your primary care physician say anything about the lab results ? [patient] he said i had some very slightly elevated liver enzymes but we would recheck them in about 6 months . [doctor] and do you remember what enzymes were elevated , alt , ast , alp ? [patient] he said the alt and the ast were elevated . [doctor] and do you take any medications either prescription or over the counter ? [patient] i take crestor and , and olmesartan daily and then tylenol for occasional , occasional pain . [doctor] and how frequently do you take the tylenol ? [patient] hardly ever , maybe once a month . [doctor] and do you consume alcohol ? [patient] yes , but only a couple of beers after working in the yard on saturdays . [doctor] okay and no previous history of heavy alcohol or drug use ? [patient] no . [doctor] and have you had any recent issues with excessive bruising or bleeding ? [patient] nope . [doctor] and how about any issues with your ankles or feet swelling ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay , i'm gon na take a look at your eyes and skin . i do n't see any jaundice . [patient] what would cause that ? [doctor] issues with your liver . let me take a quick listen to your heart and lungs . [patient] okay . [doctor] lungs are clear bilateral . heart sounds are normal . no murmurs , gallops , or rubs noted . [patient] that's good . [doctor] yes , the rest of your physical exam is normal other than what seems to be an increased stool burden in your colon and a slight hepatomegaly . [patient] what's that ? [doctor] increased stool burden means that there is a lot of stool sitting in your colon . [patient] and that's the constipation , right ? but what about the other thing ? [doctor] the hepatomegaly means the liver is enlarged . [patient] but you said mom was slightly enlarged . [doctor] correct . [patient] so what does that mean ? [doctor] well , let's talk about what we found and then some possible next steps if you're in agreement . [patient] okay . [doctor] so as i said , the hepatomegaly means your liver is enlarged . [patient] could that be why my stomach is hurting and i'm having issues with the constipation and diarrhea ? [doctor] no , i think you're constipated and have occasional bouts of diarrhea because of certain foods you eat and we can get you started right away on a fiber supplement that should help with that . [patient] so what about my liver , why is it enlarged ? [doctor] well , there are many reasons why people can have an elevated liver enzymes and also an enlarged liver . some possible causes are certain medications that can be toxic to the liver . alcohol abuse , fatty liver disease , hepatitis , cirrhosis , and other liver diseases like wilson's disease . [patient] so what do i need to do ? [doctor] well , i think since it's been about 4 months since your blood work was done , we should check your liver enzymes in addition to a few other labs . [patient] okay and then what ? [doctor] we will get those drawn today and then depending upon the results , you may need an ultrasound of your liver . i think we need to talk about your medications too . [patient] which medications ? [doctor] crestor , how long have you been taking that ? [patient] about 18 months . [doctor] okay , well crestor is one of the medications that can cause liver toxicity , so it may be a good idea to discuss other alternatives . [patient] should i talk to my primary care or can you change it ? [doctor] i would recommend calling your primary care and discuss that with him since he follows you for your blood pressure and cholesterol . [patient] okay . i'll call him this afternoon . [doctor] great . i also think we should go ahead and get you scheduled for a liver ultrasound . if your blood work looks good , then we can always cancel that . [patient] okay . when do you think i'll be able to get the ultrasound done ? [doctor] hopefully within the next 2 weeks , you will receive a call from the radiology scheduling this afternoon to get it set up . [patient] okay and then what happens ? [doctor] when i get the results from the tests , i'll contact you and depending upon what we find , we'll come up with our next steps . [patient] and when should i see you again ? [doctor] let's schedule an appointment when you check out to return in 4 weeks . we'll discuss how you're doing with the fiber supplement and your constipation and review test results to determine if we need to do further testing on your liver . [patient] okay . is there anything else i can do to help with these issues ? [doctor] definitely refrain from drinking any alcohol , increase your water intake to at least 48 ounces a day , in addition to taking the fiber supplement to help with your constipation and be mindful of eating foods that you are sensitive to so you can avoid the bouts of diarrhea . [patient] okay and i will talk to my primary care about my crestor . [doctor] excellent and do you have any other questions for me ? [patient] i do n't think so . [doctor] great . so remember when you check out at the front desk , schedule a follow-up appointment with me for 4 weeks and then go to the lab to get your blood work drawn . [patient] okay , sounds good . [doctor] and expect a call from radiology scheduling about setting up your ultrasound . [patient] alright . thanks dr. edwards . [doctor] thank you mr. allen .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea
* History of present illness: Intermittent mid-abdominal pain for approximately 2 years, with recent worsening of constipation and occasional diarrhea, pain is a nagging feeling, sometimes alleviated by bowel movements, no blood in stool, no nausea, vomiting, heartburn, or indigestion, weight stable but desires to lose 25 pounds
* Past medical history: GERD, anxiety, depression
* Social history: Occasional alcohol consumption (a couple of beers on Saturdays), no heavy alcohol or drug use, no recent bruising or bleeding, no swelling in ankles or feet
* Family history: Sister with irritable bowel syndrome, no GI cancer or liver disease

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Bowel sounds in all four quadrants, tenderness on palpation on the left side near the belly button, slight hepatomegaly noted, stool in lower colon suggesting stool burden, no jaundice observed, lungs clear, heart sounds normal
* Laboratory and imaging considerations: Recent blood work showed slightly elevated ALT and AST, physical exam indicated increased stool burden and hepatomegaly, upcoming labs and ultrasound planned, no recent colonoscopy performed

A (Assessment):

* No specific diagnoses explicitly provided; possible considerations include: constipation with bowel habit changes, hepatomegaly with elevated liver enzymes, potential functional gastrointestinal issues possibly related to diet or medication effects

P (Plan):

* Initiate fiber supplement to address constipation
* Blood tests to include liver enzymes and additional labs today
* Schedule liver ultrasound within 2 weeks if labs suggest need
* Advise patient to refrain from alcohol, increase water intake to at least 48 ounces daily, and avoid foods triggering diarrhea
* Contact primary care to discuss potential medication changes, especially regarding Crestor
* Follow up in 4 weeks to review lab and ultrasound results and adjust management accordingly

[doctor] and did you have a vasectomy ? [doctor] what time are you going to sleep and about how many hours do you sleep at night ? [patient] it varies usually i get 6 to 7 hours of sleep , i get out of bed some days to be at work by seven lecture and i try to work out in the morning . i i do n't , i'm not , i'm not really successful and now what i do is i , i do make reservations twice a week for 545 swim in the morning . [patient] i believe i snore a little bit , but she has never said anything about me not breathing . [doctor] okay . so you're currently taking vitamin d3 around 5000 units on sundays and 2000 or 50,000 units on sundays excuse me and 2000 on the other 6 days and then clindamycin prior to dental procedures correct . [patient] yeah , that's right . [doctor] have you had a covid-19 shot yet ? [patient] i've received both . my first dose on january 15 , 2021 and my second on february 5 , 2021 . SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Fatigue and routine follow-up of chronic conditions
* History of present illness: Reports increased fatigue, especially at the end of the day, despite continuing bike rides of 20-30 miles. Notes difficulty maintaining previous riding distance and feeling tired after rides. Mentions pursed lip breathing while walking, but no wheezing or shortness of breath. No significant change since last visit. No weight changes or other symptoms reported.
* Past medical history: History of aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair on 1/22/2013
* Social history: Rides a road bike 20-30 miles, typically 6-7 hours of sleep per night, makes reservations for swimming twice weekly
* Family history: No information provided
* Other: Noted presence of a small epididymal nodule on the right testicle, no concern about hernia, no prior vasectomy, no recent infections or trauma

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: 
  - Cardiac: Not specifically described
  - Respiratory: pursed lip breathing observed, low exhalation phase, clear to auscultation, no wheezing
  - Genital: right testicle with 2-3 mm palpable nodule, does not feel like epididymis or varicocele; left testicle normal
  - Abdominal/genital: No hernia palpable
  - Other: Overall physical exam normal
* Laboratory and imaging results:
  - Recent labs: Elevated alkaline phosphatase 156, vitamin D high-normal 94, TSH 2.68, CBC unremarkable, lipid panel shows high total cholesterol 247, HDL 66, LDL 166, triglycerides 74, recent CMP shows elevated alkaline phosphatase
  - Imaging/Studies ordered: Echocardiogram, stress test, pulmonary function test, urology referral for testicular nodule, antibody titers, and vaccinations

A (Assessment):

* History of aortic aneurysm repair and valve replacement, currently asymptomatic and doing well
* Elevated alkaline phosphatase, most likely related to bone health
* Exertional fatigue, possibly related to aging or cardiovascular status
* Pursed lip breathing with low exhalation phase noted; further pulmonary assessment indicated
* Small nodule on right epididymis, assessment pending urology referral
* No evidence of hernia, normal other exam components
* No significant new findings on labs or exam

P (Plan):

* Order and perform echocardiogram and stress test, follow-up with cardiology—recommend Dr. Vincent Sanchez
* Order pulmonary function test to evaluate pursed lip breathing and exhalation
* Refer to urology for evaluation of right testicular nodule
* Conduct further labs: alkaline phosphatase, antibody titers (e.g., MMR, shingles vaccine), and other relevant tests
* Administer MMR vaccine today, schedule shingles vaccine next month
* Continue vitamin D3 supplementation as currently prescribed
* Advise follow-up in about 1 year for wellness visit; see sooner if symptoms change
* Provide patient with instructions and contact information for questions or concerns

transcription: [doctor] next patient is sophia jackson , mrnr 472348 . she is a 57-year-old female who is here for a surgical consult . [patient] her dermatologist referred her . she biopsied a 0.7 mm lesion which was located on the right inferior back . pathology came back as melanoma . [doctor] mrs. jackson , it's good to meet you . [patient] likewise , wish you were under better circumstances . [doctor] yeah , i heard your dermatologist sent you to because she found the melanoma . [patient] yes , that's what the biopsy said . [doctor] okay and when did you first notice the spot ? [patient] my mom noticed it when i was visiting her last month . [doctor] i see and so you went to the dermatologist on april 10 to get it checked out , right ? [patient] yes , i wanted to be extra cautious because skin cancer does run in my family . [doctor] well i'm really glad you took a serious and got it checked . who in your family has had skin cancer and do you know if it was melanoma or was it basal cell or squamous cell ? [patient] my mom and her sister i think they both had melanoma . [doctor] okay . do you have any other types of cancer in the family like breast or ovarian ? [patient] my grandfather had pancreatic cancer . [doctor] okay and what about your mom or dad's father ? [patient] mother's . [doctor] okay and have you personally had any skin spots in the past that you got checked out and they were cancerous or precancerous ? [patient] no , this was the first time i've been to a dermatologist but my primary care doctor looks over all of my moles every year . my physical and has n't said he is concerned about any of them before . [doctor] good , good . let's go over your medical history here in your chart . i have that you are not taking any medications and do n't have any health problems listed , but that you are allergic to augmentin , is that right ? [patient] yes , that's correct . [doctor] okay and for social history , can you tell me what you do for work ? [patient] i own an auto repair shop . okay and have you ever been a smoker ? yeah , i still smoke from time to time . i started that awful habit in my teens and it's hard to break , but i'm trying . [doctor] i'm glad you're trying to quit . what about your surgical history ? have you had any surgeries ? [patient] i had gallbladder and appendix . [doctor] okay , great . we can get your chart up to date now , thank you . and other than the melanoma , how has your health been ? any unintentional weight changes , headaches , fatigue , nausea , vomiting , vision changes ? [patient] no , i've been feeling great . [doctor] good . well , let me take a look at your back here where they did the biopsy if you do n't mind . [patient] sure . [doctor] okay . i'm gon na describe it in medical jargon , what i'm seeing here so that the recording can capture it , but you and i are gon na go over it together in just a moment , okay ? [patient] okay , that's fine . [doctor] alright , so on the right inferior back , there is a 1 cm shave biopsy site including all of the dermis with no residual pigmentation there is no intrinsic or satellite lesions . no other suspicious moles . no axillary , cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy . there is a soft lymph node in the right groin but it's nontender . otherwise normal exam . [patient] okay , you can sit up . so what i was saying there is that i see your biopsy site , but i do n't see any other skin lumps or bumps that look suspicious . [doctor] i also felt your lymph nodes to see if any of them felt abnormal . there is one in the right groin that felt slightly abnormal . it's very likely nothing , but i do want you to have an ultrasound of that area to confirm it's nothing . and you know make sure it's something we need to worry about the reason we are being extra cautious is that melanoma can very rarely metastasize to the lymph nodes . the ultrasound can tell us if we need to look into this further . [patient] okay . i should have worried too much then . [doctor] no , i have a low suspicion that it will show anything . [patient] okay , good . [doctor] so assuming that the ultrasound is normal . the treatment for your melanoma is to cut out the area where the lesion was . with lesions that are 0.7 mm or less and that's what we recommend and yours was exactly 0.7 mm . if it were any bigger , we would have had to do a more complex surgery , but what i recommend for you is what we call a wide local incision , excuse me , excision meaning that i will make a long incision and then cut out an area a bit wider than your current biopsy site . the incision is long because that's what allows me to close the skin nicely . you'll have a fairly long scar from the incision . [patient] okay , that is fine with me . i ca n't see back there anyways . [doctor] yeah , your wife can tell you what it looks like and she may need to help care for the incision at it as it heals . but since we're we are n't doing the more complex surgery , i actually do n't need to see you back unless you wan na check in with me or have any problems , however , it is very important that you continue to follow up with your dermatologist regularly , so she can monitor you . your dermatologist will check if this one does n't come back , but she will also check for other lesions that look suspicious . unfortunately since you had one melanoma , you are at a higher risk of developing another one somewhere else . [patient] yeah , she did say she wants to see me back . [doctor] good and i'm sure she has already told you , but it's very important that you apply sunscreen anytime and anywhere that your skin is exposed to sunlight . [patient] yeah , she definitely went over that several times with me . [doctor] good . other than that , i think that's all for me . we'll get you set up for the ultrasound and the procedure . do you have any questions for me ? [patient] no , i ca n't think of any at this time . [doctor] okay . my nurse will be in to get you scheduled . so sit tight . it was very good to meet you . [patient] thank you . nice to meet you as well . [doctor] please add the following pathology to results a pathology , shave of right inferior back , malignant melanoma , invasive superficial spreading , histology , superficial spreading . clark level iv , breslow thickness 0.7 mm , radial growth phase present , vertical growth phase not identified , mitotic features less than 1 mm² , ulceration not identified , regression not identified , [patient] lymphatic invasion not identified . perineural invasion not identified , microscopic satellitosis not identified , infiltrating lymphocytes , breast , [doctor] melanocytic nevus not identified , predominant cytology , epithelioid , peripheral margin positive , deep margin negative , stage i . also note that i reviewed the dermatologist photo of the lesion , which showed an asymmetric black and brown nevus with central asmelanotic component and a regular border . for assessment and plan , the patient presents today with newly diagnosed melanoma . biopsy revealed an intermediate thickness melanoma . on examination today , there is right inguinal lymph node with slightly atypical consistency . [patient] i recommended an ultrasound to rule out metastatic disease . if the ultrasound is normal , the patient is a candidate for wide local excision with a 1 to 2 cm margin . primary closure should be possible , but skin graft closure may be needed . the relationship between tumor histology and prognosis and treatment was carefully reviewed . the need for follow-up according to the national comprehensive cancer network guidelines was reviewed . we also reviewed the principles of sun avoidance , skin self-examination and the abcde's of mole surveillance . after discussing the procedure , risk and expected outcomes and possible complications , questions were answered and the patient expressed understanding and did choose to proceed .

* Chief complaint: No specific current complaint; here for surgical consultation regarding melanoma diagnosis
* History of present illness: Noticed a skin lesion last month, biopsied on April 10, found to be melanoma; lesion on right inferior back, 0.7 mm in size; family history of melanoma in mother and her sister
* Past medical history: No health problems listed, previous surgeries include gallbladder and appendix
* Allergies: Allergic to augmentin
* Social history: Owns an auto repair shop, smokes intermittently since adolescence
* Family history: Mother and her sister had melanoma, grandfather had pancreatic cancer
* Review of systems: No unintentional weight changes, headaches, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, vision changes reported

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: 
  - Biopsy site on right inferior back: 1 cm shave biopsy with no residual pigmentation, no residual lesions, no suspicious moles, no lymphadenopathy in axillary, cervical, or supraclavicular regions. 
  - Right groin: soft lymph node, slightly abnormal upon palpation.
* Additional findings: No other suspicious skin lesions observed
* Lymph nodes: No abnormal lymphadenopathy found except a slightly atypical lymph node in the right groin
* Imaging: Ultrasound scheduled to evaluate groin lymph node
* Pathology results: Malignant melanoma, superficial spreading, Clark level IV, Breslow thickness 0.7 mm, radial growth phase present, vertical growth phase not identified, mitotic rate less than 1/mm², ulceration not identified, regression not identified, lymphatic invasion not identified, perineural invasion not identified, microscopic satellitosis not identified, infiltrating lymphocytes present, melanocytic nevus not identified, predominant cytology epithelioid, peripheral margin positive, deep margin negative, stage I

A (Assessment):

* No explicit diagnoses or suspected conditions provided by the physician; the key diagnosis is **melanoma** (confirmed by pathology) and accompanying assessment of suspicious lymph node

P (Plan):

* Schedule ultrasound of the right groin to exclude metastatic disease
* If ultrasound is normal, proceed with wide local excision of the melanoma with a 1-2 cm margin; primary closure likely, skin graft may be needed
* Continue regular follow-up with dermatologist for monitoring of skin for new or recurrent lesions
* Emphasize sun protection, skin self-examination, and awareness of ABCDEs of mole surveillance
* Discussed procedure, risks, outcomes, and possible complications with the patient; patient understands and opts to proceed with surgery
* Nurse to schedule ultrasound and surgical procedure

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Persistent right index finger pain, swelling, and inability to make a fist since March following a motor vehicle accident
* History of present illness: Injury occurred during a rear-end collision, felt as if finger was overstretched, with ongoing pain, swelling, and occasional unbearable pain; difficulty moving the finger and making a fist
* Past medical history: No diabetes, no rheumatoid arthritis
* Social history: Works as an x-ray tech, takes a blood pressure medication, no mention of smoking or alcohol use
* No information provided regarding family history or other relevant social history

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Heart rate regular, radial pulse 2+
* Physical exam: No distress, well-appearing male, no swelling or bruising except bruising over volar surface of index finger, normal creases with slight diminution at fingertip, index finger held in 10 degree PIP flexion, tender to pressure and pain with resisted movement, tendon segments and collateral ligaments confirmed intact
* Range of motion: Resistance to full movement with pain, able to make a fist with some discomfort, pain exacerbated by stretching
* Imaging: MRI from 4/24/2021 showing focal soft tissue swelling, partial thickness tear of the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS), fluid indicating tenosynovitis around FDS and flexor digitorum profundus (FDP), collateral ligaments and extensor tendons intact; recent x-rays show no bony abnormalities or arthritis

A (Assessment):

* Posttraumatic severe stenosing tenosynovitis of the right index finger
* Partial tear of the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) tendon, confirmed by MRI

P (Plan):

* Perform steroid injection using 1 cc of betamethasone (celestone) and half a cc of lidocaine; initial attempt caused a painful reaction and was aborted, second attempt planned
* Advise patient to apply ice and use ibuprofen in the evening
* Encourage active and passive range of motion exercises; outpatient therapy recommended, once a week for 6 weeks
* Emphasize the importance of mobilizing the finger to prevent further adhesions and improve function
* Follow-up to assess response to injection and progress in therapy
* No further surgical intervention at this time
* Completed documentation of the trigger finger injection attempt

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right hip pain
* History of present illness: Pain in the right groin area since February 2020, worsens with movement and pivoting, pain range 2-7/10, sometimes causes falls, improves with stillness
* Past medical history: Polycystic ovary syndrome, infertility, gallbladder removal
* Family history: High blood pressure, diabetes, thyroid disease, heart disease, kidney disease, gastric ulcers
* Social history: Works at an infusion center, lives with roommate, no tobacco use, alcohol intake less than five drinks per month
* No information provided about fever, chills, tingling, numbness, bowel or bladder problems

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 115/75 mmHg, pulse rate 67 bpm
* Physical exam: 
  - General: Pleasant 56-year-old woman, height 5'6", weight 169 lbs
  - Lower extremities: No ankle edema, no calf tenderness, ankle and calf exam normal
  - Gait: Walks with ability to stand, walk on toes and heels intact
  - Neck: Full range of motion, no pain, no tenderness, Spurling's test negative
  - Back: No pain with movement, skin intact, no tenderness, full range of motion except decreased exertion; no pain on bending or lateral flexion
  - Pelvis/Hip: No sacroiliac tenderness; right hip decreased range of motion with pain in groin, especially with internal and external rotation; resisted hip flexion causes groin pain; motor control normal; no tenderness or focal deficits
* Imaging: Radiographs/mr arthrogram of the right hip (June 3, 2021) show high-grade chondromalacia with subchondral marrow edema and cyst formation

A (Assessment):

* Right hip degenerative joint disease

P (Plan):

* Initiate low-impact exercise program; provide educational handout
* Prescribe NSAIDs as needed for pain
* Recommend use of a cane to offload the right hip
* Proceed with corticosteroid injection into the right hip joint today
* Educate patient on risks of injection, including sterile technique and COVID-19 protocols
* Schedule follow-up in 3 months for reassessment and potential repeat injection
* No further laboratory or imaging examinations indicated at this time

* History of present illness: Started about 2 weeks ago, woke up with severe pain around 2:00 am, relieved temporarily with ice, pain worsens at night, involves entire arm, accompanying weakness in hand and finger, numbness previously experienced, some days the pain persists following nocturnal episodes
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Takes eliquis, no blood thinners other than eliquis mentioned
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Elderly white male in wheelchair, no apparent distress, bilateral muscle strength 1+ in biceps, triceps, brachioradialis reflexes negative, no abnormal findings in extremities, neck muscles non-tender, mild restriction in cervical extension and lateral rotation, no radicular pain, benign Spurling's maneuver, cervical x-ray shows significant disc degeneration at C3-4, C4-5, C5-6, and lower lumbar facet arthropathy at C6-7 and C7-T1 was difficult to visualize
* Neurological exam: Musculoskeletal, strength and sensation as per template, gait not assessed today

A (Assessment):

* Left upper extremity neuropathy possibly related to cervical radiculopathy and peripheral neuropathy
* Neck pain associated with arthritis and disc degeneration in cervical spine

P (Plan):

* Suspected cervical radiculopathy flare; order cervical MRI to evaluate nerve root compression
* Plan for a left C7-T1 epidural injection pending MRI results
* Continue home exercise program and twice daily gabapentin
* Follow-up after imaging and treatment to assess relief
* No use of blood thinners other than eliquis confirmed

P (Plan):

SOAP:
S (Subjective):  
* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath, coughing up blood  
* History of present illness: Shortness of breath waking the patient up, occurring for about two weeks, worsening with exertion; coughing up blood (3-4 cups per day) for approximately three weeks; no fever reported; no leg swelling or calf tenderness; no other bleeding or bruising noted; no recent travel; knee pain present but no swelling  
* Past medical history: Diabetes, high blood pressure, asthma  
* Social history: No alcohol or substance use reported; no smoking mentioned; no recent travel  

O (Objective):  
* Vital signs: Oxygen saturation 94%, blood pressure 120/70 mmHg (sometimes in the low 90s), pulse rate normal  
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no neck swelling, no carotid bruits; lung exam: some rails and rhonchi more prominent on the right side, with diminished breath sounds on the right; heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, normal rhythm; abdomen: soft, no tenderness or masses; extremities: nonpitting edema 1+ in both ankles, no calf tenderness, negative Homan's sign  
* Examination findings verbalized: No JVD, no neck swelling, lungs show signs of possible lung infection or pathology, cardiac exam with unchanged systolic murmur, edema in lower extremities  

A (Assessment):  
* Shortness of breath with hemoptysis, lung findings suggestive of pulmonary pathology, possibly pneumonia or other lung pathology (unchanged from prior)  
* Coughing up blood (hemoptysis), approximately 3-4 cups daily for 3 weeks  
* No other active bleeding, no leg swelling or calf tenderness; stable cardiac exam with systolic murmur  
* No diagnosis explicitly stated but concern for underlying pulmonary issue with possible infection or blood clot; asthma and mild heart murmur noted; no evidence of congestive heart failure signs currently  

P (Plan):  
* Obtain chest X-ray to evaluate lung condition  
* Refer to emergency department for chest X-ray, CT scan, and blood tests to rule out blood clot and identify underlying cause of hemoptysis and shortness of breath  
* Blood work to be performed in ED; follow-up after diagnostic results  
* Reassess after initial testing for possible pneumonia or other serious lung pathology  
* Delay resumption of Norvasc; hold medication until further evaluation of blood pressure and cause of symptoms  
* Order repeat hemoglobin A1c to evaluate diabetes control  
* Increase metformin dosage from 500 mg twice daily to 750 mg twice daily after stabilizing current issues  
* Follow-up appointment in 3 weeks to review blood sugar management and treatment plan  
* No further questions from the patient

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chest pain and shortness of breath
* History of present illness: Recently experienced chest pain similar to previous heart attack, prompting emergency visit and stent placement; no current chest pain or shortness of breath reported; symptoms occurred after a recent stent placement for inferior STEMI
* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes mellitus
* Social history: Walks dog daily (~1.5-2 miles), plans for holidays with family, no specific plans
* Additional: Noted leg swelling since hospital discharge; patient reports ability to lie flat with use of pillows; taking prescribed medications; dietary habits include pizza and processed meats; managing blood sugars with metformin and walking actively

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific readings provided, but noted as good
* Physical exam:
   - Neck: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits
   - Heart: Systolic ejection murmur (3/6) at the left base
   - Lungs: Clear
   - Extremities: Pitting lower limb edema (1+), right radial artery pulses palpable, cath site: clean, dry, intact, no hematoma
* Test results:
   - EKG: Normal sinus rhythm, good R wave progression, expected post-STEMI changes
   - Echocardiogram: Reduced ejection fraction of 35%, moderate mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

* Coronary artery disease
* Newly reduced left ventricular systolic function (ejection fraction 35%)
* Moderate mitral regurgitation
* Possible acute heart failure (due to fluid retention and edema)
* Hypertension (controlled)

P (Plan):

* Continue medications: aspirin 81 mg daily, brilinta 90 mg twice daily, lipitor 80 mg daily, toprol 50 mg daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily
* Refer to cardiac rehab for education and exercise confidence
* Prescribe diuretics for fluid retention: lasix 40 mg daily, aldactone 12.5 mg daily
* Arrange repeat echocardiogram in 2 months
* Labs: Obtain relevant labs (e.g., renal function, electrolytes)
* Nutrition counseling: Advise to limit salt and processed meats, explore dietary modifications
* Follow-up: Regular monitoring of cardiac function and symptoms

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee injury with swelling and limited function
* History of present illness: Right knee "popped" during soccer playing about three days ago, swelling has decreased but knee feels limited in motion and function, pain rated 6-7/10 currently, 4-5/10 with some swelling reduction; relief with anti-inflammatory medication (ibuprofen)
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Regular jogging, currently advised to slow down activity and avoid jogging until further evaluation
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Marked effusion in the right knee, slight ecchymosis, tenderness at medial joint line, pain on palpation, positive Lachman test, limited passive range of motion (terminal extension approximately 115°, limited terminal flexion approximately 20-30°), muscle strength 5/5 bilaterally, neurovascular status intact, gait shows marked limp on right leg
* Test results: No imaging or laboratory results yet

A (Assessment):

* Suspected anterior cruciate ligament tear (ACL tear)

P (Plan):

* Order MRI to evaluate ACL integrity
* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily to reduce swelling and pain
* Advise ice application to knee for swelling and pain control
* Recommend wearing a knee immobilizer and using crutches to minimize stress on the knee
* Advise limited activity and significant activity restriction, including avoiding jogging
* Educate patient on activity moderation to prevent knee locking
* Schedule follow-up once MRI results are available to determine further management

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness, tingling, and pain in the right hand
* History of present illness: Symptoms have been intermittent for six months, more persistent in the last month. Pain occurs mainly during typing and when using the mouse, with numbness and tingling occurring all the time. Pain is alleviated by rest and taking ibuprofen. No symptoms wake the patient at night.
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Pain on wrist flexion and extension, pain upon wrist movement, numbness in thumb, index finger, and middle finger predominantly on the right, decreased grip strength on the right, positive Tinel's sign at the wrist, grimacing when tapping on the inner wrist indicating nerve discomfort

A (Assessment):

* Carpal tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Prescribe wrist splint to wear at night
* Continue ibuprofen, increase dose to 600 mg four times daily
* Order outpatient nerve conduction study (EMG)
* Educate patient on conservative treatment and possible surgical options if nerve conduction study indicates
* Follow-up to review test results and decide on further management

SOAP:
S (Subjective):  
- Chief complaint: Inside right knee pain after injury during basketball  
- History of present illness: Fell to the ground while playing basketball about 7 days ago, landed on side of the knee, unable to continue, swelling and pain on the inside of the knee, had ice and ace wrap immediately after injury  
- Past medical history: Diabetes, taking metformin 500 mg twice daily, monitors blood sugars every morning  
- Social history: Plays basketball at the YMCA for fun  
- Family history: No information provided  

O (Objective):  
- Vital signs: No information provided  
- Physical exam: Swelling and ecchymosis on the inside of the right knee, effusion present, tenderness on medial aspect of knee, decreased range of motion with pain during movement, no pain on external palpation or when pushing on the outside of the knee, no injury heard or felt when pushing, negative varus and valgus stress tests, right knee alignment in good position on x-ray  
- Test results: X-ray shows no fractures, small joint effusion observed, fluid present in the knee; no evidence of bony abnormality or dislocation  

A (Assessment):  
- Suspected medial collateral ligament strain of the right knee  

P (Plan):  
- Continue using an ace wrap and a knee brace for stabilization  
- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling, discontinue current NSAIDs (Motrin/Advil)  
- Recommend light walking and continuation of exercises with brace  
- Refer for physical therapy to strengthen knee muscles  
- Follow-up appointment in 7 days for reevaluation and possible advanced imaging (MRI or CT scan) if swelling persists or worsens  
- Advise patient to avoid playing basketball for at least one week  
- Remind patient to monitor blood sugars closely due to decreased activity and continue regular diabetes management  
- Encourage patient to contact primary care provider if blood sugars elevate significantly  

**Any questions?**

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left back pain, blood in urine
* History of present illness: Pain started about three days ago, constant, traveling lower, severe enough that the patient cannot get comfortable, has not passed the stone yet, associated with nausea, chills, inability to eat, and blood in urine this morning
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure ranged from 130–150/70–80 mmHg (blood pressure elevated but improved), blood pressure cuff used sporadically
* Physical exam: Tenderness on abdominal palpation, flank tenderness on right, no rebound or guarding, heart: grade 2 systolic ejection murmur, lungs: clear bilaterally
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

* Suspected kidney stone with inflammation around the kidney, as evidenced by flank tenderness and CVA tenderness; history of recurrent kidney stones (third episode); hypertension; diabetes

P (Plan):

* Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6–8 hours as needed for pain, continue Tylenol for breakthrough pain
* Advise increased fluid intake to aid stone passage
* Provide a urine strainer to monitor for passing stone
* Refer to urology for further evaluation and management of recurrent kidney stones
* Continue current blood pressure medication (Norvasc 2.5 mg)
* Maintain metformin 500 mg for diabetes, refer to nutritionist/dietitian for dietary counseling, including salt intake reduction
* Follow-up for pain management and possible stone passage
* Educate patient on signs of infection or complications requiring urgent care

* Chief complaint: Bilateral elbow pain, worse on the right side
* History of present illness: Onset approximately 1.5 years ago, worsening with use of hands or arms; pain located inside elbows; pain with flexion, extension, and torsion; no relief with icing; pain limited on extension but not on flexion; pain on medial side of elbows; no pain on outside of elbows; no numbness or sensation changes reported
* Past medical history: No specific medical history provided

* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: 
  - Right elbow: Pain with flexion and extension, limited extension range of motion, pain with torsion and supination, no pain with pronation, pain on medial side with palpation, no pain outside the elbow, normal sensation, pulses equal
  - Left elbow: Mildly less pain with movement, some pain with flexion and extension, no pain on outside, normal sensation, pulses equal

P (Plan):

* Aim to heal within two weeks, especially considering upcoming childbirth
* Follow-up after MRI and procedure as needed

my assessment and plan now for for the first concern of right foot pain your right foot pain is due to a lisfranc fracture which is a fracture to one of your second metatarsal bones at the top of your foot where the metatarsals meet your cuboids now there are ligaments at the top of your foot so i'm gon na be ordering an mri to assess for injury to any of these ligaments now based on your exam and from what i'm seeing on your x-ray you're most likely going to need surgery of that foot now the surgery will place the bones back in their proper position and using plates and screws will hold them there while they heal and this is gon na allow those bones and ligaments to heal properly it is a day surgery and you will be able to go home the same day and then i'm going to have you follow up with me here in the clinic you'll be in a cast and you will need to use crutches and you will not be able to use that left foot for about six to eight weeks now after that six to eight weeks you will gradually start walking on your foot based on how you tolerate it and we'll see how you do at that point so i do believe you're gon na need surgery i i'm recommending this because there are significant complications to your foot if we do not do this poor bone and ligament healing can lead to losing the arch of your foot and you're becoming flat-footed you also have a high likelihood of developing arthritis in that foot so what i'm gon na do unfortunately you'll be out the rest of the season but we are gon na get you fixed up and ready for next season if you're okay with all of this i'm gon na have the nurse come in and get you started on your paperwork and then i will see you on monday morning and we will get your foot taken care of
[patient] alright thank you
[doctor] you're welcome
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Foot pain
* History of present illness: Pain started after falling onto the left foot during a soccer game, unable to continue playing, pain level with ibuprofen is 3, without ibuprofen is 7-8, swelling and bruising observed, tenderness on palpation of midfoot, positive piano key test
* Past medical history: No previous injury to this foot
* Social history: Long-term soccer player since age 4-5, played through school and high school
* No information provided on family history or other medical conditions

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 118/72 mmHg, heart rate 58/min, respiratory rate 14/min, afebrile, oxygen saturation 99% on room air
* Physical exam: Bruising on bottom and top of left foot, swelling, tenderness of midfoot, positive piano key test, neurovascular intact with brisk capillary refill (<3 sec), dorsalis pedis pulse strong and intact, motor and sensation to light touch preserved
* Imaging findings: Subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal, 3 mm separation of the first and second metatarsal bases, bony fragment in the Lisfranc joint space

A (Assessment):

* Lisfranc fracture of the left foot

P (Plan):

* Order MRI to assess for ligament injury
* Recommend surgery to realign bones with plates and screws, performed as day surgery
* Postoperative care includes immobilization in a cast, crutches, and non-weight bearing on the left foot for 6-8 weeks
* Follow-up in the clinic after surgery to monitor healing
* Educate about potential complications if not treated, including arch loss, flat-footedness, and arthritis
* Advise patient that recovery will extend through the season; aim for readiness for next season
* Have nurse assist with paperwork and schedule follow-up appointment on Monday

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, affecting daily activities
* History of present illness: Loose and watery stool, frequent bowel movements (around six to seven times daily), lower abdominal pain on one side, headache on the left side rated 8/10, cramp-like, intermittent, associated with weakness and shakiness, occurred three days ago, no blood in stool, no fever currently but experienced a temperature at symptom onset, vomited initially but stopped vomiting, loss of appetite, difficulty with vision and light sensitivity, no neck pain or stiffness, no difficulty speaking or weakness in arms and legs, no recent head injuries, no rashes, no recent head trauma or similar past episodes, recent takeaway food consumption, no other medical conditions besides asthma, no allergies to medications, no smoking or alcohol intake, stress or anxiety recently increased, no other notable symptoms.

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No physical examination details provided
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

* Likely viral gastroenteritis with associated headache and light sensitivity, possibly migraine given family history

P (Plan):

* Prescribed stronger analgesics (e.g., alternative painkillers such as paracetamol or codeine), considering previous ibuprofen use
* Advised maintaining hydration and using a headache diary to identify potential triggers
* Follow-up in 1 to 2 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen, including new or worsening neurological signs
* Educated patient on warning signs such as vision problems or limb weakness requiring immediate medical attention

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stool, frequent defecation affecting daily activities, cramp-like pain in lower abdomen on the left side, feeling weak and shaky, started about 4-5 days ago, associated with fever, hot sensation, and vomiting initially, now stopped vomiting, loss of appetite but able to hold fluids
* Additional symptoms: Runny nose, mild sore throat, muscle stiffness all over, intermittent white spots and redness in the back of the throat, no chest pain or dyspnea, no blood in stool, no blood in vomit, no ear pain or blocked ears, no significant cough, no chest tightness, no alcohol or smoking, no recent exposure to contagious illnesses in family
* Medical history: Diabetes (type not specified), high blood pressure (on Lisinopril)
* Social history: Lives with wife, work as an accountant, no smoking, no alcohol consumption
* No medication allergies reported

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No physical exam findings documented
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

* No definitive diagnosis explicitly provided; suspected viral or early respiratory illness with gastrointestinal involvement
* Likely viral gastroenteritis or flu-like illness, based on symptom profile and clinical judgment; no evidence of bacterial infection or pneumonia noted
* No confirmed diagnoses; differential diagnoses not explicitly discussed

P (Plan):

* Advise rest and increased fluid intake
* Recommend taking paracetamol for fever and body aches as needed
* Prescribe amoxicillin 500 mg, three times daily, if symptoms persist or worsen over 24-48 hours
* Follow-up if no improvement by next week or if new symptoms develop
* No additional tests or referrals indicated at this time

* Family history: No relatives with rheumatology diseases or similar symptoms

* No definitive diagnosis provided; differential considerations include infectious or inflammatory causes for diarrhea, possible bursitis of the elbow suspected

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea lasting three days, affecting daily activities
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stool approximately 6-7 times daily, with lower left abdominal cramp, weakness, and shakiness; onset about three days ago
* Additional symptoms: Shortness of breath worsening over past few days, mild chest discomfort, dry cough, swelling in ankles, feeling hot, loss of appetite, vomiting initial days (stopped now), no blood in stool, no chest pain, no palpitations, no fever at present, no abnormal urination, no significant alcohol or smoking, regular medications including diuretics, no known allergies
* Past medical history: Heart failure, asthma (controlled with inhaler)
* Family history: Father died in early sixties, no other relevant medical history
* Social history: Works as an accountant, lives alone with two cats, no smoking or alcohol currently, generally healthy apart from heart failure and asthma
* No recent travel or specific exposures other than eating at a Chinese restaurant four days ago

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific measurements provided
* Physical exam: No detailed findings recorded
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results available at this time

A (Assessment):

* Suspected heart failure flare-up based on recent worsening breathlessness, ankle swelling, and medical history
* No other explicit diagnoses or suspected conditions documented; diarrhea etiology remains undetermined

* Increase Furosemide to two tablets daily for initial management
* Arrange blood tests (full blood count, kidney function) and echocardiogram of the heart
* Follow-up appointment scheduled in about one week to assess progress
* Advise patient to seek medical attention sooner if symptoms worsen (e.g., increased breathlessness, chest pain, palpitations, dizziness)
* Patient education about symptom monitoring and medication adherence

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stools occurring 6-7 times daily, associated with lower abdominal cramp, weakness, shakiness, feeling hot, loss of appetite, and vomiting initially. Symptoms started approximately four days ago after eating takeaway from a Chinese restaurant. No blood in stools. No fever currently but had a temperature at symptom onset. Difficulties staying close to the toilet and impacting daily activities. No other symptoms such as chest pain or abnormal urination. No contact with individuals with diarrhea, but one family member experienced vomiting without diarrhea.
* Past medical history: Asthma (uses inhaler, under control), diabetes (type not specified)
* Social history: Lives alone, non-smoker, does not consume alcohol, currently working
* Family history: Mother with diabetes

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No physical examination findings available
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

* Likely gastroenteritis (viral or bacterial origin) suspected based on history and symptom pattern

P (Plan):

* Advise to drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration, including Dioralyte for electrolyte replenishment
* Recommend taking paracetamol if feeling feverish or weak
* Suggest taking time off work until symptom-free for 24-48 hours
* Inform to return if symptoms persist beyond the next week or worsen
* No further investigations or referrals indicated at this time

* Past medical history: No specific illnesses mentioned

* No laboratory results or imaging findings provided

A (Assessment):

* No explicit diagnoses or suspected conditions provided

P (Plan):

* Provided contact numbers for hospital PALS and TIA clinic for follow-up

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days affecting daily activities
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stools occurring frequently, with lower abdominal cramp pain on the left side, waking the patient 6-7 times per night, associated with feeling weak and shaky, preceded by feeling hot and a mild fever three or four days ago, accompanied by neck stiffness and headache, sensitivity to light, and previous vomiting at symptom onset
* Past medical history: History of anxiety, previous vomiting, use of inhaler for asthma
* Family history: Family members have migraines, no other relevant illnesses
* Social history: No smoking, no alcohol consumption, working as an accountant, recent intake of takeaway food, normal diet otherwise, no current exercise routine, living situation unknown, no pets mentioned

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific measurements provided
* Physical exam: No direct examination findings recorded
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results available

A (Assessment):

* No specific diagnoses confirmed or suspected; symptoms suggest gastroenteritis possibly linked to recent food intake, with concurrent headache possibly indicative of tension headache or migraine, considering sensitivity to light and unilateral head pain; neck stiffness present, but no definitive diagnosis made

P (Plan):

* Advise self-certification for one week off work to reduce stress and explore counseling options via referral link
* Recommend increasing sleep to 7-8 hours per night and fluid intake of 1.5-2 liters daily (excluding coffee or tea)
* Monitor symptoms; follow-up in one week; if symptoms worsen or do not improve, consider blood tests and further evaluation
* Provide patient with information on danger signs for headaches and instruct to contact the practice if symptoms change or worsen

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stool, frequent bowel movements, lower abdominal cramp on the left side, feelings of weakness and shakiness, some nausea and vomiting, increased frequency of urination, no blood in stool, diarrhea affecting daily activities, symptoms started about three days ago
* Past medical history: Asthma (uses inhaler), hypertension (taking list of medications including Zinopril), diabetes (managed by a doctor), no other medical conditions
* Social history: Works as an accountant, smokes, drinks alcohol (mentioned drinking wine, possibly weekly), drinks alcohol on nights out (about 2 glasses per occasion), exposure to potential contaminated food (ate at a Chinese restaurant)
* Family history: No known family illnesses reported
* Additional info: No recent fever, no skin rashes, no joint or muscle problems besides asthma, no recent trauma or injuries, no current chest pain or waterworks issues

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific values provided
* Physical exam: No detailed physical exam findings recorded
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results available

A (Assessment):

* No specific diagnoses explicitly stated; likely viral gastroenteritis based on symptom history and duration
* Symptoms consistent with viral illness, including diarrhea, cough, and transient fever
* No evidence of bacterial infection, no blood in stool, and symptoms improving

P (Plan):

* Supportive management: Adequate hydration, rest, use of paracetamol for fever or discomfort
* Dietary advice: Continue light foods, avoid alcohol and potentially contaminated foods
* Symptom monitoring: If no improvement in 2-3 days or worsening cough/breathing, return for re-evaluation
* Consider antibiotics if symptoms persist or worsen
* Advise to avoid work for a day or two, until improvement
* Follow-up: Re-evaluate if symptoms do not resolve or worsen in next few days
